PETITION.TITLE: Preservation of the Environment
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

But for a High Court decision narrowly favouring the Federal Government, 20,000 years old archaeological cave sites near the Franklin River, Tasmania, would have been destroyed, like a United Kingdom Government unable to stop a Wiltshire authority from clearing Stonehenge for a freeway. Constitutional protection for historical and environmental assets is needed.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government to hold a referendum to amend the constitution so that the Federal Government has the bounded constitutional duty, which any citizen may legally require it to perform and a right superior to state and local governments, to set above the commercial advantage of one generation, protect and restore all we hold in trust for the future-including relics, sites, features, areas, wildlife, buildings or things of Aboriginal and other historical, cultural architectural, scientific, aesthetic, ecological or environmental importance and-to care for the maintenance of the balance of nature, manage land, marine and atmospheric use so as to avoid their degradation and act nationally and internationally in any matter seen as related to these including-to prevent military and commercial use of uranium and derivatives, beach and related mining; to preserve Heritage Areas, The Great Barrier Reef Region at least as originally defined in the 1975 Act and extended into Torres Strait.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Drugs

Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should heed the above.

The adoption of the upgraded Tax-File Number proposal would allow an increase of databanks and surveillance methods, and thus would be an intrusion on the traditional rights that have been enjoyed in Australia.

There are other parallel threats to our privacy and liberties, such as the move to give Police in Australia and overseas access to Australian income tax records, and to give computer access to those records through a bureau in Brussels, and the move to give State police power to listen to private telephone conversation.

DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING (PROHIBITION OF VIOLENT PROGRAMS FOR CHILDREN) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Vallentine) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced:
A Bill for an Act to amend the Broadcasting Act 1942 to prohibit the broadcasting for children of violent programs with which toys are associated.
Motion (by Senator Vallentine) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have my second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill seeks to address an issue which has become of increasing concern to many Australians-the exposure to and manipulation of children by violent television programs.

The Bill is based on three undeniable facts. First, that children are very susceptible to the influence of television images and the behaviour such images promote. Secondly, this susceptibility is manipulated and exploited in the market place, and thirdly, and most importantly, these images and their associated toys are becoming more prevalent and more violent in nature.
It has reached the stage where many programs are merely ``program length commercials'' for various products. These have become a cynical force, or should I say farce, in children's television.
It is time that this legislature stopped the tidal wave of television programs aimed at the nation's children; which are violent shows promoting violent toys.
I will now briefly outline to the Senate the extent of infiltration of such programs and their toys.
Children's cartoon programs that have been shown, or are showing on Australian TV screens are:
He Man and Masters of the Universe, currently showing each weekday morning on Channel 7's Earlybird program. `He Man' averages 21 acts of violence per hour.

Galvotron, with an average of 70 acts of violence per hour, has a hugely successful line of toys, known as Transformers usually in the form of a robot that the child can manipulate into a tank or spaceship.

Voltron, which until recently was showing at 7 a.m. every weekday morning on Channel 2. Probably the repeat rights expired because the ABC has replaced it with another program based on the same sort of combative model, that is, Battle of the Planets.
Robotech, with 70 acts of violence per hour, currently shows on Channel 9 at 8 a.m. on Saturday.
Centurions, with 84 acts of violence per hour, was showing on Channel 10 in 1987.

M.A.S.K. (Mobile Armoured Strike Force), with 70 acts of violence per hour, was showing on Channel 9 last year. MASK toys by Toltoy were the top selling boys' toy in Australia in 1986, with almost half a million pieces sold in our country.
Bravestarr, shows at 6 a.m. on Saturday on Channel 9. Its associated action doll, looking like a combined cowboy-spaceman actually hit toy shelves here before its television series arrived.
Pac-Man, shows on Channel 7 at 6.30 a.m. on Saturday. There are Pac-Man video games.

Captain Power and Soldiers of the Future (with an incredible 130 acts of violence per hour), was shown three times on Channel 9 recently but then withdrawn. The associated toys by Mattel are ``TV interactive'' computerised fighter planes that children fire at the screen to kill their cartoon enemies. The TV emits coded signals which are detected by these toys, which register when children hit a target. The hand-held toys may also be zapped by signals from the screen, in which case, the little fighter pilots actually eject from their planes but being ``goodies'' of course they are invulnerable, and can soon be reinstalled so that the game can go on. There must be a better application of this brilliant technology than that!

The list of these program length commercials goes on-there's She Ra: Princess of Power (sister of He-Man, she matches some of his exploits; Thundercats, Gobots, Dragon Force Ninja, Inhumanoids (with 87 acts of violence per hour and associated toys by Hasbro), Silverhawks, Action Force and more.
This Bill inserts a new provision, s.118A, in the Broadcast Act 1942 to prohibit the Australian Broadcasting Corporation or a television broadcasting licensee from broadcasting a program that
(a) is designed for children; and
(b) depicts acts of violence

if the Corporation or the licensee as the case may be, is aware that toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories depicted in the program, being toys designed on a theme of violence or war, are available for purchase in Australia.''

At present s.118 of the Act prohibits the Corporation or a licensee from broadcasting certain objectionable items, specifically ``matter which is blasphemous, indecent or obscene''. It also prohibits a person from rendering for broadcast, or passing or selecting for broadcast, an item, which contains matter which is ``blasphemous, indecent or obscene''.
It is important to note that offences against the existing s.118 may be prosecuted only with the written consent of the Minister for Transport and Communications.
The Bill however, imposes no such limitations in relation to prosecutions under the proposed s.118A. It therefore retains the right of members of the public to initiate a private prosecution.
There are several reasons why the Bill seeks to prohibit these programs by inserting a new provision in the Act itself.

First, it is the only real option available to me as under the Broadcasting Act it is the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal which has the function of determining program standards and it is appropriate that it has this role. However I believe it is also entirely appropriate that such an important concern as violence on children's programs be expressed specifically in the Act itself. It should be alongside the other ``objectionable'' matters which are deemed sufficiently important to be in the existing s.118 of the Act.
The Tribunal could expand its existing Children's Television Standards to incorporate and elaborate on the operation of s.118A.

Secondly, it is important to note that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and SBS are not expressly bound to comply with the program standards determined by the Tribunal. The Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act does however, direct the ABC to take account of the standards from time to time approved by the Tribunal.
Therefore it is important to have this prohibition in the Act itself, expressly applying to the ABC (as does the existing s.118) as well as licensees.

The third reason why the proposed amendment is appropriate is that it fits in with one of the main underlying philosophies of the Broadcasting Act which is to enable the public and the Tribunal to work together to determine what is permissible in our children's television programs.
More specifically, it would potentially enable the public to participate in a review of a licence by the Tribunal if the proposed s.118A was contravened.

The mechanisms of the Act would work in the following way: the prohibition in the proposed s.118A (as with all the other provisions in the Act) would be incorporated as a condition of a television licence. Where the Tribunal is satisfied that a condition of the licence has not been complied with it must refuse to renew the licence it may also suspend or revoke the licence.

Public participation is facilitated because the Act empowers any person to make an application to the Tribunal requesting the Tribunal to exercise any of its substantive powers, one of which is the power to suspend or revoke a licence.

Where the Tribunal receives such an application (or proposes to investigate a breach on its own initiative) the Tribunal must hold an inquiry. Such inquiries are generally required to be held in public.
Submissions may be made to a public inquiry by any concerned person.

Fourthly, placing the amendment in the Act itself means that where a licensee or the ABC contravenes s.118A they would be subject to the pecuniary penalties set out in s.132 of the Act ranging from $2,000-$10,000 for a body corporate.

Overall then, there are four main sanctions for a breach of the proposed s.118A by a licensee: prosecution either by a member of the public or the Director of Public Prosecutions; refusal to renew a licence by the Tribunal; possible suspension or revocation of a licence by the Tribunal; and a fine under s.132. In practice it is the Tribunal's power to review licences which is the most effective sanction against licensees who transgress.
The ABC is not subject to the licensing provision of the Act and where it contravenes s.118A it is subject to a fine under s.132.

Importantly the philosophy of this Bill is quite in keeping with the existing Children's Television Standards determined by the Tribunal. But the Bill specifically addresses a phenomena which has developed fairly recently and tightens up the controls on such cartoons.
Children's Television Standard 12 prohibits the broadcasting of programs which:
(a) demean any group of class of people on the basis of their sex, age, race, ethnicity, disability, religious beliefs or political convictions; or
(b) present images or events in a way which is unduly frightening or unduly disturbing to children.

It is confusing, to say the least, why many of the programs I refer to are assessed as complying with Standard 12. Many questions could be raised concerning whether war cartoons do demean people on the basis of their sex-as most cartoons are based on ``macho'' action men and contain no positive or worthwhile view of females; and on the basis of race and ethnicity-as they encourage the view that killing and ``zapping'' the enemy i.e. those who are different, is an appropriate form of behaviour.

Likewise it could be argued that many of these cartoons are frightening and disturbing to children. Both in the short term where research has shown that children may become more aggressive and agitated while watching such programs; and in the long term, where the seeds of such disturbance have been planted but may manifest themselves later through violent teenage and adult life. I will refer shortly to the large body of research which shows such consequences.

However, for the purposes of supporting this Bill I want to focus on Children's Television Standard 11 which recognises the particular susceptibility of children to products and prizes associated with a program. Among other things it restricts the presenter from recommending or endorsing a product or service which is presented as a prize, or encouraging children to buy it. Pre-school Standards 8 and 9 are in similar terms. These standards recognise that children regard the images on the television as authoritative or at least as desirable role models and are therefore susceptible to manipulation in the market place.

The Bill goes a step further and makes it clear that programs which encourage, endorse or are based on certain violent war toys associated with the programs should be prohibited and it inserts the prohibition in the Act itself.
It is important to learn from the United States experience where such programs are allowed.

Deregulation of American children's television programs was started in force in 1982 by Mark Fowler, then Commissioner of the F.C.C. (Federal Communications Commission, which is the U.S. Government's television control board). Since then, a glut of toy based cartoons has been developed, emanating to many countries including Australia.

Such program length commercials had been banned by the F.C.C. in 1969 because research had shown that children were unable to distinguish between programming and advertising. The ruling was also due to the rights of children to have programming made for them-and not merely as a means to profit through sales of related toys.

Since the discarding of these restrictions in '82, (at the request of powerful toy manufacturer, Mattel) 80 per cent of all children's programming in the U.S. has consisted of programs funded by toy companies to sell their various lines of toys, many of which promote adversarial, war-based play by children. In fact, between 1982 and 1986, the sales of war toys increased by 600 to 700 per cent in the U.S. Starting off with `He Man' which first aired in 1983, there have been at least 40 war cartoon series.
We must see children's television programs which are violent and their war toys as one total package.

The industry's response to the plethora of research linking violence in children's television programs with aggressive, antisocial or disturbed behaviour in children, has been devastatingly irresponsible and unfortunately parents seem to be unable to resist the temptation of using TV as a built-in baby-sitter. Research by the TV industry itself shows that most children select their own programs.

The recent Victorian Committee of Inquiry on Anti-Social Toys called for the banning of toys of violence (i.e. toys designed to inflict real or imagined harm such as Transformers) and war toys, (which include toys, war games, model kits or soldiers and scenes or war). Examining psychological studies on the impact of such toys brought the Committee to this conclusion. 12 out of 13 studies on toy guns and war toys reported harmful effects on normal children from playing with violent toys when compared with non-violent toys.

Via the toys that adults buy for children, they transmit certain values-war toys embody attitudes that are pro-militarism, pro-racism and pro-sexism. These toys become props for children to imitate the violent themes of their related TV cartoon shows. This connection becomes even more insidious when we realise that these war toys are actually designed first, and then the animated cartoons are created afterwards in order to entice child viewers into the toy stores. Children who have swallowed the marketing pitch of the cartoon shows and/or have been influenced by peers, often wield remarkable consumerist power over their parents these days.
The combined might of these violent, futuristic children's TV shows and associated lines of war toys, is encouraging children to come to some worrying and antisocial conclusions:
- that the way to successfully solve problems and conflicts is to apply violence with all speed;
- that heroes are invincible, have no sense of fear and always shoot faster and hit harder than their adversaries;
- that being a hero depends on physical power and strength of weaponry-and for a man, on getting his own way;
- that enemies have no redeeming features being totally evil and unworthy and therefore subjects to be killed;
- that violence itself is entertaining;
- that it is appropriate that so much human ingenuity should be expended on more new and spectacular ways to kill and destroy.

As children's violent cartoons concentrate on perpetual exciting action and high points of violent confrontation, extremely little attention is paid to either the causes or consequences of such violent actions. This is neither a healthy nor realistic understanding for children to develop about violence.

Murray and Lonnborg, in an article published in 1986 in Media Information Australia, wrote ``Most psychologists who have ever conducted research in the area . . . are convinced by the accumulated evidence from hundreds of research projects that indicate a relationship between TV violence and children's aggressive behaviour (Murray, J. and Lonnborg-Article in Media Information (1986).

Frost (1986) stated that research shows that viewing cartoon, violence increases children's aggression and playground violence, their verbal hostility, anger levels and intensity of violent responses. Further, it reduces sharing behaviour and imaginative play, decreases enthusiasm for school, produces and increases anxiety, maintains long term aggression, and produces false understandings of social realities. He also refers to numerous studies which document harmful effects of playing with war toys, so many of which are now promoted by violent cartoons (Frost, Joe Influences of Television on Children's Behaviour. Paper presented at the international Association for the Child's right to play Seminar. (Birmingham, August 26, 1986).

Sprafkin, Gadow and Grayson (1987) found that children with low IQs became increasingly more physically aggressive following aggressive cartoons as compared with controls (Sprafkin, J. Gadow, I.C. and Grayson, P.-Effects of Viewing Aggressive cartoons on the behaviour of learning disabled children. Jnl of child psychology and psychiatry and allied disciplines. May 87 Vo1 28 (3).

The report by the New Zealand Ministerial Committee of Inquiry into Violence (March, 1987) stated the following: ``In our opinion, analysis of television content shows that television certainly does not portray violence as it actually occurs in real life. It grossly distorts and exaggerates this aspect of life, and by these distortions, offers harmful models to its young viewers.'' Also, ``The Commission concluded that there was enough established knowledge of public concern about long term cumulative effects of viewing high levels of violence to warrant action to reduce the amount of it shown on television.'' (Report of Ministerial Committee of Inquiry into Violence (NZ) March 1987, 131-133

Dr Di Bretherton a Melbourne psychologist was quoted in the October 1988 issue of Habitat: ``Today the average boy spends 4 hours with the television superheroes per day, and 3 minutes interacting with his father'' (Bretherton, D.-War Toys, would you buy one? Habitat October, 1988. This is a very sad reflection on present parenting practices.

Some of those psychologists I have just quoted, make a plea to parents not to use the TV sets as an unmonitored baby-sitter-but rather to intervene in their children's viewing habits. Some parents are conscientious in this regard-but many are not.

Liebert (1986) stated that ``research has shown that heavy doses of TV violence viewing are associated with the development of aggressive attitudes and behaviour'' . . . and further, that ``TV viewing also appears to cultivate stereotypic views of gender roles and race'' . . . and that ``commercials often capitalise on children's naivete and also can foster and reinforce overly materialistic attitudes.'' (Liebert, R.-Effects of Television on children and adolescents. Jnl of Developmental and Behavioural Paediatrics. February 1986, Vol 7 (1), 43-48

Huesmann (1986) presents a developmental theory to account for the link between increased exposure to media violence and increased aggressive behaviour. It is argued that the effect of media violence on individual differences in aggression is primarily the result of a cumulative learning process during childhood (Huesmann, L. R.-Psychological processes promoting the relation between exposure to media violence and aggressive behaviour by the viewer. Jnl of Social Issues. 1986; Vol 42 (3) 125-139. It is contended that if undampened, this process can build enduring schemes for aggressive behaviour that persist into adulthood. In a paper published in 1987, Huesmann with co-researcher Eron maintained that heavy exposure to TV violence is one of the causes of aggressive behaviour, crime and violence in society (Eron, L. and Huesmann, L.-Television as a source of maltreatment of children-Social Psychology Review 1987 Vol 16 (2)195-202).

It is impossible to do justice to the huge amount of research in psychology which has been done both in Australia and overseas showing the damaging effects of such programs but the major findings are consistent and universal.
We cannot ignore the dire message of all this data.

We can, however, make some changes in our social environment to avoid the actual encouragement of the more antisocial expression of this aggression. Further than that, we can encourage the development of more pro-social attitudes in developing children.

What action can we take to ensure that children have a more positive, wholesome menu available to them in both their all-pervasive televised media environment and in their play environment? For their own sakes as individuals, and for the sake of our society, we have to tackle this question in an energetic and practical fashion.

The Government is to be congratulated for the setting up in August of this year an inquiry to be conducted by the Tribunal into the ``portrayal, presentation and reporting of violence on television''.

The inquiry is to include general entertainment, current affairs and news programs and, very importantly, cartoons. The Tribunal is directed to have regard to the concern in the Australian community an erosion of human sensibilities and respect for life and also to have regard to the ``particular susceptibility of children''.

Although the inquiry is to look into the adequacy of existing powers under the Broadcasting Act and report on the best way to regulate violence on television, the inquiry is not due to report until 31 August 1989. Thus it may take up to two years before such ``violent cartoons'' are properly regulated.

Likewise, it may be a long time before a review currently being conducted by the Tribunal into the Children's and Pre-school Children's Television Standards results in actual changes to those Standards.

Concern about violence in the community has also seen the establishment of a National Committee on Violence, a joint Commonwealth/State initiative recommended by the 1987 summit on gun control and violence. However we must not focus merely on ``Rambo'' movies and their effect on their eighteen year old audience. We must also focus on the ``Rambos'' of the 5-14 year olds-the ``He Men'', the Galvatrons and the Robotechs.
If we are really serious about stemming the rising incidence of violence in the community we must look at what is being fed to our children on television screens.

At the community level there is very strong evidence of public concern over violent cartoons and associated aggressive toys. Two of Australia's largest retailers must be congratulated on their recent decisions regarding war toys. Myers banned the selling or buying of toy guns in August of this year and banned certain ``antisocial'' toys in 1987, Australia wide. David Jones decided in February 1988 not to restock toy guns in their Melbourne stores with toy guns being unavailable from about September 1988 as a result. ``Victim'' toys have been banned Australia wide.

Many general community groups are working to stop the trading in war toys and their insidious connection with children's Television Programs, and new groups have been established with this specific aim such as the National Coalition Against war and Violent Toys established in September 1987.

It is important that the Parliament reflects this community concern about negative and aggressive attitudes and behaviour being encouraged in our children by television programs designed specially for them.

If we are concerned about the physical, mental and spiritual well being of the nation's children, we should at least prohibit the broadcasting of violent programs for children with which toys are associated. Therefore, I commend this Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 5) 1988INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT BILL 1988SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 6 December.
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 5) 1988
Clause 9.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night when we were discussing the estimated extra revenue of $300m, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) referred us to his speech explaining the make-up of that figure. We have since examined the Hansard in detail and the explanation is quite unsatisfactory. This chamber could well be passing this gold tax legislation on a false and misleading premise based on what I might term incomplete arithmetic by this Government. This Government and this Minister boast of economic rationality. The calculation that I believe has been the basis for this figure is incomplete and does not rest on this premise about which he is undoubtedly proud.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has misled the chamber because page 4 of the explanatory memorandum would lead all reasonable people to believe that the figure of $300m stated thereon is a net figure. In fact, it appears from the Minister's explanation and from the explanation given by Senator Cook that in effect it is the primary tax payable by companies. How misleading! In effect, we could well find that the Government is losing money as a result of this particular transaction. This is a quite deliberate attempt by the Government to mislead the people of Australia about the true extent of the so-called tax savings of this amount. What is the point of having a financial impact statement to accompany a Bill if it is not honest, so deficient, and does now show the true effect? A company's profitability is not determined by its gross turnover; it is determined by its net profit after tax. Will the Minister come clean and explain the basis of the calculations. I ask the Minister to table before this chamber his calculations as to how this $300m has been determined. Will he do that?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not made any calculations myself. In all of the tax reform measures that this Government has pushed through in the last few years the authenticity or accuracy of the figures put up has been queried by the Opposition. In every case that I can remember the estimates made by the Australian Taxation Office, perhaps with some consultation with the Treasury, have proved to be conservative. I have made no calculations myself. I do not know whether there is any document per se which shows the basis of the calculations.
—You sprayed the figures around all over the place last night.

—I did not spray figures around all over the place last night. If the honourable senator wants to talk about figures, I would not mind having a list of the shareholdings that some of the Opposition members have in goldmining companies. They are in a conflict of interest situation in that they are trenchantly opposing a piece of legislation in which six senators have declared they have no interest, one senator has declared he has an interest-I give them full credit for that-and the rest have maintained their silence. I will inquire from the Treasurer (Mr Keating) whether such a document per se is in existence and whether he is prepared to make it available for tabling.

—I wish to take the Minister up on his last statement. I hope that there is a document; otherwise, what is the basis for arriving at the figure of $300m? Again I submit that we could be passing this legislation on an entirely false premise. I would have thought that the various factors I raised last night should have been taken into account and that some sort of allowance should have been made. After all, the Treasury has the expertise. It makes much more difficult calculations when framing a Budget. I ask that the basis of the calculation and the figures be tabled in the Parliament before we pass this legislation.
—I wish to follow up on that point. Last night Senator Cook attempted to give us a calculation.
—But he used gross figures.

INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT BILL 1988
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill 1988 is the legislation that contains the 20 per cent cut to company tax rates. As I indicated at the second reading stage, the Australian Democrats believe that the Government's priorities are somewhat awry if it believes that company tax should be dropped from 49c in the dollar to 39c in the dollar at a time when many companies in this country are paying less than 1c in the dollar in tax while pensioners and low income earners, of course, are paying considerably more than that.

SPEECH.PARA: We signalled at the second reading stage that we would be moving an amendment that would delay the implementation of company tax cuts until such time as the promised personal tax cuts came into effect at a similar percentage rate. I do not think that this is inappropriate. We have a position in this country where company tax is nominally 49c in the dollar; where the top 200 or so companies pay on average 28c in the dollar; where most of the major companies in this country are paying 10c or 11c in the dollar and are threatening to take their companies to other countries because they claim that this is an excessively high imposition on them; and where at least one major company-and I point out that it is a company involved in goldmining ventures here and overseas-will pay no tax at all next year and will be paying less than 1c in the dollar this year.

It is quite inappropriate that we have that sort of situation existing when company tax is nominally set at 49c in the dollar and when the Government is still persisting with a plan to cut a further 20 per cent off that payment. Company tax would drop to a nominal 39c in the dollar, and presumably those companies which are paying 28c in the dollar will be paying around 20c in the dollar-and companies which are paying less than 1c in the dollar at the moment will start getting money back from the Government! One wonders where the Government's priorities are in all of this, at a time when ordinary pay as you earn (PAYE) taxpayers whose incomes hit $19,500 per year are expected to pay 40.25c in the dollar for every dollar earned above that amount. There is something very sadly wrong when that sort of situation applies in a country which is supposed to put a high regard on social justice and economic equity. There is nothing equitable about that sort of situation. The amendment which the Democrats have circulated to page 1, clause 2, of the Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill 1988 would effectively hold up this cut in company tax until the Government had attended to the question of tax cuts for ordinary PAYE taxpayers.

Some people in government and in business have argued that it is inappropriate to give ordinary PAYE taxpayers a tax cut too soon, because they go out and spend that money. This action overheats the economy, particularly since these people spend their money, to a very large extent, on imported goods. This affects our balance of trade and all sorts of other nasty things happen. I would point out that some of the biggest purchasers of the most expensive imported items are companies. Australia has never developed the heavy machinery industry in this country that would allow those companies to purchase Australian-made goods. It is beyond my understanding why we are now talking about cutting company tax and giving companies a free rein on purchasing imports. This will no doubt have exactly the same effect on our balance of trade figures as a pensioner family going out and buying its children a sweater which is made in Taiwan.

This Government was voted into office, apparently, by low income earners, although it was heavily supported by the big business community. Whether this is a payoff to the latter or not, I do not know. Certainly, the Government has abandoned any support in return to those low income families and traditional Labor supporters who put it into office in 1983, then in 1984, and again in 1987.

If there is a problem in the economy and if tax cuts to PAYE wage and salary earners are going to be held off until the middle of next year, and may not be as high as was first anticipated, then it is quite inappropriate to be proceeding with a 20 per cent tax cut to companies when many companies in this country are paying nothing like 49c in the dollar and some of them are paying nothing at all. An amendment has been circulated in the name of the Australian Democrats and I move:
Page 1, clause 2, lines 8 to 10, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
Commencement
``2. (1) In this section:
`income tax' has the same meaning as in the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936;
`rates of income tax' are the rates of income tax specified in the Income Tax Rates Act 1986 as in force when this Act commences.

``2. (2) This Act commences on the commencement of provisions in an Act, howsoever that Act is described, which have the effect of reducing, by not less than the percentage by which the rate of tax payable by companies is reduced by this Act, the rates of income tax payable, on his or her own behalf, by an individual taxpayer who is a natural person.''.

I hope that at least a majority of honourable senators will see some sense in introducing a little equity into this taxation system. In this way, the vast bulk of families for whom the Liberal Party, in particular, is constantly expressing concern, will not be put further behind the eight-ball whilst some of the biggest money earners in this country, in the way of companies, and some of the smallest taxpayers in this country-often the same companies-will be allowed a further 20 per cent bonanza.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government decided not to accept this amendment without having heard any argument about it, which does not surprise me; that is the normal way this Government proceeds. On past performance, it is clearly the Government that is once again wrong. But who would be surprised by that? SPEECH.PARA: There has been a 147 per cent increase in sales tax collections since this Government came to power-more than double the rate of inflation. It is an extraordinary, incredible increase. We heard this Government complaining bitterly about any suggestions of a consumption tax to offset a significant reduction in income tax. We heard its attitude to that a year or so ago. What the Government has done is far more dishonourable. It has hit us with enormous consumption taxes, with no reduction offsetting that in income taxes. It promised a reduction but, frankly, I can understand how nervous the Government must be about the prospect of introducing those income tax cuts. This probably explains the reason why the Government was so keen to cut short Mr Hayden's overseas visit. If it had continued at that rate of expenditure the Government certainly could not have afforded any income tax cuts next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —It added significantly to the overseas debt.

—As Senator Messner says, it also contributed horrendously to the overseas debt. That may be part of the reason the figures have been so bad. To that extent, I can understand the Government's enthusiasm to cut short Mr Hayden's overseas visit.

SPEECH.PARA: The companies in this area were legally entitled not to apply the 20 per cent tax on their goods. If the Government wants to amend item 92 to reflect its Budget announcement, then it should apply the amendment to the date of its introduction or announcement. Having introduced legislation which purported to cover the issue and to which people had responded in a proper commercial way, it cannot then say, `We did not do it properly. This is what the Minister is effectively saying, `We inadvertently made a mistake but we don't cop the cost of our mistake; the taxpayer cops the cost of the mistake'.

Surely this is a reasonable proposition. No company could object to the tax applying to item 92 from the date of the introduction of the legislation. How on earth can this company now go back to try to collect from its customers a sales tax which it did not apply because it believed-quite properly, because it was not in the legislation-that it should not apply? If this is so, the Australian Taxation Office must have a record of it.

Senator Walsh says there is a principle involved. There certainly is, and it is not the principle of creating some sort of precedent for when the Government makes a mistake. The principle is this: there should not be retrospective laws. The Government made the mistake; it has to wear it. It can correct that mistake by amending the legislation so that an item is included from a specific date but it cannot turn around and correct its mistake by saying, `Whoops, we erred; now give us the money that you would have given us if only we had got it right in the first place'. I doubt whether any ordinary taxpayer in the country could get away with that argument, put to the Commissioner of Taxation as a result of a late tax payment. If some ordinary pay as you earn taxpayer owes the Government money and does not pay up on time and the tax people come around and say that a penalty applies, he cannot say, `Whoops, I thought I had actually done that; I guess I forgot to put it in the mail or forgot to sign the cheque, or got the amount wrong'. Those sorts of arguments do not wash, and neither should the reverse situation wash. The Government either gets its legislation right or it wears the consequences. In this case the consequence is a couple of months of smaller revenue than had been anticipated.

The so-called minor amendments to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act of 1935 introduced by the Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Peter Morris) in another place early in November will be quite costly for a number of firms involved in the production of these items. The amendments relate in particular to the classification of paper and plastic bags-pie bags, bread bags, flour bags and what have you. The Australian Taxation Office, as I said a minute ago, argued that it really intended to tax these bags from the date of the Budget, but whoever drafted the legislation made a mistake. Of course, the problem is that the mistake is being corrected not from the time that the amending legislation has come before us, or even the time that it is passed, but by the Bill being made to apply retrospectively from 23 August 1988. The simple fact of the matter is that the proposed changes were not announced until the first week in November, some 10 weeks after the date on which the legislation is now supposed to apply. In that 10-week period the companies involved will have sold millions of dollars worth of products which they are now being told are retrospectively taxable. When those goods were sold they were exempt, so the increased price that is accrued from the imposition of the sales tax that should have been in place but was not, because of the mistake made by the tax people, was not added to the customers' costs. There is no way that the companies can recoup that by getting in touch with the people who purchased the items and saying, `Look, we are sorry but the Tax Office has made a mistake and it is going to bash us around the ears retrospectively so can you please give us a bit more money?'. I presume there is no legal method by which those companies can do that, even assuming they could find every one of the people to whom they sold a package.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then they have to find everyone who has bought a meat pie.

—Yes, and increase the price of the meat pie proportionately. The whole thing is something out of Alice in Wonderland. The Government deserves what it is about to get. This piece of the legislation will not be passed. It is very unfair when companies through no fault of their own are asked to bear the costs of a tax error by the Government which they cannot then recoup themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, I am reliably told that the sales tax rate applicable to food bags is still unclear. Notwithstanding the fact that we made a little mistake a couple of months ago, we are about to have something that is blurred around the edges continue to operate in an area which ought to be precise. Maths used to be my field before I came into this game. Now all it is is numbers-and we are usually on the wrong side of those anyway. Maths ought to be a precise science, and certainly tax ought to be a precise area of government. We are now being told that notwithstanding the correction of this mistake-and I inform the Government now that it will not be a retrospective correction-there will still be some blurring around the edges.

Following this change the sales tax rate applicable to food bags, I am told by those people who ought to know, namely the producers, is still unclear. Following these amendments the producers say the bags will no longer be exempted. Fine. The Australian Taxation Office has advised them that some paper bags, for example hot chicken bags-God only knows what happened to cold chicken bags-are taxable at the 10 per cent rate while others, for example hot pie bags, are taxable at the 20 per cent rate. I suggest to people that when they buy a pie they ask that it be put in a chicken bag.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you do with chicken pies?

—Fifteen per cent; otherwise take your own bag or risk burnt fingers. This matter is becoming bizarre. People in the industry argue-I take their point-that there is no basis in law for this arbitrary distinction. Even if the amendments are passed in a prospective form only, the companies will still be uncertain of future liability. This is simply not acceptable. It is not the prerogative of public servants to make up the law as they go along. At least it should be the Parliament that is to make up the law as it goes along. At the moment public servants look for mistakes and then try to correct them retrospectively. People in the community are entitled to clarity and precision, and to know where they are going and what their liabilities are. If people break a law they are entitled to know what the punishments are; if they abide by the law at any given minute they are entitled to believe that nobody is going to jump on them from a great height and extract payment retrospectively because there was an oversight or a typographical error, or somebody had a bad night the night before and did not get things quite right the first time-or sometimes even the second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats will be supporting this amendment to the legislation because it is highly inequitable to have people in this state of confusion and uncertainty. I do not think it is unreasonable to expect public servants, who are well paid, within reason to get things right in the first place and, in an area of tax which is so problematic for most people, to be precise, accurate and clear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Item 92 has provided an exemption, and will continue to provide an exemption, for sacks used for fertilisers, chaff and other primary produce. The relevant item in the Act states:

SPEECH.PARA: Bags and sacks used for fertilizers or chaff or for marketing goods covered by any item or sub-item in this Schedule . . .

That is, bags and sacks used for wrapping exempt goods. So far as the chaff and fertilisers are concerned the exemption will continue, but the Government's legislation removes any doubt that may have arisen about the other questions-that is, wrappings or containers for covering other exempt goods. There is no record of any exemption ever having been granted under item 92 for goods in the second category-that is, goods used to wrap items that are exempt. I understand that the reason for that is that, prior to the Budget announcement, item 96 could have been used for that purpose. I do not think I can say that there has never been an application under item 92 that is relevant to the wrapping of exempt goods, but certainly there has been none for a very long time, for the fairly obvious reason that item 96 was available and was an unambiguous alternative. For that reason, as I have already said, item 92 was not included in the original Budget list.

Some smart alecs who call themselves sales tax consultants get a living from an essentially parasitic activity; that is, searching around to see whatever loopholes they can find in any tax law and then retailing them around the place. Following the Budget announcement a number of wholesalers sought advice from the Australian Taxation Office because several large retailers, at the suggestion of sales tax consultants-for that read `parasites'-had refused to pay the tax to the wholesalers, suggesting instead that the wholesaler challenge an exemption under item 92 in the first schedule. The advice given by the Office has always been that exemption is not available under this item in respect of these goods.

I should also add that it is important to note that item 92 applies only to bags and sacks used for fertilisers or chaff or for marketing exempt goods. Bags used by supermarkets and department stores could not qualify for exemption under this item because most goods marketed by them are taxable. In the case of supermarkets, about 30 per cent of goods marketed are exempt, and the figure is much less in department stores. That is the way that item 92 has always been applied by the Taxation Office and, to the best of my knowledge, quite successfully. However, once it became known that these sales tax consultants were trying to market a tax avoidance scheme, advice was sought from Parliamentary Counsel as to whether item 92 should be further clarified. Advice from Parliamentary Counsel was that that should be done.

It is not possible to quantify what the cost, if any, of Senator Messner's amendment would be because some of the relevant returns have not yet been received. For all we know a great wad of them could turn up tomorrow. Let me deal with the people who have apparently written to Senator Baume. They are not the innocent bystanders that Senator Baume has depicted them as being. Such people have not claimed, prior to August, exemptions pursuant to item 92 because there were other, more clear cut, items under which they could claim exemptions. But it appears that, following the pernicious activities of these sales tax consultants, some people thought, `Here is a bit of a try on. We will try on a claim under item 92 even though we have never used it before'. They thought that here was an opportunity to exploit a loophole in the sales tax system. The purpose of the Opposition's amendment is to allow them to get away with it. The Government certainly will not accept it. I regret that the Australian Democrats have seen fit to say that they will vote for the amendment but this matter is important enough for us to call a division. If this amendment is carried I will approach the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to ask the Taxation Office to assess the cost of the amendment, which, of course, will have to be done at some later time. It also seems to me quite possible that it will lead to some costly litigation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the extraordinary comment by the Minister at the end of his speech that, if this amendment is carried, he will ask the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to assess its cost. It would have been more useful if he had been more diligent before bringing in this legislation. To say now that he intends to assess it once again raises doubts about his initial statement--
—It can't be assessed now and I told you why.

—The Minister says that it cannot be assessed now because there may be a whole swag of claims to come in. Surely the Government had some knowledge-if it did not, it should have-of the sort of activity that has been going on. It says that it has been approached by wholesalers. I must say that I find it extraordinary that there is such a lack of knowledge in the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Basically, that was not the point I wanted to make. I must say that I am not certain about the threat the Minister has made of litigation in this matter. I do not know whether it is proper for the Minister to say-if that is what he is saying-that in some manner the wishes of the Parliament would be subverted by the Government resorting to the courts in some way. I just do not understand, and I do not think the people concerned understand, what that threat is. It might be a good idea for the Minister to say just who he is standing over, in what way is he standing over them, and what threats he is really making to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not standing over anyone; I am just warning you of the likely consequences of your silly amendment.

—The Minister says that he is warning us of the consequences of our amendment. Our amendment simply stops this legislation from being retrospective. If there are consequences as a result it appears to me that they will fall on the Government. If the Minister's comment is an attempt to get us to review our decision, what does he mean by threatening legal action? Is he talking about the `parasitic consultants' who, as I understand it, are parasites simply because they have advised taxpayers how to obey the law? If it is an incompetent law passed yet again by his Government, all I can say is that that kind of threat comes pretty poorly from the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: I say in conclusion that it is not illegal for people to organise their affairs to fit in with the tax law when such organisation is to the disadvantage of the Government. People throughout Australia organise their affairs legally in keeping with the tax law. As Senator Haines has quite properly said, there is such imprecision in the whole of the tax legislation that it involves a great deal of skill simply to meet the requirements of the tax law. For the Government to suggest that it is somehow improper for people to organise their affairs under the tax law as it exists seems to me a little strange. The suggestion by the Minister that the people involved are not innocent bystanders is typical of the sort of approach and smear that comes from this Government. I expect that sort of thing. It is one of the reasons I did not mention the name of any company in this debate. Senator Haines did not mention any companies either. I presume that she, too, knew perfectly well that if she mentioned a company's name it would be smeared in this way as this Minister has done.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the threat of victimisation.
—And there is the threat of victimisation. On all those grounds there is no way that the Opposition will reconsider its view-certainly not after the pretty crude threat from the Minister.

—That there are no financial implications mentioned in the second reading speech or now will not prevent me from voting one way or the other. It is important, as has been expressed by the Senate previously, that financial implications of measures that come before the Parliament should be detailed for the benefit of the Parliament. However, when it comes to matters of principle, or of major public policy, those are the bases upon which the decision should be made. Having listened to the debate at the committee stage I feel that the argument in favour of the amendment has been sustained and I intend to vote for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 November this year the Australian Democrats introduced two amendments to the sales tax Bills that were similar to amendments we had introduced several times in the past. The amendments sought the removal of sales tax on two products used by people with disabilities, in particular, children with disabilities-flavoured soy milk and computers and other special aids which can be adapted for use by people with disabilities, but which were not produced specifically for people with disabilities.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that we realise that there are people in the community who suffer from disabilities of one sort or another which impede their standard of living and which in some cases impede their capacity to learn and hence to earn an income and to take as full a part in life as possible unless they are provided with special assistance. I do not know how many members of this chamber have among their families children, in particular, who are unable to tolerate certain foods and for whom substitute foods need to be found.

TALK.START.PARA: —Gluten allergy, for example.

—Senator Baume interjects with one problem; there are others. An increasing number of children are unable to tolerate foods of one sort or another, quite frequently dairy products. In not being able to tolerate those foods they are deprived of certain proteins, vitamins and so on that are necessary to their full growth and development.

SPEECH.PARA: It is unfortunate that, for various reasons, modern living is making it difficult for some of these youngsters, in particular, to live easy lives. Their parents are required to go looking for other sources of those proteins, vitamins and so on. One of the products that parents look to is soy milk. The Government has applied a 10 per cent tax, not to plain soy milk, but to flavoured soy milk. I cannot imagine that this is the biggest revenue raiser for the Australian Government this year. It must be a small part of the Government's tax revenue. Yet it will have a significant effect on those families where one or more children are required to consume this product because they cannot consume other products.

All of us who have had children know how difficult it is to make them take something which is good for them but which they do not like. If putting a bit of flavouring into a product helps them take that product more easily, I find it incomprehensible why the Government should be putting an additional 10 per cent tax on that item. The Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, who is the Minister in the chamber at the moment, and I have had discussions in the past about the problems of chronic fatigue syndrome and other modern diseases that are caused by intolerance to chemicals that abound in foodstuffs and elsewhere. I would have thought that he of all people-I understand that he has had firsthand knowledge of this matter-would be interested in removing a financial impediment to alternative products, of which flavoured soy milk is one.

As I said, our amendments also related to special aids that can be adapted for use by people with disabilities to enable them to function better but which were not specifically designed for people with disabilities. Let me run past those senators who are interested in this matter an example we have raised in the past. It was drawn to our attention a couple of years ago by a Queensland family who had a child who, as a result of his mother having taken thalidomide during pregnancy, was born with his hands attached to his shoulders. The child grew up to be a bright, lively and intelligent child. The family did its best to make sure that the child and the family led as normal a life as possible. It obviously was not possible for that child to undertake standard education with his hands joined to his shoulders. The parents quite properly sought alternative ways of furthering his education. They discovered that it was possible to adapt an ordinary computer so that the young boy could use it. If the keyboard were raised he could reach it, even though his hands were joined at the shoulders, and he could still see the screen. His chances of conducting a fulfilling education as a consequence of that were massively increased. Unfortunately there happens to be a 20 per cent sales tax on computers, a sales tax that was not removed because the computer was to be used by a child with a disability following an adaption which, I might add, added to the cost of the computer.

We are not looking at something which is relatively inexpensive. We are looking at something which is quite a drain on any ordinary family even when it is not adapted and even when the family does not have additional costs accruing from bringing up a child with a significant disability such as this. The family was faced with paying that extra 20 per cent. As it turned out, the company that was retailing the computer absorbed that 20 per cent sales tax and did not charge as high a profit as it could have. As a consequence, the family were able to get that computer adapted and give it to the child to use.

What sort of society are we when we penalise people like this? We have acknowledged in other areas of the sales tax legislation that people with disabilities deserve to be given a sales tax exemption if a medical practitioner or a qualified or registered therapist of some kind recommends that an item be provided. Let me give honourable senators some examples. If someone becomes bald as a consequence of a disease, the wig that he buys is sales tax exempt. If somebody with a disability buys a car to take himself to work and that car is adapted so that even though he has a disability he can drive it, that car is sales tax exempt. Why in heaven's name are we not extending that exemption to other special aids that can be adapted for use by people with disabilities so that they can function as normally as possible? We are not saying in this amendment, `open slather'. We are saying that, if a medical practitioner or somebody else equally qualified recommends it, as happens with other sales tax exemptions in this area, the goods concerned should also have the 20 per cent sales tax waived.

Senator Walsh said when we first raised this that if people can afford the 80 per cent, which is the price of the computer, they can afford the 20 per cent, which is the cost of the sales tax. I do not know whether Senator Walsh has anybody in his family with a disability or knows any family that has amongst its members a person with a disability. It may just be that the family is strapped enough to afford the 80 per cent without the additional disincentive through the financial burden of a 20 per cent sales tax. What makes it even worse is that presumably the changes that have to be made to the computer to raise the keyboard and so on add to the cost in the first place. The sales tax will be a 20 per cent tax on the original price of the computer plus the cost of the adjustments.

Our amendment does not specifically say `computers'. It says `special aids'. But we are using computers as an example because they are a classic and widely needed item in this area. If we can exempt wigs for people who are bald, if we can exempt cars for people who want to be able to work effectively, surely we should be able to exempt other special aids that allow individuals with disabilities to function as normally as possible. This is particularly urgent in an area of children's education. I might point out that a car is not exempt from sales tax unless a disabled person is using it to go to and from work. I would say that computers are being bought for children with disabilities mostly because a computer enables them to get the best value out of their education so that when they leave school they can go to work. If we are looking at work-related areas, this is one.

The Opposition said that it would send this matter off to a committee. For pity's sake! We have been moving this sort of amendment for at least three years. How much longer does it take to think about this? I would have thought that the Opposition could have turned its mind over the last three years to this question without having to pass the buck to a committee. Mind you, when one of its members does not even know whether he is sitting among the Government or the Opposition, I am not at all surprised that some of them have a little difficulty in thinking through something like this.

All right, I cannot tell honourable senators what the cost of this will be. But Senator Michael Baume, Senator Messner and, indeed, the Minister could not tell us what the cost would be of changing the sales tax amendment that we have just changed in this place. The Australian Democrats thought it was justified, whatever the cost, that people should not pay sales tax retrospectively. If the Opposition can go into bat for a company which is hardly disabled on the question of retrospective tax over two months, I would have thought it could go into bat for a group of youngsters, and others-I am not excluding adults who want to benefit from this-who have a disability and whose whole lives can be improved as a consequence of having access to this sort of equipment. I seek leave to move together the two amendments that were circulated in my name.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not propose to accept the amendments which Senator Haines has now moved. The amendments are, I guess, the sorts of ubiquitous amendments that keep cropping up whenever this type of legislation is before the Parliament. I note that Senator Haines attached a great deal of passion to her submission for support. Indeed, there is no criticism of passion. In fact, in this place we could do with a bit more of it from time to time in relation to beliefs that people hold dear. But no amount of passion indicates that the proposal itself is justified.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to very briefly go to a number of reasons why the Government holds that view but, before I do so, I observe that the Opposition concurs-as I understand it-in general terms with the Government on this position, so Senator Haines has a fairly large job ahead of her to persuade both the major parties, the Government and the alternative government in this place, to her version of responsibility in tax matters on this issue.

I do not intend to linger long on this, but I observe that in 1984 Senator Macklin introduced a private member's Bill which goes to this general issue. An amendment of this character has been moved to each Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Bill debated here since that time. The first point is, yes, the Democrats are being consistent, but its amendments have not been accepted and that is the view of both the Government and the Opposition. The point raised by Senator Haines has been considered in Budget deliberations by various governments over many years. Each time the decision taken has been not to amend the law, because of the problems involved and the cost to revenue. In 1984, the estimated cost to revenue was $150m.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much was it then?

—The estimated cost in 1984 was $150m. I believe that is the cost attached to the Macklin private member's Bill, to answer Senator Baume's interjection. We would say, as well, that the proposed amendment is too wide-ranging; that the existing sales tax exemptions for disabled and handicapped persons apply to specific goods. To this extent they are self-policing, because there is no incentive to get the benefits of the exemption for people without disabilities, given that the goods can only be used by disabled persons. On that basis, I reject the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the Government claims too much support from the Opposition, let us be clear about what the Opposition's view is. The Opposition certainly shares the concern of the Australian Democrats about the Government, in effect, prospering at the expense of the handicapped. It was because of that concern that in the past we have taken strong and positive views about exempting some matters from taxation when we have been in government. The problem here is one which emerges, in effect, from the response of the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) where he alleged that $150m would be the cost to revenue if the general proposition outlined in 1984 by Senator Macklin--
—As I understand it, that was in relation to the Macklin 1984 Bill; not necessarily this amendment.

—Yes, that is right, but taking this situation to its logical conclusion which is, in fact, the Macklin Bill I would imagine, the first question clearly is: Is this the best way of spending $150m on people who are handicapped?
—That is patronising.

—Not at all. It is not patronising. The second question is: Are there better ways of providing a more meaningful assistance to the handicapped than the way being proposed in this legislation, which tends to benefit only those people who are rich enough to be able to afford the large items on which there will be a significant sales tax benefit? What I am suggesting is that there may well be better ways of providing assistance, particularly to those people who are handicapped but not nearly as well off and who do not even have the base.

SPEECH.PARA: All I am saying is that they are questions that have to be looked at. We can be criticised for not having looked at them earlier. That would be a reasonable basis for objection. If the Democrats were to object on that basis I would acknowledge their position. The reality is that the Government has consistently said that there are problems relating to cost and to administration. If there are problems relating to cost and administration, let the Government argue that case clearly and properly. Let it be subject to cross-examination; let it be examined. The place for it to be examined is in a Senate committee inquiry. That is why the Opposition says, `Look, there is a sound case for the Government not prospering at the cost of the handicapped,'-which is what it is doing. According to the Government it is prospering to the extent of $150m, if it were taken to the logical conclusion of the Macklin Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the cost of the loophole that would be opened up for the non-handicapped.

—Let us see what this cost really is. As Senator Walsh interjects, that cost is largely made up of people using loopholes in such legislation, where the full benefit of such special advantages may not be limited only to people with handicaps; others may take some advantages as a result of on sales, on purchases, and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us get this matter very simple and clear: Is the answer to provide, instead of the sales tax benefit, some sort of rebate? Is it better to have a higher grant? Is it better to have no sales tax? What is the best way of providing this? Should there be a subsidy for people who want to buy these kinds of things? There are many technical ways of going about it. There are many important and significant problems, according to the Government, which have to be examined. The Democrats have waited for four years and have raised this matter for four years. They have a sound point that something should be done to examine this properly. It has not been done over the four years and that is why the Opposition is very keen indeed to have a Senate inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are just palming it off again.

—It is not palming it off again. It is to have an inquiry where the very issues which the honourable senator complains about, and which have not been answered by this Government, have to be answered. It is a simple proposition. Let us combine to get the Government into a situation where it has to respond to the sound points which the Democrats have been making. What is wrong with that approach? Do I get the impression from Senator Haines that, because it has not been done immediately and the Democrats have waited for four years, the Democrats are rejecting the concept I am putting up? The Government would be forced to come clean, to explain absolutely perfectly why it objects to this kind of assistance to the handicapped and what the technical, administrative and financial impediments are that the Government has continually claimed exist without ever providing details of them.

SPEECH.PARA: That is why I believe it would be wrong to try to resolve this problem on the run, the way the Democrats' amendment does. There are clear implications, not simply in this respect, but in terms of the natural consequences, why it should clearly go to such a Senate committee. The Opposition will be examining the preparation of such a submission in the near future, because it believes that this is a matter of very real significance. I must say that, I do object to the Australian Democrats claiming that the Opposition has failed to go in to bat for the handicapped, as if the Democrats were the only people who had done so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that. This is an important issue.

Reasons of the House of Representatives for disagreeing to the amendments of the Senate
Senate amendment No. 1 is not acceptable because-
The proposed requirement that the individual be informed in writing would be burdensome for agencies and of limited benefit to some individuals.

Information Privacy Principle 2 is expressed in terms that would cover a wide range of collection practices of agencies and can be tailored to suit a variety of circumstances. The Privacy Commissioner is empowered to issue guidelines on what would be sufficient information for an individual to be made generally aware of the purpose of collection, the legal authority for the collection and the usual disclosure practices of the collector.
Senate amendment No. 2 is not acceptable because-
There are practical difficulties in imposing an obligation on agencies to check the accuracy of personal information at the time of collection.

Information Privacy Principle 3 requires a record-keeper collecting personal information to take reasonable steps to ensure that the information is relevant to the purpose of collection, up to date and complete. The record-keeper is also required to ensure that the collection of the information does not intrude to an unreasonable extent upon the personal affairs of the individual concerned.
Information Privacy Principles 7 and 8 provide important privacy safeguards for individuals by requiring record-keepers to correct inaccuracies before making any use of information in records.
Senate amendment No. 3 is not acceptable because-
Information Privacy Principle 5 requires the record-keeper to provide information to enable any person to ascertain the main purposes for which that information is used.

Agencies may have a range of purposes for which personal information is used. It would be impractical to require agencies to set out all the possible purposes for which information held by an agency is used.
Senate amendment No. 4 is not acceptable because-

The amendment is directed to enabling a person to find out the information handling practices of the record-keeper. The Information Privacy Principles already do this. Information Privacy Principle 2 requires information to be provided by record-keepers about their disclosure practices. Information Privacy Principle 5 also requires the record-keeper to maintain a public record setting out extensive information about the personal records kept and how to obtain access to those records.

The Privacy Commissioner is empowered to issue guidelines on the safe storage and security of records of personal information. It is not appropriate for individuals to be given details of security controls on information held by a record-keeper.
Senate amendment No. 5 is not acceptable because-

It is a condition for the handling of a complaint as a representative complaint that the Privacy Commissioner is satisfied that the class of persons making complaints is so numerous that joinder of all its members is impracticable. The Commissioner can waive this condition if justice demands that the matter be dealt with as a representative complaint. Accordingly, the awarding of compensation to each member of the class is likely to give rise to practical difficulties.

In the case of representative complaints, the main remedy is likely to be the cessation of the act or practice giving rise to the complaint rather than compensation. A similar approach has been taken in relation to complaints under the Sex Discrimination Act and the Racial Discrimination Act.
An individual who believes compensation is justifiable can bring an individual complaint notwithstanding that a representative complaint has been brought.
Senate amendment No. 6 is not acceptable because-

It is a condition for the handling of a complaint as a representative complaint that the Privacy Commissioner is satisfied that the class of persons making a complaint is so numerous that joinder of all its members is impracticable. The Commissioner can waive this condition if justice demands that the matter be dealt with as a representative complaint. Accordingly, the awarding of expenses for costs incurred in making the complaint to each member of the class is likely to give rise to practical difficulties.
Senate amendment No. 7 is not acceptable because-
The provision should not be deleted as the definition of complainant in relation to a representative complaint needs to include all the persons on whose behalf the complaint is made.
Senate amendment No. 9 is not acceptable because-

The Bill provides a right to complain to the Privacy Commissioner, who conducts an investigation and may award compensation. This will give the Australian people a simple and effective remedy. For most people, it will be a more accessible and cheaper remedy than an action in the courts.
This is the approach the Parliament has adopted for other interferences with the rights of individuals in the areas of sex discrimination and race discrimination.

An injunction can also be obtained from the Federal Court to restrain a breach of the Privacy Act. The remedy enables the Privacy Commissioner or an individual to get a privacy infringing practice stopped.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Privacy Bill 1988, which has been brought back to us from the House of Representatives, is the twin brother, so to speak, of the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill.
