SPEECH.PARA: After the failure of the Australia Card legislation the Government moved to introduce a tax file numbering system, which contained a number of requirements of individuals with regard to the quoting of their tax file number, that I do not intend to go into at the moment, and was given assurances by the Opposition that that legislation would be supported if privacy legislation were introduced at the same time. I do not know what requirements the Opposition placed on the privacy legislation with regard to its efficiency or effectiveness, but certainly this piece of legislation does not seem to fit the bill. We discovered that on the first occasion that this legislation was before the Senate, when we moved a number of amendments that were supported by the Opposition and when the Opposition moved amendments that we then supported. So the Government was faced with a piece of privacy legislation that had a significant number of amendments made to its operation-to the information privacy principles, to appeals mechanisms and to the capacity of an individual to take an action for damages before a civil court.

Before I go on to those, I want to raise a peripheral matter with regard to the whole concept of a tax file number and the attendant privacy legislation. We were assured by the Government, with the support of the Opposition, that the tax file number legislation would not be intrusive and would not particularly endanger people's privacy but that, just to make absolutely sure of that fact, it would do two things: introduce privacy legislation that covered, I might add, only the public sector and not the private sector and also write into the tax file number legislation a provision that gave people the option of whether or not to quote their tax file number to their employer, the bank, the building society, the stockbroker and so on. So what that amendment did was to make it optional. It removed a section in the original legislation that would have created an offence if somebody had not quoted his tax file number. That was fine as far as it went; but what also applied was a penalty. You do not commit an offence by not quoting your tax file number, but you do accrue a tax of 50.25c in the dollar. We made the point during the debate on this that this was a pay-off by the Opposition to some of their wealthy supporters in the community who can afford to wear that sort of penalty. People on average weekly earnings and less do not have that option. So they are required to quote their tax file numbers.

What has been drawn to my attention since the passage of that legislation is that there is at least one major employing agency in New South Wales which, a couple of weeks ago, sent all its employees home to get hold of their tax file numbers before it agreed to pay them. So much for the legislation and the fact that it is not compulsory to quote one's tax file number. People out there have not got any idea at all how this is working. If employers do not, or for some reason of their own choose to ignore it, what employee is going to know the ins and outs of an intricate piece of legislation like the tax file legislation? What use is the Privacy Bill, even if it worked and was effective, when those sorts of things happen? I can give the Minister the name of the employer group if he is at all interested in pursuing this matter.

Honourable senators came into this place a couple of weeks ago, decided that there were enough holes in the privacy legislation to drive a fleet of trucks through and, between us and the Opposition, moved a series of amendments. For example, these required that the information collected about somebody had to be accurate. That does not seem a particularly unreasonable expectation about information that is stored on people in areas of tax, social security, health or anywhere else. It is a simple requirement that the information be not only up to date and complete but also accurate. The Opposition supported us in that. The Democrats also thought it might not be unreasonable if people were told the purposes for which the information that was being collected on them was to be used; not just the main purpose at the time, but the other purposes for which the information was to be used. The Opposition agreed with that. The Democrats thought that it was not unreasonable that people should know what happened to the information, how it was stored, how it was collated, how it was altered, how it was used, to whom it was going to be released and why. The Opposition agreed with that.

The Opposition raised a few matters of its own. It said that the right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal was a necessary adjunct to all the other clauses in the Privacy Bill if it were to be meaningful and effective. That seemed not unreasonable, although it would cost people an arm and a leg.

—Can the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs explain to the Senate why the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs released Mr Kurtovic, a man convicted of manslaughter, from custody? Did this occur whilst Mr Kurtovic was being detained by Immigration pending deportation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been informed by my Department that my predecessor, Mr Young, signed a deportation order against Mr Kurtovic on 28 January this year. Mr Kurtovic was convicted in July 1983 of the manslaughter by shooting of his parents-in-law. The Crown accepted a plea of manslaughter, rather than murder, on psychiatric evidence of diminished responsibility from a depressive psychosis. This was said to have been precipitated by domestic disputes with his wife and parents-in-law. His young daughter witnessed the shooting. There is no doubt that this was a very serious offence. A sentence of 10 years with a non-parole period to expire on 15 December 1985 was imposed.

ANSWER.PARA: A previous deportation order had been signed in 1984. This was revoked on the recommendation of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. However, Mr Young considered this year that there were new facts regarding Mr Kurtovic's mental state which indicated that Mr Kurtovic could constitute a risk to the Australian community, particularly Mr Kurtovic's former in-laws. They have persistently expressed fears of Mr Kurtovic, particularly regarding his former wife, who has custody of their child, and a desire that he be deported.

Australia's criminal deportation policy is based on an assessment of four broad criteria: the seriousness of the offence; the risk of recidivism; the person's ties with and contribution to Australia; and hardship suffered by both the person and Australian citizens if deportation takes place. These were the primary considerations to which Mr Young had regard.

Mr Kurtovic was held in immigration custody pending deportation from February this year immediately following his release from prison. Since then he has been pursuing various avenues of appeal, though I am informed that he sought release from custody only after some months. Mr Kurtovic sought review of the decisions to keep him in immigration custody, but the hearing of this application has not yet been completed. The usual course when administrative decisions are challenged in the Federal Court is to remit the decision for reconsideration, though the court does have power to quash such decisions. However, Mr Justice Einfeld made an interim order that Mr Kurtovic be released subject to certain conditions. In releasing Mr Kurtovic as an interim measure, Mr Justice Einfeld considered that there was a serious question as to whether the Migration Act allowed an authorised officer to take into account the seriousness of a deportee's offences and the risk of further offences in deciding whether to take or hold such a person in custody pending deportation.

I am informed that Mr Justice Einfeld, having decided that there was a serious question to be tried, considered that it was not appropriate that his consideration of that issue should be rushed. On the evidence before him and with the conditions he imposed, he felt the risk of Mr Kurtovic absconding and of committing further offences was acceptable and he should be released immediately pending his decision in the case or until further order. The view that any risk should be borne or that the risk is acceptable in this case is not shared by my Department or by me, and Mr Kurtovic's release has been strenuously opposed. I intend, and so does my Department, to lodge an appeal on this particular matter against Mr Justice Einfeld's decision.

I think it is the view of most commentators that this move has been an outstanding success. Not only has the rate of detection of illegal fishing boats increased but also there is now a new vigour in the system due to the enforcement--

TALK.START.PARA: —If you had given more resources to the AFP, you might have got some result.

—His Leader is like Senator Hill. Senator Hill anticipates; his Leader leads his regiment from behind and does not even get the facts right. There is a new vigour in the system due to the enforcement approach adopted by Customs, unlike the passive methods which have existed in the past. It is rather absurd at this stage to contemplate further changes to Coastwatch, at a time when it is now being successfully managed, because of some vague ideological disposition. It is necessary to remind the Opposition that the bulk of coastal surveillance is for civil purposes such as immigration, quarantine, anti-smuggling and so on. These are not tasks which should be allocated expensive and specialised military equipment, which is designed for quite different roles. Even so, defence equipment does back up civil tasks. Naval patrol boats are an obvious example and this is why the Government has allocated certain levels of naval and Air Force resources to support Coastwatch operations when appropriate and when sensible in terms of the resources which have to be made available.

ANSWER.PARA: I further make the point that the Customs Service is one of the few government agencies with resources spread throughout remote parts of northern Australia. It is located in areas where not even the defence forces are based. It is the ideal body to have responsibility for Coastwatch. All the indications are that the Government's decision to place Coastwatch with Customs has been the correct one.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training aware of the failure of the Skillshare program to fund a project in the Inglewood-Wedderburn district of country Victoria, solely on the grounds that no funds are available? Is the Minister also aware that a community youth support scheme (CYSS) project had operated successfully in the area for 10 years; that there is no Commonwealth Employment Service office in the area; and that there are more than 500 people in the Skillshare target group of disadvantaged unemployed? Can the Minister say how the unemployed, sole supporting parents and special beneficiaries are expected to improve their situation when many are hundreds of kilometres from the job training and support that this Government acknowledges they need? Is all this the result of funding cuts which have occurred with the introduction of Skillshare? Does this mean that rural people are once again to miss out in spite of their special needs?

—I was asked about the alleged failure of Skillshare. It was asserted that no funds were available and that the CYSS scheme was operating in some country towns in Victoria. I do not know the answer to any of those questions. I will try to get them from Mr Dawkins. I will see whether Mr Dawkins has any comment to make about the rhetorical bit at the end of the question.

—Has the Minister for Resources seen the article in the Bundaberg News Mail in which Brian Courtice, the Federal member for Hinkler, calls for the resignation of the Queensland Water Resources Minister? Mr Courtice has asked for Mr Neal's resignation because, according to Mr Courtice, Mr Neal misled parliament when he denied there had been a delay in the setting up of a consultancy report to investigate the Bundaberg irrigation scheme and its funding situation. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the situation regarding the Bundaberg irrigation scheme and the State and Commonwealth commitment to this scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —That question does call for a little background, which I will briefly give. In the context of the 1980 Federal election the coalition-I am not sure whether it was through Nixon or Anthony-gave a commitment to the Queensland Government that it would contribute to a joint Commonwealth-State funding arrangement to support the Bundaberg irrigation scheme. Of course, Bundaberg was the centre of what was arguably a sensitive seat. That commitment, naturally, has been honoured by this Government. The last $4m instalment to Queensland was brought forward by me and paid earlier than required in recognition of the harsh wet season experienced in Bundaberg and the difficulties being experienced by farmers in that area. As a consequence of that, too, the Queensland Government, through Don Neal, the State Minister for Water Resources and Maritime Services, approached this Government earlier this year to write a new agreement to continue funding further. The original agreement reached back in 1980 was that the Commonwealth pay $4m a year and the State $6m a year, and that arrangement was to last for eight years in order to fund the scheme.

ANSWER.PARA: The complaint of the Queensland Government now is that the original agreement did not take account of inflation. But it is clear that the Queensland Government, with its eyes open, signed the agreement to accept the proposal of the Commonwealth, as put forward in 1980. One must accept that the Queensland Government understood all the way through the conditions of this agreement. Now it has asked for more Commonwealth money. The Queensland Government has proposed that the Commonwealth contribute $6m to its $9m for years one and two and that the total payout for the scheme in year three be $7m, based on the same proportions. So far so good. What is the context of Mr Courtice's remarks? When the Commonwealth got this request from the Queensland Government we said that we wanted to specify two things. Firstly, we wanted a cost-benefit review of the scheme in order to be sure that if we were to consider further funding, the Commonwealth dollar would, in terms of water resources, be spent properly. Secondly, we wanted an indication from the Queensland Government of when the scheme might be completed, because it is now running on for many more years than was originally anticipated. On the basis of our specifying those things, the joint Commonwealth-State working party was formed. A consultant's report was commissioned by that working party to deal with those points, and it is the timing and delivery of that report over which this issue arises. I saw Don Neal in September. He indicated then that the report was some weeks away from being delivered to me. I am advised by my Department today that the joint Commonwealth-State working party may clear for presentation to Mr Neal and me the document from the consultants some time this week, and thus I would expect to have it before me close to but certainly before Christmas.

Mr Courtice has pointed out that Minister Neal in the Queensland Parliament indicated that the report had in fact been sent to the Commonwealth, and, as I have said, we have not yet received it. That is the point of the dispute. The strength of the Government's argument certainly lies with Mr Courtice, who is an outstanding local member in the Bundaberg area. He invited me to Bundaberg to meet the Isis farmers. I accepted his invitation, and they expressed their concerns about the delay. In terms of the bureaucratic chain that has been put in place for the clearance of all these things, the delay of two months is perhaps not a long delay; but for the farmers in the Bundaberg area experiencing difficulties because of the recent lack of rains, two months could be, if they are uncertain about their future, a quite serious and important delay. When I receive the final report I propose to expedite the Commonwealth's dealing with it, and if we do see in that report a case for further funding to complete works now in progress that will be dealt with appropriately in the Budget context.

Public controversy has been generated in Queensland over Commonwealth funding for works involving dam construction in that State. Queensland has nominated to the Commonwealth the Burdekin dam and surrounding work as a key priority, as well as the Bundaberg project. I make the observation, however, that the Queensland Government has chosen to divert its own State funds to other projects. The Barker-Barambah dam, which is colloquially known as the Bjelke-Petersen memorial dam, has been fully funded by the Queensland Government, and also the Kroombit dam and the Peter Faust dam are in prospect. One would have thought that if the priority assigned to the Burdekin and Bundaberg projects were to be held to by the Queensland Government, it would have diverted more funding to those projects rather than give the projects I have just referred to a direct priority over and above the Commonwealth-State priority.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Has the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the Hon. Gerry Hand, recently appointed Mr Chris McGuigan as one of the three members of an important committee appointed to review the Aboriginal arts and crafts industry? Is this person the same Mr McGuigan who some years ago was formally reprimanded by the then Chairman of the Aboriginal Arts Board of the Australia Council for attempting to offer for private sale Aboriginal works of art and artefacts which had been placed in his custody and which in fact belonged to the Australia Council? Was this the second time that Mr McGuigan had been formally reprimanded or cautioned for serious dereliction of his duties and improper conduct as an employee of the Commonwealth? Can the Minister now say why a person with such a history in this area has been appointed by the Minister to such an important position?

—I have no particular brief in relation to the appointment of Mr Chris McGuigan, of the Australia Council, to the review team on the Aboriginal arts and crafts industry in terms of the particular question that was put by Senator Puplick. Obviously, I will need to approach the Minister and get further information for the Senate.

—Can the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer inform the Senate how much export revenue the Elders grain division earns for Australia which contributes to Australia's balance of payments? Does this mean that Elders is making a greater contribution to Australia's exports than the newspaper advertisements featuring the figure of $5.7 billion suggest?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —According to figures published in the Australian Business magazine in 30 November, the Elders grain division earned just over $160m in export revenue in 1987 and is expected to earn $170m this year. Of course, that is the gross value-probably the f.o.b. value-of sales; it is not the value added by Elders. That puts the Elders grain division in a quite credible forty-sixth place in the table of Australia's top 500 exporters. The advertisements featuring the figure of $5.7 billion relates to the export revenues earned by the Elders wool division. I have already mentioned in the Senate that the $5.7 billion figure is a very serious misrepresentation. The value of wool exported by Elders in the relevant year was $380m, not the $5.7 billion as the advertisements imply. Those advertisements also refer to Elders-IXL Ltd, the whole of the company group, as being 110 per cent Australian.

ANSWER.PARA: In yesterday's Australian Financial Review there appeared an article from which I will quote four sections. I make it clear in the beginning that they are not continuous, but the article states:
Elders IXL Ltd's grain division is to shift its Melbourne headquarters to Kansas City in the US . . .
The move follows the effective relocation of Elders giant brewing division in London . . .
Elders recently launched an extensive campaign to promote Elders Agribusiness as `110 per cent Australia'.
That article continues:
. . . there are already rumours that Elders' meat division may be the next to relocate in the US.

When one looks at three of those four quotations together it seems as though Mr Elliott actually believes John Howard's boast that he will be Prime Minister, and wants to get his company out of Australia before the economy collapses, as it did the last time Mr Howard had some responsibility for running it. Of course, it also shows that Mr Elliott tends to change his rhetoric and the facts to suit the preferences of a particular target audience at the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Does the Government intend on 12 December, or any other date for that matter, to take action under section 81b or 81c of the Public Service Act to transfer staff of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC), with or without their consent, to the direct control of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs (DAA) or vice versa? Would not such an action be in direct contempt of the Senate, which presently has under consideration the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill as well as many issues relating to the maladministration of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, not to speak of several cases where the Minister appears to be telling the Parliament one thing and doing another? Will the Minister assure the Senate that no action under section 81b or 81c of the Public Service Act will be taken without full and proper consultation with staff and staff associations? In fact, can the Minister advise what consultations with unions have already taken place? Will the Minister for Justice make it clear to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and the Prime Minister, who has to sign the execution order, that any action to force the placement of ADC staff under the control of the DAA, or vice versa, will be viewed most seriously by the Senate as a pre-emption of the work of the Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs and the Senate itself?

—I am unaware of any proposal whatsoever to do with the transfer of personnel, as Senator Tambling has put it, either from the Aboriginal Development Commission into the Department or from the Department into the Aboriginal Development Commission. It is not clear from his question which of those he is suggesting is about to occur on 12 December. It is a rather remarkable question based, as I say, on an assertion which could go in either direction as to the flow of staff from one organisation to another. Nevertheless, I will make such inquiries as I can to find out whether any such movement of staff is proposed between the Aboriginal Development Commission and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. I am sure that, in relation to any staff and personnel matters, the fullest consideration would be given to the need to advise staff in a timely way of any administrative rearrangements that might involve them. I am confident that proper consultations will take place, if required, as to any such movement of personnel, in accordance with the ordinary decencies of proper industrial relations.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister advise what consultations have already taken place on this matter, either in Canberra or in the various regional offices?

—Quite clearly, there is an assumption that a decision has been taken and that some sorts of preliminary steps have been adverted to or notified which could lead to the supposed transfer on 12 December. As I have said, until I can answer the Senate--
—I hope the Minister will not plead on this occasion that because he has not signed anything no decision has been taken.

—I will not respond to that interjection. I do not know what the interjection was; it is very hard to hear across the chamber. I will undertake to do what I have said I will do and I am sure that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs would undertake proper consultations in relation to any transfers that might be envisaged.

—Can the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs inform the Senate of the outcome of applications to remain in Australia made by the three Somali Navy cadets who arrived in Australia on an Italian training ship in September this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I granted refugee status to these Somalis on 21 October 1988. At the time the Australian Government took the view that, as they arrived on an Italian naval vessel in Italian uniform and had been resident in Italy for some years, the Italian Government bore the major responsibility for their ultimate resettlement. Negotiations with the Italian Government were initiated on this basis. The Italian Government's lack of a substantial response and its prevarication were fairly disappointing, particularly in view of the history of cooperation over the years between our two countries. I am most concerned at the Italian Government's very uncooperative attitude on the fate of the Somalis. It would not even categorically rule out their involuntary return to Somalia, thus calling into question Italy's reputation as a humanitarian nation. In the circumstances, I have decided to approve in principle the grant of permanent resident status to the Somalis, thereby demonstrating that Australia is willing to live up to its obligations under the United Nations convention and protocol relating to the status of refugees.

ANSWER.PARA: I regret that, in view of the Italian Government's rather unhelpful attitude, I have decided to consider a reduction in the very generous assistance Australia has traditionally provided in resettling refugees seeking asylum in Italy. Instead, my Department may-I stress the word `may'-make some of these places available to other parts of the world. For many years Australia has been regarded as a country that will always cooperate on refugee matters, but when we seek the cooperation of other countries it is rarely forthcoming. I think sooner or later we have to stand up and ask other countries to fulfil their obligations as well as we do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to the legal advice given by Mr Michael Adams, QC, which the Minister tabled yesterday on whether it was legal for the Aboriginal Development Commission to have provided almost half a million dollars to Tranby College to enable it to promote the proposal for an Aboriginal treaty. I ask: Why was the opinion given as a favour? Does that mean that it was done without charge? If so, on what basis? Can the Minister assure the Senate that normal procedures for procuring legal opinions were observed in this matter and that all normal legal advices were sought and received? Finally, is Mr Adams doing any other work for the Aboriginal Development Commission or its commissioners?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the opinion obtained from Mr Michael Adams, QC, in relation to the funding of Tranby College by the Aboriginal Development Commission was prepared and received on 25 November 1988 and there was a supplementary opinion dated 2 December 1988. It is my understanding that that advice was provided without the charge of a fee. The honourable senator asked whether all other normal legal advices were obtained. Honourable senators will recall that the Senate was informed that Mr Bailey, the principal legal officer of the Aboriginal Development Commission, had formed an opinion in relation to the legality of the funding of Tranby College by the Aboriginal Development Commission and--
—A contrary view.

—It was a contrary view. In a letter dated 1 December 1988 Mr Bailey maintained that distinction, or contrariness, if you like, from Mr Adams's opinion. So, on the papers available to me, the Aboriginal Development Commission had available to it the advice of its own principal legal officer and the legal opinion, supplemented by a further opinion in response to Mr Bailey's misgivings about the first opinion, from Mr Adams.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator asked me whether Mr Adams was undertaking, or had done in the past, the provision of other legal advice to the Aboriginal Development Commission or to individual commissioners. I am not quite sure of the purport of that. Perhaps he was asking whether Mr Adams was providing legal advice in some capacity other than as a legal adviser to the commissioners of the Aboriginal Development Commission. I will seek a further answer to that question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. My question relates to that part of my question which asked whether all normal legal advices were sought and received. In view of the differing views provided by Mr Adams, QC, and by the Aboriginal Development Commission's own principal legal officer, and in view of the now three differing views that have been provided to the Senate as to whether the transaction was legal, has the Commission taken steps to obtain further legal advice to resolve the conflict that so obviously exists between the two advices it has now received?

—To my knowledge it has not. The Aboriginal Development Commission obviously has an obligation to try to ensure that it acts at all times within the statute which established it and which provides for its functions and the exercise of its powers. It has done that in the light of advice received from its own legal officer which was in a sense overruled by the opinion received from Mr Michael Adams. The principal legal officer himself then commented on the first opinion, and a further opinion was received from Mr Adams. So the Aboriginal Development Commission has, in accordance with its obligation to act within its statute, sought and received opinion which I believe has enabled it to have the assurance that it quite properly requires that its grants to Tranby College are within the bounds of the statute.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I refer to a statement to the Senate on 12 October 1988 by Senator Richardson in which it was claimed that the Minister for Defence had not known of, authorised or ordered any espionage of the Jervis Bay Protection Committee. I draw the Minister's attention to a report of a meeting of the Jervis Bay Protection Committee which was held on 4 September 1987. The report is held in the files of his Department and I have given the Minister a copy of it. Can the Minister confirm that Beryl France, the wife of a Royal Australian Navy officer, produced the report of the 4 September meeting? If not, who did produce the report? Is it a fact that the surveillance of the Jervis Bay Protection Committee was mainly done by Navy wives, and has been organised by Hill and Knowlton Pty Ltd on behalf of Sinclair Knight and Partners Pty Ltd who are producing the Jervis Bay environmental impact study for the Minister's Department? If not, how is the surveillance being organised? Given that parliament was told on 12 October that the Minister did not know of these espionage activities, will the Minister explain why the Parliament was misled?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there is a correlation between falling off your sailboard and brain degeneration, but I am not sure what it is. I am asked a number of questions which do not really fit together very well. It is almost as though Senator Sanders is the walking epitome of the Truth newspaper in the Senate because there are a lot of convoluted jumps in logic in his question. The honourable senator asks whether I can confirm that Beryl France wrote the minutes of the 4 September meeting of the Jervis Bay Protection Committee. I have a fairly wide reading pattern but that has not come within my purview yet. I also do not know who wrote the minutes of the Bentleigh mothers club or anything else along those lines. I apologise deeply to the Senate for my lack of knowledge. Therefore, if I do not know whether Beryl France wrote the report, I cannot confirm who wrote the report. But Senator Sanders can, by using his subscriber trunk dialling facility, ring that particular organisation and ask who produced the minutes of the 4 September meeting. He must have its phone number because he has given me a copy of the minutes which go to such matters as the amount of money made on its theatre night, a cake stall to be organised the following Sunday, and a few other activities. It is dated 4 September, but there is nothing on the document to indicate who wrote it.
—It is a report filed with them by a Navy wife who is spying on this organisation. Get around that one.

—If Senator Sanders knows the answers to the questions he asks I do not know why he asks me to assist him. However, that deals with part 1 and part 2 of the question. The third part asks whether it is a fact that surveillance of the Jervis Bay Protection Committee is done by Navy wives, and if not who does it. I do not have any knowledge of any surveillance by the Navy at Jervis Bay. I have no knowledge as to whether it is true or not. The answer given by Senator Richardson was based on the same information. He stated quite categorically that he did not know of an organised attempt. I think in Senator Sanders's last question he implied that it was the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation or some other organisation.

ANSWER.PARA: Frankly, I think this is pretty mickey mouse stuff and we should move on to more substantive issues than whether a particular Navy wife has taken the minutes and given them to someone else. What does it matter? What is the point of the honourable senator's question? I really do not understand it. To allege that Senator Richardson misled the Senate in answer to a previous question is as equally ridiculous as this one and does not have any foundation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister consider it a mickey mouse affair when the Department of Defence or its officials, or members of the Navy undertake espionage activities on a citizens group? Is that a mickey mouse affair?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —What we have is an assertion by Senator Sanders that there may have been, in his own mind, a surveillance activity undertaken on behalf of the Navy. He had no evidence of that.
—What is this if it is not evidence?

—It is quite possible for the Navy to have the minutes of a meeting that do not arrive via espionage and to use them for its own benefit. I will refer the case of the cake stall espionage to the Minister for Defence and I will get Senator Sanders a response within the next two years.

—Has the Minister for resources noted the Opposition's commitment in its Future Directions document, described by Laurie Oakes in this week's Bulletin as primarily a pastiche of platitudes, propaganda and prejudice, to complete deregulation of the liquefied petroleum gas market in Australia, including the removal of the role of the Prices Surveillance Authority in setting maximum wholesale prices for LPG? How does this fit with the Government's recent changes to LPG pricing announced by the Minister? What would be the consequences for consumers of complete deregulation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have noticed this document called Future Directions-or `Lost Directions'. I observed in his feature column of this week's Bulletin that Laurie Oakes, a quite distinguished critic of politics--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition senators say that he is not distinguished. That might be their view, but my view is that he is a distinguished commentator. He described the document as `a volume of platitudes, propaganda and prejudice', not as a policy document. Let me go to the questions of substance on LPG that Senator Beahan has asked.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government earlier this year released a discussion paper on LPG pricing. We received over 40 submissions from State governments, from the industry, from local governments, and from consumers. It is not surprising that the balance was that most of the LPG producers favour complete deregulation but that the distributors, local government, consumers, and so on, support a continuance of the regulated market. On 11 October I announced that with effect from 1 February next year we would move towards a free market in LPG while providing-and this is an important proviso-protection for the consumers. I said that we would ask the Prices Surveillance Authority to determine maximum wholesale prices of LPG in each capital city, that we would retain export controls as a reserve power to ensure that there was not a flight of LPG overseas thus forcing up domestic prices, and that we would see that the domestic market was properly supplied. I think that was a sensible balance between the need to deregulate and the need to protect consumers.

The Opposition has proposed in its document to jump into the void and move to a completely deregulated market. To do so would be not to recognise the unique characteristics of LPG. There is limited competition in this field. There are big transport and storage costs as well, which cause the market to be different from the crude oil market, which we deregulated at the beginning of this year. The Opposition does not offer any safeguards, except the platitude that it would take the interests of country consumers into account.

I was rather surprised to find that, in this section of the document, the Liberal Party-or Mr Howard, or whoever claims ownership of the document-has moved so far down the ideological path it has. When we released our discussion paper about the prospects of a free market, as a Minister I received, from a person who I understand is now my Opposition shadow spokesman in the House of Representatives, a Mr Peter McGauran, a plaintive lobby not to deregulate the LPG market. He said, `Do not deregulate it. Keep it as it is, as a regulated market'. He is the shadow energy spokesman for the coalition. I now find the coalition document calling for the reverse of what he was proposing.

Mr McGauran's was not the only voice calling for the retention of a regulated market. A number of other Opposition spokesmen called for regulation to continue in the way we had administered it until now. Those Opposition spokesmen were: Charles Blunt, Noel Hicks, John Sharp, Tim Fischer, Wal Fife and, in this chamber, Senator David Brownhill. They all made lobbies or requests to me as the Minister to retain the regulated market. We have gone to partial deregulation, with the price being fixed by the Prices Surveillance Authority. On what basis has the coalition now issued a policy going against the interests of people who are predominantly representatives of country electorates-electorates which would be most adversely affected if the move to a deregulated market, as contemplated by the coalition policy documents, were to be carried out?

Let me conclude by citing some figures as to the likely impact of moving to a deregulated market as proselytised in the coalition's document. The ex-refinery wholesale prices of LPG would increase significantly with complete deregulation. The estimates of price increases are as follow: $20 to $30 per tonne in the Melbourne metropolitan area, a price increase of 1c to 1.5c per litre; in the Sydney metropolitan area, $70 to $80 per tonne, a price increase of 3.5c to 4c per litre; and in the Brisbane metropolitan area, $100 to $110 per tonne, a price increase of 5c to 5.5c per litre. If we are talking about country consumers we are talking about further loading the metropolitan price increases with transport costs and so on.

What the coalition's document-that document of platitude, propaganda and prejudice-proposes is a significantly higher price for LPG, particularly for country consumers but also for metropolitan consumers. This is in direct contrast to what many Opposition members, in private correspondence to me, have requested.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL ABORIGINAL AND ISLANDER HEALTH ORGANISATION

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to the extraordinary series of events involving the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs which were revealed to the Senate as a result of questioning by senators on this side of the chamber late last week and again on Monday and yesterday. I refer the Minister, in particular, to the clear and uncontestable fact that Mr Hand misled the Senate in a statement made on his behalf by Senator Bolkus on Monday about when the audit report on the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation (NAIHO) was first brought to his attention. I ask: Does the Government adhere to the principle that Ministers who mislead Parliament, whether intentionally or, as is alleged in the case of the Hon. John Brown, unintentionally, should resign and that if no resignation is forthcoming the Prime Minister should dismiss the Minister, as even Prime Minister Whitlam did on more than one occasion? Will the Prime Minister dismiss Mr Hand for misleading the Senate and the House of Representatives and for his disastrous administration of the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio, to the detriment of Aboriginal Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to Senator Chaney's question is no. Mr Hand and Ministers representing him in the Senate have made it clear that Mr Hand, as Minister, had a well-known disposition to fund a body such as a reconstructed NAIHO, with proper representative and accountability processes, because there is a gap in the range of Aboriginal advisory bodies in the health area. He has had discussions with NAIHO representatives regarding that. He has not given written or formal approval for funding and no funding has gone to NAIHO. There has been no decision on the matter.
—It is like getting caught in the bank without blowing the safe.

—Senator Boswell should not start on the question of getting caught in the bank. He should wait and see what happens to him after they have finished up there in Queensland, before he interjects like that. There has been no decision on the matter. Documents tabled in the Senate and the statement made on Mr Hand's behalf yesterday made that clear.

ANSWER.PARA: The general principles relating to ministerial responsibility have been enunciated in the Senate on numerous occasions and I do not intend to repeat them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note that the Minister in his reply did not even advert to the clear misleading of the Senate when Senator Bolkus introduced Mr Hand's statement into the Senate earlier this week. I specifically asked the Minister about the statement made about when the audit report on the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation was first brought to the attention of Minister Hand. I remind the Leader of the Government that on the basis of information produced by his Minister in this place yesterday, following the introduction of the same document by Senator Short, Mr Hand was advised of the existence of this document in July 1987, and on the basis of other documents introduced into the Senate by both Senator Tate and Senator Bolkus it is quite clear that Minister Hand was again advised of the existence of that document before the end of August this year. Therefore, I again ask the Minister: Does the Government adhere to the principle that Ministers who mislead the Parliament, intentionally or otherwise, should resign, and that if no resignation is forthcoming the Minister should be dismissed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact that Senator Chaney chooses to characterise a particular course of action as a clear misleading of the Senate does not mean that a clear misleading of the Senate has taken place. As we know from numerous hours of debate yesterday, a question of interpretation is involved as to what the expression `brought to the attention of the Minister' means and meant in that context. If Senator Chaney chooses to characterise the response as a misleading of the Senate, that does not necessarily mean that such an event took place. The Government's position on that issue was made quite clear yesterday. I am aware that Mr Hand was given documents in July 1987 and again on 30 August, I think, or 31 August 1988 which referred to that document. But in terms of what the Minister and his representatives in this place have said, I concede that there is a difference of interpretation as to what the expression `brought to the attention of the Minister' means, and that is as far as it goes. The Opposition has established nothing further than that.

ANSWER.PARA: In the light of that, I decline again to repeat what has been said in this chamber on numerous occasions about ministerial responsibility. It does not need further elaboration at Question Time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Chaney moving forthwith-That the Senate censures the Prime Minister for:

(a) his failure to uphold proper standards of ministerial propriety and responsibility in relation to the misleading of Parliament by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in contrast with the standards adhered to by the Hon. John Brown who resigned because he misled parliament.
(b) his failure to uphold even the principles concerning the misleading of Parliament applied by the Whitlam government and
(c) his failure to ensure the orderly and proper administration of the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs to the continuing detriment of Aboriginal Australians.

While Senator Tate sorts out his position with the Australian Democrats, I might ask the Government whether it wishes to debate the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders or whether it wishes to agree to the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Give us a minute.
—Since the Government is not prepared to follow the normal course and to allow the suspension to deal--
—That is a lie. I said, `Give us a minute'.

—The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has asked for a minute and I am happy to discuss the motion for suspension. I do not think that anything could be more apparent as to the need for this motion than the non-answer we have just had from the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). The Leader of the Government totally failed to address himself to the principle that a Minister could not be allowed to mislead the Parliament. He refused to make any comment on that issue. He chose instead to deny the facts which have been so amply demonstrated in this place over recent days. I am happy to address the issue as to why the Standing Orders should be suspended and why we should deal with this issue now rather than later. The matter could be dealt with by going back a great distance--
—I only asked Senator Tate to check with the Democrats whether they would support the suspension. I do not think he got an answer. We will agree to the suspension.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate censures the Prime Minister for:

(a) his failure to uphold proper standards of ministerial propriety and responsibility in relation to the misleading of Parliament by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in contrast with the standards adhered to by the Hon. John Brown who resigned because he misled parliament
(b) his failure to uphold even the principles concerning the misleading of Parliament applied by the Whitlam government and
(c) his failure to ensure the orderly and proper administration of the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs to the continuing detriment of Aboriginal Australians.

We bring this motion forward because there are two matters of immediate and major concern. One is the proper functioning of this Parliament, the proper functioning of parliamentary democracy in this country, which depends upon accurate information being given to the Parliament by Ministers and those other people who provide the information to us. That is a fundamental requirement if we are to have an effective Westminster system of government in Australia. We can clearly demonstrate that those standards have not been met by the Government and that that is to the detriment of this institution, the Senate, and the Parliament generally.

It is an extraordinary thing that one can point to an area where the Hawke Government has shown even lower standards than those which were displayed by the Whitlam Government. At least in the time of that Government we saw examples of Ministers having misled the House of Representatives or having caused the House of Representatives to be misled and the immediate requirement by the then Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, that they resign.

The other major concern which we have and which I wish to touch on briefly at this stage of the debate is that, whilst there are important institutional reasons for being concerned at any case of the Parliament being misled, there are also very serious long term and long held concerns about the maladministration of Aboriginal affairs under the Hawke Government not just in 1988 under Minister Hand but for the whole of the period of the Hawke Labor Government. I intend to address that matter in the limited way that is possible in a debate of this type, but I want to make the point that the substance of the concerns that we have goes to the blighting of the lives of a generation of Aboriginal Australians. Whilst it is true that there are many Aboriginal Australians who are taking advantage of the opportunities which this country offers to build better lives for themselves, it is also true that in settlements around Australia, in the cities and suburbs of Australia, this Government's failures in the administration of the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs are resulting in intense damage being done to a generation of Aboriginal people.

When I spoke to some senior members of Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory just a few months ago about what is happening to the next generation of Aboriginal people they agreed with me that the very promising group who were coming through into the community 20 years ago are not being replaced under the confusion of administration that is currently occurring. We see the situation where a whole generation will be blighted unless this Government takes a grip on this key policy area, stops engaging in tokenism and symbolism and stops the sort of self-indulgence that we have seen from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and from the Ministers who have held this portfolio, and unless we see a genuine commitment to improving the lives of Aboriginal Australians.

Let me turn to the failure to uphold proper standards of ministerial propriety and responsibility. We heard in the answer which was given by Senator Button the sort of obfuscation we have had from the Government ever since this matter was raised originally in the House of Representatives by Roger Shipton but consistently in this Senate over recent days. Senator Button likes to state that in some mysterious way it is a matter of opinion as to whether the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, has misled the Parliament.

I do not intend to spend time on the detailed discussion and argument that we had in this chamber only yesterday on the original complaint which we had about Mr Hand and his statement that he had not approved the funding of the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation (NAIHO). That is a matter on which there has been some confusion because of conflict within minutes that have been produced. The fact is that there is some room for the sort of argument that Senator Button has put forward here this afternoon. But there is absolutely no room for the sort of argument that has been made by Senator Button when one looks at the material which has been made available by the Government in recent days.

Let me quote precisely what was said by Minister Hand in a statement settled by him, tabled in this Senate and read into the record of this Senate by Senator Bolkus in the absence of Senator Tate. I quote from the prepared statement of Mr Hand. Referring to the auditor's report on NAIHO, he said:
This report was compiled before I was Minister and this was the first time it was drawn to my attention.

That is a very simple statement. What the Minister is saying is that it was not until 8 September that the auditor's report which was sought by the previous Minister and which was a prelude to the refusal to further fund NAIHO was drawn to his attention. The Government itself, however, has introduced into this Parliament documents which show that when the Minister was originally briefed by his Department in July of 1987 he was provided with a brief on the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation and that that brief clearly set out the reasons why a Minister would be concerned about his dealings with NAIHO.

The brief refers to the receipt of more than $1m of public money. It refers to the fact that NAIHO has not lived up to the expectations of either Aboriginal people or the Government. It refers to the fact that despite repeated requests NAIHO has failed to account adequately for its funds or to provide considered and timely advice. Most significantly for the purpose of this debate, it also said:

. . . the Minister instructed that the accounts and administrative practices be audited in depth. The independent and professional auditor, Arthur Andersen and Co., found that NAIHO's system of internal control of operations and finance was inadequate . . .
How the Leader of the Government can suggest that a Minister who agrees that he received that briefing note in 1987 and who then received the more detailed briefing note in August 1988--

TALK.START.PARA: —Less detailed.

—This is the difficulty in this debate. The Ministers who have defended this Minister in this chamber have not bothered to master the material which is before the Parliament. The Leader of the Government just interjected that the brief received in August was less detailed than the original brief.
—It is shorter.

—It is not shorter. The Minister interjects that it was a shorter brief. Again I simply remind the Senate that this is like Senator Tate's lack of preparedness on this matter and Senator Bolkus's lack of preparedness on this matter: they simply are not familiar with the documents which have been tabled in this place. It is typical of the slackness of their approach to the administration of Aboriginal affairs. I direct the attention of the Minister to the two attachments to the memorandum of August. The first attachment refers on the second page to the independent audit. The second attachment refers to the Arthur Andersen audit and the nature of the concerns which are expressed in that audit.

SPEECH.PARA: They are the simple facts of this matter and it is absurd for the Government to suggest that the Minister did not mislead the House or the Senate, because the Minister, in his public statements, has indicated that he accepts that he did mislead the Senate. Let me quote the Minister. Let me not bandy words with the honourable senator for the Australian Capital Territory, who has so pathetically tried to defend the indefensible over the last 24 hours. Mr Hand has said:
What I was saying that the first time `it' had been brought to my attention, meaning the document . . . itself-
so he is referring to the fact that he meant something else other than what was said in that statement-
I would hardly have tabled a series of documents within 10 minutes referring to the Arthur Andersen report if I was intending to mislead Parliament.
I apologise to people if my interpretation of what the word `it' means is different from those in the Senate. Quite clearly, the 8th was the first time the document was given to me.
Mr Hand admitted that, on two or three occasions before then, aspects of the report had been brought to his attention. When asked again if his statement was misleading he said:
. . . it wasn't designed to be misleading.

How can the Government assert that the statement is not misleading when it requires that sort of explanation from the Minister? He is saying that he meant something quite different from the clear meaning of the words which were put into this place in a statement approved by him, namely, that 8 September was the first time that the document was drawn to his attention-not that he saw the document; not that he held it in his hands; but that it was drawn to his attention. I think that if Mr Hand is denying the allegation he should sue the newspapers which have headlined this morning that Hand misled both Houses of the Parliament.

That is a matter which no person of goodwill, or even of ill will, could misconstrue. Mr Hand has misled the Senate on at least one occasion, if not more. We find Mr Hand taking refuge in the defence that he meant something else; that his misleading was innocent. In that context, I think it is instructive to turn to what was said by John Brown just a year ago when he also was found to have misled the Parliament. In that case, the misleading involved Mr Brown advising the House of Representatives that there had been a 2 : 2 vote in a committee which was set up to monitor the awarding of a contract for Expo. It subsequently transpired that the vote was 4 : 2. The Minister in that case explained the difference on the basis that he had not understood that two public servants were allowed a vote. Let me quote what only a year ago John Brown was saying about the situation in which he found himself, and contrast the position with that of Mr Gerry Hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister was not dependent upon Mr Brown's vote.

—Perhaps it has something to do with the fact that Mr Brown is from the Right faction of the Party and Mr Hand is from the Left faction, but there is an absolutely extraordinary difference in the responses of the two. Let me quote what Mr Brown said:

SPEECH.PARA: After examining the documents on file relating to the composition and decisions of the Expo tender assessment panel, it has become apparent to me that I misled the Parliament on December 10 when I stated that there had been a tied vote on the relevant decision on March 21 this year.

My statement to the Parliament was made in complete good faith, in the honest but mistaken belief that the two public-servant members of the panel were not entitled to vote, but were simply present to ensure that proper tender procedures were followed . . .
I had always genuinely believed this to be the case, and I had no intention whatever to deceive the Parliament when I said as much again last week.
I have been shown to be wrong on the facts, but my conscience is, and will remain, completely clear.

TALK.START.PARA: —But Brownie didn't jump; he was pushed.
—Mr Brown at least had the sense to say this publicly, and I quote him again:

SPEECH.PARA: Because of my respect for the institution of Parliament, I feel that I have no alternative in all the circumstances but to resign as a Minister.

Senator Michael Baume interjects and says that Mr Brown was pushed. That is probably a reasonable assumption on the facts that we know. But the public statement by the Minister is a complete acceptance that his involuntary, innocent, moral misleading of the House of Representatives-all words used by the Minister-required him to leave the Ministry. Let us contrast that with the behaviour of Minister Hand, who simply adopts the Alice in Wonderland approach of saying, `Well, the words don't mean what I meant them to mean, but here is what the words I said actually were meant to mean'. That is the Hand defence and it is totally wrong and totally unsatisfactory.

TALK.START.PARA: —But Hawke can't push him.

—Senator Michael Baume again interjects that the Prime Minister cannot sack him. I do not know of the arrangements within the Government that would prevent that. It was suggested to me by Senator Michael Baume that perhaps it was a case of the Right not being able to control what the Left Hand was doing. That may well be the case, but all we can do is say that the clear obligation on the Government is to impose the standards which have been laid down in the Parliament time and time again, including by previous Labor governments and even within the life of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not some unimportant matter. I want to address that point, because some people have raised with me, as a genuine query: does it matter whether the Parliament is misled on a matter in a way where the man might be innocent in what he has done? I wish to say that it is a very serious matter for the Parliament, that we insist on the most careful standards in this area. I address these comments particularly to those Australian Democrats and members of the Nuclear Disarmament Party who chose to vote against the motion we brought into the Parliament yesterday and who obviously paid much less regard to this principle than did the three members of the Australian Democrats who voted with the Opposition. I would agree with the comment in an editorial of the London Observer, of 16 September, which was in these terms:

We may sometimes scoff at the way in which the British Parliament regards lying to its members as the most serious sin imaginable, but the convention serves a purpose. It is the only way for Parliament to keep a check on the Executive.

The truth of the matter is that unless we can rely upon the truth of what is told us in this place we cannot function as a parliament. I would like to acknowledge the explanation of that given by Senator Macklin in the debate yesterday. In the Senate Hansard of yesterday at page 3584, Senator Macklin said:

Misleading the Senate is extremely serious, and so it should be, because we have to rely on what we are told by Ministers. That is the only way in which this place can operate. It is a serious matter.
A little later, when he was quoting what the Minister was saying, he said:

`This is the very first time that this has been drawn to my attention'. It is obvious that it was drawn to his attention, or should have been drawn to his attention, in July 1987. If this document is correct it was drawn to his attention in July 1987.

Senator Macklin accurately describes the simple, grammatical meaning of what the Minister said in this place and Senator Macklin has accurately set out the reasons why misleading the Parliament is extremely serious. The fact is that we cannot operate unless we can rely upon the honesty and the truth of what is put before us.

I turn now to the standards which were imposed by the Whitlam Government. In the cases of both Cairns and Connor, Whitlam insisted that the standards be adhered to. In each case there are parallels with the situation in which Minister Hand finds himself. In the case of Dr Cairns, Dr Cairns at all times stressed that he had behaved in good faith. He may have been inept, but he behaved in good faith. At most, it would appear that he signed a letter without being conscious of its contents; something which I suppose one can say any busy Minister could do. The fact is that that led to the misleading of the House of Representatives and it led to Dr Cairns's dismissal, notwithstanding the fact that he totally protested his innocence. Mr Whitlam said this:
I do not regard these documents-
they are the documents in which Cairns set forth his innocence-

as satisfactory explanations of these two issues which I put to you and which with your consent I stated to the Press. Since you write that you do not intend to resign from any position you hold, I must advise the Governor-General to terminate your commission.

I say to those Australian Democrats who were unable to accept the argument of Senator Macklin yesterday that, just as Dr Cairns claimed-and it was not disputed by his Prime Minister-that he had innocently misled the House, so Mr Hand has misled this chamber and the same standards should apply. If one turned to the case of Minister Connor, one would find exactly the same situation applied. Mr Whitlam found that he had been led to mislead the House, because of the misinformation provided by Connor to him. In those circumstances, Connor had to go.

I think if one looks at the principles which are discussed extensively in a book entitled The Politics of Australian Democracy, written by Professor Emy of Monash University, one finds a very simple and clear statement that there is a convention that it is just not possible to tolerate a misleading of the House by a Minister. I do not think time will permit me to talk about that in any extensive way. But I do commend a study of that book to the Australian Democrats who, by their vote yesterday, showed an insufficient appreciation of that fundamental institutional fact. That book reports:
Whitlam thereby confirmed that the sanction of resignation was brought because of the minister's indiscretion in misleading parliament, not because of improper, illegal or corrupt conduct.
It is not necessary to suggest that there has been improper, illegal or corrupt conduct; it is only necessary that the Parliament should have been misled.
I turn to the third leg of this censure motion, which relates to the failure of the Prime Minister:
to ensure the orderly and proper administration of the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs to the continuing detriment of Aboriginal Australians.

It would be unfair to the Prime Minister to say that he has in no way interfered with the administration of Aboriginal Affairs. I think that most senators would recall the Prime Minister's foray in the Northern Territory last year. The Prime Minister chose to go to the Northern Territory and to make an unexpected, unresearched and damaging statement that he would enter into a treaty during the bicentennial year. It was an amazing thing that such a major announcement could be made in the way the Prime Minister did it. It was done in a way which was calculated to harm the Aboriginal people of Australia. The issue of a treaty has been around for a decade. It has been subject to considerable discussion. Nothing could be clearer than that it is an utterly divisive issue within the Australian community. Nothing could be clearer than that it would lead to the most solid objection and complaint from a substantial majority of the Australian community.

What Mr Hawke did, in a flamboyant, self-indulgent and destructive way, was to reopen a discussion without prior thought, a discussion which inevitably will lead nowhere. It is part of a pattern of failure which again requires longer than the period of this debate to document. It starts with the utter irresponsibility of Senator Susan Ryan, who, on behalf of the then Opposition, made those famous promises of national land rights which have never been delivered on. It was part of a purchasing of Aboriginal votes which was very successful. That promise was kept alive in a half-hearted way for 4 1/2 years, again to the continuing detriment of the Aboriginal people because of its divisiveness and because of the guarantee that in the end it would never be put into operation. I remind honourable senators that during the whole of that period it was within the legislative power of the Government to do that because it had the full-hearted support of the Australian Democrats. Senator Michael Macklin made that clear time and again.

The pattern is to make promises, to raise expectations, to give rise to Aboriginals making unreasonable demands, and to causing, by that process, an outbreak of white resentment, which is described as the white backlash, and which is central to the sorry position of Aboriginal Australians during 1988. That is the pattern of administration in Aboriginal affairs-unfulfilled promises, unrealistic promises, a carelessness about basic administration, a raising of expectations, a raising of Aboriginal demands, and a steady deterioration of the attitudes of Australians generally to Aboriginal advancement programs. It is a disgraceful situation and I believe it is the greatest blot on the Hawke Labor Government. It is an example of unparalleled political cynicism and utter carelessness.

I have drawn the attention of senior Ministers in this Government to my concerns about maladministration of Aboriginal affairs almost from the first year of this Government being in office. I have found them uninterested in the mess which is developing under their administration. The Prime Minister has chosen to enter this debate only on occasions of theatre. He has let the Aboriginal people of Australia down.

In this debate I do not need to document the failures of administration. Honourable senators should go to the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, which is years old now. It documents the failures. They should look at the audit report that was just tabled where it shows that $1.2m was delivered for totally unsatisfactory performance by the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation. And what confusion! I have been talking within the last two days to an honourable senator with a deep interest in Aboriginal affairs. He said to me, `But NAIHO has delivered very good services'. NAIHO has delivered nothing. The very good services have been delivered by many of the Aboriginal medical services funded under the previous Government and funded under this Government. NAIHO is not a service delivery organisation. It is a coordinating body. It is a body that was supposed to improve communications, a body which we find under the auditor's report did not bother to communicate.

We have had nothing but failure and symbolism from this Government. In the long term, whilst the institutional interests of the Parliament in getting the truth are fundamentally important to the future of this country, I believe that nothing is more important than getting the administration of Aboriginal affairs on an orderly basis, on a basis which will give the next generation of Aboriginal people some hope. It is not possible to travel around Australia, it is not possible to visit the Aboriginal communities which are isolated, it is not possible to visit Aboriginal communities which are part of the towns and cities of this country, without getting continuous reports of disquiet about the administration of Aboriginal affairs under Labor.

The Canberra Times, the newspaper which is no doubt closest to the bureaucracy in Australia, carried an editorial with the headline `Why Hand must step down now'. That leading article talked about serious issues of ministerial accountability. It stated:
The real issue ought to be what the episode reveals about Mr Hand's administration of Aboriginal Affairs.

The truth is that if anything is in the right place in Aboriginal Affairs today it is the Minister's heart. Everybody tells me his heart is in the right place, and I accept that. But that is the only thing that is in the right place. The Department has been estranged from the Minister. The Department has been ignored by the Minister. The Department has been put down by the Minister. Those members of the Aboriginal community who are not part of the favoured few, those who are favoured by the land councils, have been put down by the Minister. The Minister has spent a lot of time on the track and he has not listened to the Aboriginal people of Australia. I have never known such frequency of complaint from the people who are supposed to be being advantaged by the hundreds of millions of dollars of expenditure which is put forward by this Government.

This is an area of total failure. It is an area of huge promise and huge failure. That is why we censure the Prime Minister. We censure the Prime Minister because he is ultimately responsible for his Government. He tolerated the nonsense under Minister Holding of 4 1/2 years of promises of national land rights. There is no serious observer of Aboriginal affairs in Australia who believes that that was a legal, constitutional, administrative or political possibility. It was a lie. This Prime Minister presided over the delivery of a lie to that community for 4 1/2 years under the previous Minister. Under this Minister he has promoted a last bit of symbolism which is going to cause more misery.

My final charge against the Prime Minister is that he has involved himself only when it has been of symbolic value to him. I think that is shameful. I contrast that with the attitude of the last Prime Minister who, right or wrong, tried to look to the interests of Aboriginal Australians on a consistent basis, indeed often to the detriment of his support among his own supporters in the community. He had a serious and consistent interest in the interests of Aboriginal Australians. Senator Peter Baume would know of this. I know of this as a former Minister. Viner knows of it. The contrast between Fraser and Hawke in this area is a really shameful one for Prime Minister Hawke.

Prime Minister Hawke has failed to live up to his responsibilities to ensure that his Ministers meet proper ministerial standards for this Parliament. He has at the same time failed the most vulnerable section of the Australian community. I have to say that I despise the record of the Labor Government in this area. I hope that this motion will be carried, and that we will see the end of this Minister and a more serious approach to the interests of disadvantaged Australians, and disadvantaged Aboriginal Australians in particular.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been a number of achievements under this Government in respect of Aboriginal matters. Under a coalition Government, priority would be given to health, housing, education and employment.
