SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney raised three issues: one, close to his heart, the administration of the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio; another, an attack on the Prime Minister; and the third, the question of standards generally. The Prime Minister has not stood aside from the issue. He attaches a great deal of importance to ministerial integrity and regards seriously allegations of misleading Parliament made against any Minister. As I said in Question Time, it is no good going through the issues relating to John Brown or other people, as Senator Chaney has sought to do. Mr Brown made a statement in Parliament which was totally incorrect in fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —So is this one.

—No, not at all. As I said at Question Time, and as has been said by other Government spokesmen in the last two days-and as Senator Chaney has picked up properly-certainly Mr Hand's statement might be regarded as highly ambiguous.
—`Loose' is the term.

—Loose, if one likes. But it is a totally different issue from the issue which involved Mr Brown, which he himself acknowledged was a complete misstatement of fact. That is not the issue here. In spite of that, the Prime Minister has been very concerned about these issues, has spoken at length with Mr Hand and reviewed the relevant documents. On the question of whether a decision was made by Mr Hand on funding for the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation, the Prime Minister, after an examination of the facts, was satisfied that Mr Hand did not mislead Parliament in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Many points could be made and have been made, not the least of which is that it is perfectly clear that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs knew that it should not move on this issue until authorised to do so by the Minister. As to the audit report, the Prime Minister, like all of us, on reflection believes there could have been greater precision in what was said in the Parliament, but the meaning and the intention of the words were clear enough. Semantic imprecision is not sufficient ground for calling for a resignation. As Senator Durack put it in 1979 when he was a Minister, `The Minister must have been shown to have had a guilty mind'. That is not something that could be said of Mr Hand. In spite of the Opposition's best efforts--

TALK.START.PARA: —That relates to departmental maladministration and has nothing to do with misleading the Parliament.

—No. In spite of the Opposition's best efforts over a long period, that cannot be said in this case. Senator Chaney has given us a lecture from the textbooks and elsewhere on the doctrine of ministerial responsibility, the so-called Westminster system.

SPEECH.PARA: There is one thing that this Government is sure about: every time the Opposition raises a clamour, or the media promotes an issue as a result of an Opposition clamour, that does not involve a Minister resigning. The principle to which the Government adheres faithfully is not that Ministers resign over every perceived error or failure of administration, but that they answer for their actions publicly and particularly in the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —None of that is relevant to this debate, and you know it.

—If the debate were about relevance, it would have been encompassed in a very short space of time. The Opposition has managed to make it run on for a week, in pursuit of Senator Tambling's objective of getting this Minister for one reason or another. That is the objective. If the debate were to be relevant in every respect, and with a competent opposition, it would be encompassed in half an hour.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, a Minister is responsible to the Parliament and has to account to Parliament. Ministers have to account for those for whom they are responsible; they have to indicate actions they are taking to remedy deficiencies; they face detailed questions and possible censure motions. In the case of Mr Hand, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, do they ever! I cannot count them. I do not know how many questions, how many censure motions, how many matters of public importance there have been.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that mean he is accident prone?
—No. Sadly, they have all been about essentially the same issue in the last 10 days!
—He is accident prone; you are correct.
—Maladministration-that's what they are about.

—Those honourable senators ought not to interject about maladministration. Senator Boswell comes here from the National Party in Queensland to tell us about maladministration, with a brown paper bag tucked in his pocket-with his lunch in it, I hope. Senator Stone, a member of the National Party, was promoted down here by Joh Bjelke-Petersen and his first reaction was to repudiate the man who put him here. Senator Stone and Senator Boswell are experts on government administration, experts on a government which administered as a result of cash donations made to Ministers. Yet they interject here about this sort of issue.
—You are failing your colleague.

—That is a more intelligent interjection, if I might say so. As I said, the Prime Minister has addressed himself to these issues and the Government has maintained a consistent standard of ministerial propriety. In addressing himself to the issues, the Prime Minister has said publicly that, on reflection, there could have been greater precision in what was said in the Parliament. But the question arises as to whether that is a reason for resignation. No amount of clamouring by the Opposition on the basis of what has been substantiated will lead to the resignation of Mr Hand, or to a request for his resignation, if one returns to the essential point of what was said in the statement of 8 September and its relationship with what happened in July last year and on 31 October.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, Senator Chaney raised three issues. There was a general attack on the question of Aboriginal administration, which other colleagues of mine will deal with in greater detail but to which I have referred. The first leg, as Senator Chaney puts it, of his censure motion relates to the failure of the Prime Minister to uphold proper standards of ministerial propriety. That paragraph refers to the misleading, so-called, which has been debated in this Parliament for about three or four days. Interestingly enough, a contrast is drawn with the standards adhered to by John Brown, who resigned because he misled parliament. As I pointed out, the circumstances then were considerably different from the circumstances with which the Government and the Prime Minister are confronted now.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only difference is that Mr Hand did so more deliberately in a prepared statement to the Parliament put in this place by his representative here.
—That shows how much Senator Stone knows. Mr Brown's statement was also a prepared statement, so Senator Stone should not start drawing that dichotomy on the basis of ignorance.

SPEECH.PARA: The second leg of the argument relates to the failure to uphold even the principles concerning the misleading of parliament applied by the Whitlam Government. We could have one of those debates that go on all afternoon about what Whitlam did and what Fraser did in relation to ministerial responsibility. On each side of the House we can draw comfort from things said by prime ministers of the day, and in certain circumstances we can draw discomfort. I see no merit in continuing that part of the debate because it is just an historical exercise which wastes time and involves beating the air and moral posturing. I do not see much point in continuing that exercise in the Senate after this issue has been exposed for so long.

I come back to the point which is central to the argument: the question of what Mr Hand meant by his statement relating to the first sighting of this document. That has been dealt with in hours of debate. I do not propose to pursue that issue further, except to say that within that statement there is a clear ambiguity. It is open to different interpretations. The Opposition takes one interpretation; the Government takes another. Trying to answer that question in the adversarial forum which the Senate constitutes on a matter of this kind is like dealing with angels on the head of a pin. The Government rejects this censure motion, and in the course of subsequent speeches the reason for that will be further elaborated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate today is a motion of censure against the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in three parts:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) his failure to uphold proper standards of ministerial propriety and responsibility in relation to the misleading of parliament by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs . . .
(b) his failure to uphold even the principles concerning the misleading of parliament applied by the Whitlam government
(c) and his failure to ensure the orderly and proper administration of the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs to the continuing detriment of Aboriginal Australians.

I was telephoned early this morning by a person from a radio station who wanted a comment from me with regard to the vote of the Senate yesterday on a motion with regard to the misleading of the House of Representatives or the Senate-it could have been both in terms of the way that the motion was drafted-by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), a motion that I supported yesterday. My response to that person was that the vote of the Senate had been lost and that there could not be seen in any way, shape of form to be any obligation on the Prime Minister with regard to that lost vote. I had supported it, but it had been lost. I had been on the losing side and, as happens so many times, unfortunately, in this place, if one does not win one must move on to the next issue. It seems though that the Opposition has no intention of moving on to the next issue.

The Senate has decided the first part. I do not see there being a situation in which the votes that honourable senators cast yesterday are likely to change unless new information is brought before the Parliament in this or some other subsequent debate. There has not been any today, but there may be some in future. On that basis I do not think one could support the first part of the censure motion, because the Senate obviously has far more important things to do with its time than reiterate an exercise without any new information.

I looked at the Notice Paper and saw that it has 67 Bills on it, some of which I consider-I do not know whether other honourable senators do-to be of vital and overwhelming importance to this country not only in 1988 but in years to come. One in particular which the Opposition is interested in burying is the Higher Education Funding Bill. It is a Bill which I consider to be of vital importance, and I consider its defeat to be of vital importance to the educational future of all Australians. On looking through the Notice Paper I notice the Foreign Takeovers Amendment Bill, the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill-that concerns our trading position which is also vital to the economic health of this country-and the National Crimes Authority Amendment Bill, which relates to the controlling of crime in South Australia. The list goes on. They are items which I consider to be of vital importance and to which I hope the Senate will be able to devote a fair amount of its time.

In so far as the first part of the censure motion is a reiteration of yesterday's motion, it could not be supported. With regard to part (b), that is simply irrelevant, not only to the debate today but probably to the debate of yesterday and certainly to any debate in the future. Part (c) is a totally different matter. The censure here relates to the failure of the Prime Minister `to ensure the orderly and proper administration of the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs to the continuing detriment of Aboriginal Australians'. I would like to confine my remarks to that particular section since I think sections (a) and (b) are not relevant and should not consume any more time of the Senate.

The last part is a very important issue. It is an issue that has concerned the Australian Democrats for a long time, not only since 1983 when the Hawke Labor Government came to power but before that. My views on that matter, as the spokesperson for my Party, and Senator Coulter's views as the current spokesperson for our Party, are very well known to people in the Senate. I do not intend to reiterate all of those views in this debate. We have, in the past, under Liberal-National Party governments and under this Government, been appalled at the treatment of Aboriginal people in this country. We are appalled that people want to continue to press a paternalistic attitude. We are appalled that people will not recognise the rights of Aboriginal people to land and to self-determination.

We are appalled that we have had so many votes in this chamber opposing the legitimate aspirations of the Aboriginal people. For example, when that extraordinary symbol to the people, Uluru, was being debated in this chamber-a Bill was introduced by the Labor Government to return the rightful ownership of Uluru to the Aboriginal people-it was opposed by the Opposition parties. Even when we get down to insignificant things, such as the small parcel of land in Wreck Bay in Jervis Bay Territory, we still have an extraordinary debate in this place. When there was an attempt in this chamber, prompted by the combined churches of Australia, to carry a motion-it would have been the first such motion in this chamber, an historic event, and hopefully, a motion that everybody could have agreed to-to support the legitimate aspirations of the Aboriginal people, even when the motion was watered down in such a way that the Opposition parties would be enticed to give it unanimous support, so that I could hardly end up supporting it, they still opposed it. I think the Opposition's attitude with regard to Aboriginal affairs and, if it ever gets into government, its attempt to implement its policy, will be to the lasting detriment of the Aboriginal people.

However, we do not find the current Government's exercise very much better. Certainly, in terms of orderly and proper administration, as is set out in this motion there has not been any. So many opportunities have been lost in the last five years of Labor Party administration with regard to Aboriginal people. When the Labor Party came into government it had quite an extensive policy. It was based, correctly in our view, on the fundamental view of the Aboriginal people that all else stems from their attitude to the land and that their ownership of the land is fundamental to their future. It is not a simplistic view that they take; it is a very complex view. But it is one which people have been tempted to put aside by attitudes which tend to be massively paternalistic: for example, that we ought to concentrate on health, on education or on some other matter. We know what that means in fact. It means denying the legitimate rights of Aboriginal people in this country to their land. It is from their land that will stem their health, their education, their culture and their future. That is a view that my Party has taken since it was founded. It is a view that we intend to continue to push.

It is not a view which is shared by the Opposition or the Australian Labor Party but it is a view which we believe ultimately will occur in this country. If it does not occur, the white problem of Aboriginals will continue. It is not an Aboriginal problem; it is a white problem. It is a white problem not to be able to come to grips with the legitimate aspirations of the original inhabitants of this country.

Unfortunately, we do not have the opportunity to censure the Opposition, which we would dearly love to do in terms of its recently enunciated policy. We are confined to deciding whether we wish to censure the Prime Minister with regard to the administration of the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. In terms of what I have just said, fairly obviously we do. We would also like to encompass a censure of the Opposition, but we know that neither the Opposition nor the Government would support such a motion. It certainly pains us that the vast amount of time that has been spent on this matter regarding the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has been drawn away from the time that should be spent on real issues-time that has not been devoted to legitimate aspirations.

Before I sit down I want to say that some of what the Labor Party Government has done in the Aboriginal area has been wholeheartedly supported and has been long overdue. These things were never undertaken by the Fraser Administration in the seven long years that Senator Chaney referred to as a compassionate period for the Aboriginal people. They did not occur during the Fraser Government; they occurred during the Hawke Labor Government administration. As a matter of history, those things will be able to be pointed out. However, probably the only exercise in which we really got onto the statute book a major piece of legislative work with regard to land rights occurred during the Fraser Administration, although admittedly it was at the initiative of the Whitlam Government; in fact, the legislation had been introduced by the Whitlam Government before it was destroyed on 11 November 1975. The exercise that the Fraser Government continued with, to its credit, was to undertake and put in place a piece of land rights legislation that was the envy of many other countries around the world that have had to confront the same types of situations. I know from many discussions I have had with lawyers working on native rights in Canada, for example, that they drew an enormous amount of inspiration from that piece of legislation introduced by the Fraser Administration.

There have been some good things done over time. I suppose that is because in all of the governments there have been people who have been working away at what they believe to be the correct policies, despite the fact that the overall policy of those governments has been horrific. There have been people in the Liberal Party, the National Party and the Labor Party who in their heart of hearts know what has to be done and have attempted to work towards that. Unfortunately, any judgment made in this area would have to be that the pace of progress has been infinitesimal, has been slow, and has had so many setbacks that the Aboriginal people have a right to be dispirited. The Aboriginal people have a history of 200 years of suffering-a history which, in terms of the numbers, has been the most massive holocaust of any people anywhere in the world. It has been a period when they have suffered in ways in which no other native community has ever had to suffer. It has been a period of slavery, never acknowledged--
Senator Stone interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Stone in his normal way is tittering and laughing. If Senator Stone ever bothered to read any history, instead of passing the types of remarks that he makes in this place and elsewhere, and if he bothered visiting his own electorate, he would find plenty of people who had had their parents shot before their faces. I have seen and talked to those people. Senator Stone would not know, and Senator Stone would not care. He operates in an ignorant world, in his own little cocoon, in which he has no compassion for those people. There have been many people-I have met them, as have many other senators around here-who have had their parents shot before their faces. Senator Stone is the type of person who could go into Buchenwald and laugh at the attitude and the things that happened to the Jews.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I understand very well that people are very passionate about this subject, but I do suggest that that last remark, and probably some remarks before that, are beyond what is permitted in this Parliament. Mr Deputy President, I think you should ask the senator to withdraw that last remark.
—Mr Deputy President, I have no intention of withdrawing that remark because it happens to be true.
—Order! The question of truth or falsity is not before the Chair. The question is whether it was proper to be made in the Senate. It was not, and Senator Macklin should withdraw it.
—Mr Deputy President, I am unable to withdraw that remark.
—Order! I name Senator Macklin. In accordance with standing order 440, I call upon Senator Macklin to make any explanation or apology he may think fit.
—Mr Deputy President, I am unable to withdraw that remark.
—Order! I call on the Leader of the Government in the Senate to move the appropriate motion in accordance with the standing order.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with standing order 440, I call upon Senator Macklin to make any explanation or apology. Mr Deputy President, that is what you have just done and he has not done that. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Senator Macklin be suspended from the sitting of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue that we are addressing today is a censure motion by Senator Chaney of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It reflects on the standards of ministerial propriety and responsibility; it reflects on the failure of the Prime Minister to uphold the principles concerning the misleading of Parliament; and it centres on the failure to ensure an orderly and proper administration of a particular portfolio. What are really at stake here today, very desperately, are the real needs of Aboriginal people. It is a tragedy that the 80,000 people who live in the traditional Aboriginal communities of Australia, because of the policies of this Government, have problems in the area of literacy and education; in fact, it is quite openly proven that in those areas things are regressing.

SPEECH.PARA: The health care of Aboriginal people is in a shambles and, in trying to secure decent and proper employment, things are stalled. The participation and involvement of Aboriginal people from traditional communities in the leadership of their communities has been nobbled. In the urban communities of Australia there are some 150,000 Aboriginal people who, by the action of this Government, have been caught up in power games and political struggles. We have seen emerging in recent years, under the influence more particularly of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) in recent events, cliques of radicals who are seeking to exercise the management authority in so many areas.

In replying to Senator Chaney, Senator Button attempted to draw a difference between the Fraser Government and the Hawke Government. He implied that some of us did not have the credentials that could stack up. I would be happy to stack my credentials any day against those of Minister Hand or Senator Button, because I believe that my colleague Senator Collins from the Northern Territory and I are the only two people in this place who can claim to be related through marriage to Aborigines. A large number of my personal friends in the Northern Territory are Aborigines, just as I hope Senator Collins's are. Some 35,000 people, or 25 per cent, of the electorate that Senator Collins and I share are Aborigines. Those people certainly talk to Senator Collins and me; they are not here talking frequently to Senator Button or to Mr Hand. Senator Button referred to the semantic indecision of the Minister, Mr Hand. That should read `the semantic imprecision'. Senator Button referred to an article in yesterday's Melbourne Herald in which I am quoted as saying-I do not walk away from it:
If we don't get him-
that is, Mr Hand-
on the issue of misleading Parliament, we'll get him on others.

In the last six weeks there have been many other matters before this place on which the Minister ought to have resigned. They just keep falling out; they keep dropping; they keep coming. It is because of his rotten, lousy administration. If it does not happen today, it will certainly happen tomorrow or next week or when we come back in February because there are so many occasions when these things happen.
Let me refer to today's media and the important feature writers and editorials and the way this event has been picked up in the last couple of days. In the Australian today Paul Kelly says:

The Hand statement to Parliament-that the audit report had only been drawn to his attention of late-should be seen for what it is: a pathetic excuse to ease the heat on himself, a clear act of disloyalty to his department, and a statement that was plain wrong.
Today's Canberra Times, under an editorial headed `Why Hand must step down now', commences:
The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Gerry Hand, has been in serious trouble with his portfolio for many weeks, and his political future looks bleak.
Further, the editorial states:
The Hand ministerial style has been strangely reminiscent of the style of Gordon Bryant, and may face the same consequences.

How true. But the censure motion we are today addressing relates to the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the fact that he has looked on and done nothing about the scandals and the ineptitude. What about the political process of which he is meant to be the leader? The leader of the Australian nation should ensure that this Parliament operates properly and effectively. When should a Minister resign? Let me quote from the article entitled The Politics of Australian Democracy that Senator Chaney referred to earlier:

Responsible government requires a high standard of integrity. The ancient maxim that those who rule others should first be able to rule themselves is still relevant. Those entrusted with public office need to be excessively scrupulous in their public behaviour because public contempt for an individual minister may easily produce contempt for his authority and office.
A further quote:

Resignation is still a valid sanction where ministers have been indiscreet or arbitrary in exercising power. In cases where the minister has misled parliament, condoned or authorised a blatantly unreasonable use of executive power, or more vaguely, where the minister's behaviour contravenes established standards of morality, resignation or dismissal is the appropriate action.

Where a minister's judgment, discretion or conduct are impugned, he may resign not merely as an admission of guilt, but in order that his fault (or alleged fault) does not endanger the integrity of the Government as a whole.

In a case of ministerial misconduct, there is more to be lost by trying to explain it away. Requiring the minister to resign is a symbolic act by which the Government is able to dissociate itself publicly from the misconduct in question. The public usually expect such dissociation from the Government. The Government usually looks to the Minister to tender his resignation.

Senator Chaney referred to the instances of Cairns and Connor in the Whitlam Administration. That was terribly important. John Brown, when he was forced to resign last year, in his letter of resignation said:
Because of my respect for the institution of Parliament, I feel that I have no alternative in all circumstances but to resign as a Minister.

More importantly, on 27 October 1988-last month-what did the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, say? This highlights the hypocrisy of the standard the Prime Minister has applied to the Hand affair. On 27 October the Prime Minister said:

. . . ministers must, of course, continue to be answerable to the parliament and to take any necessary corrective action. But the truth is that there is no requirement for them to resign except where a significant act or omission was theirs, or was taken at their personal direction, or was a matter about which they obviously should have known, and done something.
Our Governor-General designate, Bill Hayden, on 28 April 1982 said:
No minister should believe that he or she can flout the spirit if not the letter of the law as well as the high standards of propriety demanded of public office.

They are all quotes that should be read and studied intimately and quickly by Minister Hand. He has no alternative but to resign and the Prime Minister has no alternative but to sack him. What have we seen today with regard to Mr Hand and the detriment he is causing to Aboriginal Australians? He is obviously the Minister who does not know anything. If ever anything was noted and put before him, it was certainly not understood. If ever anything was written to him, it was filed and ignored; it was obviously not studied and acted upon.

In this place in the last month or so we have seen the examples of the Charleville Housing Cooperative with the Minister's mate, Sugar Ray Robinson. It was a matter of audit; a matter of involvement of the Ombudsman. We have seen the matters of Nardoola and the Oasis Hotel in New South Wales, where special Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) deals and negotiations were carried on by the Minister as he went around and discussed those areas. We have seen the matter of the Middar dance company of Western Australia, where Minister Hand exercised undue influence on the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) and attempted to bypass the normal procedures of office.

In the last week we have concentrated on the supposed restructuring of the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation (NAIHO). In all of the evidence put before us in this last week there has not been one bit of paper about the restructuring that is supposed to have been in place since January this year. We have seen what has been going on. Very obviously, the previous Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Holding, attempted to clear out the crooks from that organisation. What have we seen in this restructuring? We have seen Mr Hand attempting to find ways to put them back on the payroll.

Since May this year, when the Aboriginal Development Commission was restructured-or should I say perestroikaed-by the Minister by putting his mate into the Commission, we have seen nothing but a complex and very suspicious board operating with all sorts of hidden agendas, without proper authority, without answering to the Minister, and obviously with backroom deals being done.

Yesterday in this place Senator Tate tabled an apology from the Acting General Manager of the Aboriginal Development Commission with regard to legal opinions for Tranby College. Let me remind the Senate that the essential issue around Tranby College is not this series of legal opinions but rather the allocation of some $500,000 of taxpayers' money to promote the Aboriginal treaty. That was initiated by Mr Hand at the Barunga festival in the middle of this year, when he put a ring in the nose of the Prime Minister, led him around the events, made a commitment and then came back. We saw one of the new commissioners of the ADC, Pat Dodson, march off to the next meeting of the ADC and demand and get $500,000 for Tranby College. At that stage there was no paperwork, no consideration.

We now see a litany of change of legal opinions in these legal documents that were tabled yesterday. The most concerning thing I find in them is that they were done again without the Minister's authority or without the authority of the Commission. They were instituted by the Deputy Chairman, Pat Dodson, the mate of the Minister. Mr Dodson bypassed the Commission and got his mate Michael Stewart on the staff of the Commission so he could keep in touch with his contacts. The Chairman of the ADC, Mrs McPherson, was completely bypassed-as was everybody else.

A free for favour legal opinion by a Queen's Counsel has been called into question by the principal legal officers of the ADC. Senator Tate has been forced to eat humble pie, because he came back here yesterday and apologised to the Senate for misleading it and for putting information through this place in such an unusual way. The fact that Tranby College had that half a million dollars allocated to it by such unconventional means, and by mates of the Minister, should tell the Prime Minister something about the way in which this whole Department is being administered. The Hand administration has involved nothing but by-passing the Department. A series of events indicate that Hand himself is forever by-passing the Department.

Let me take the Senate to the Budget Estimates for this year that were looked at by Senate Estimates committees. The former Minister, Mr Holding, allocated $460,000 in the financial year 1986-87 under the special financial program for the engagement of consultants. What do we have this financial year under Mr Hand? We have an allocation of $1.8m to engage consultants-a 300 per cent increase. This has nothing to do with the other Budget allocations of the normal national consultative program or the promotion of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission; it results from the way in which Minister Hand has bypassed and insulted the mechanisms available to him within the bureaucracy of his Department.

Similarly, what about his relationship with the land council network? He has used the land councils in the Northern Territory-the Northern Land Council and the Central Land Council-as his policy unit. Perhaps I should say he has used these councils and their staffs as an alternative Public Service-as a shadowing Department of Aboriginal Affairs. He has relied totally on the many people in that area linked to him. The Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs has posed a number of questions recently about the Minister's movement around the country when he was promoting ATSIC. I quote one of those questions:

Did any of those approaches result in Ministerial or Departmental decisions, or commitments, to increase funding beyond what had been budgeted or committed up to the time the approach was made? If so, what was the community, the approach, the decision and the amount involved in each case?

The answer tabled by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs is horrifying. Of 93 approaches-approaches made while the Minister was out doing something political-involving additional or new funding, 21 have subsequently resulted in additional or new funds being granted after the projects were subjected to the Department's established process for appraisal and funding. These are set out in a schedule. So 21 additional jobs have been favoured by Minister Hand as he marched around the country trying to sell ATSIC to his mates. How much did he give? He dipped into the bin for this financial year to the tune of $457,536. He has precommitted for next financial year $239,683, and for the year after that he has precommitted $110,780. So the Minister has made a budgeting commitment of $800,000. It is no wonder that the Canberra Times editorial drew comparisons between Minister Hand and Gordon Bryant, because Bryant also had the same philosophy of walking around the country with a chequebook in his hand and passing out the dough as he went. Minister Hand has done nothing but demonstrate that the Labor Government is indulging in chequebook, on the run policy making. If the Prime Minister is condoning this form of administration, I believe he is adopting a totally wrong attitude.

There have been many instances where Hand has not acted as the Minister but as a mate. He acts as a mate to anyone who will scratch his back. What is his job at the moment? What is he looking at? Senator Button said that we are going to throw a few more things at Minister Hand in the coming week. I hope we do. But if Mr Hand remains Minister, the Prime Minister has to recognise that Gerry Hand will be the Minister for coordinating inquiries. He has in place seven major inquiries now, four of which are within the Public Service. The Prime Minister has put in place inquiries by the Auditor-General, the Public Service Commissioner, the Department of Finance and a Mr Menzies to back him up. They are all going to report in February or March. If honourable senators think these debates are light on, they can just wait until those reports come in and Hand is sitting in the dock. We will go through all this again if he is still in office. How stupid of the Prime Minister. There are also three parliamentary inquiries in place. We have the select committee of this Senate as well as the Senate Standing Committee on Privileges and the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs. Hand is involved in every one.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are these inquiries doing to Aboriginals?

—These inquiries are really upsetting their morale, and the various organisations cannot get on with the delivery of their services. At the same time, they do address important issues. We asked for one inquiry-one judicial inquiry-to be put in place which would have given protection to witnesses and would have allowed Aboriginal people and others to give evidence. Instead, the Prime Minister is backing his mate from the Left, this left-handed character who is Minister, by providing him with a whole lot of cocoons.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the recent times when the Minister for inquiries himself has asked for inquiries to be put in place-either within the Department of Aboriginal Affairs or independent inquiries. There are at least six, maybe seven, that I can count. He has put in place a special review of arts and craft. Senator Puplick asked a question in this chamber today about that inquiry because the Minister has put somebody on that review committee with very suspicious credentials, somebody who has been flogging off Australia's collection of Aboriginal art. Minister Tate did not address that. Mr Hand has that person acting as a special adviser.

The national Aboriginal health strategy working party will not report until some time next year. Yet behind its back Gerry Hand is running around trying to do some special deal for NAIHO. Last January the Minister told that organisation that he would not be able to help it until this new strategy working party provides some information. What a way to administer. It is total incompetence. He has commenced the Bonner review into the Pitjantjatjara areas of northern South Australia, Western Australia and the Northern Territory and he has the review of Aboriginal independent schools, the review of Commonwealth-State funding and the special interdepartmental committee on the Torres Strait Islands. All of these reviews have been instituted on Minister Hand's initiative. So he is the coordinator of inquiries. By my count there are 13 inquiries at least and there are probably a lot more that we do not know about in the Department and the ADC. How the heck can he be a competent Minister when he is running around with all of these reviews that have either been put on him by the Prime Minister or that he has initiated himself?

Hand's style of administration needs to be called into question. He certainly has divided the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the ADC. He has done nothing but destroy morale and tear these organisations apart since he has been Minister. We need to be reminded that he has dismissed 10 senior, prominent, involved Aboriginal people; chucked them out of office because they dared to put up an alternative view to his. He chucked out eight commissioners of the ADC last May. He sacked Perkins over some trumped up charge concerning the Woden Town Club and he has replaced one of the deputy secretaries of the Department, Rob Winroe, by shuffling the pack and putting Winroe further down than what was expected.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about O'Brien?

—What has the Minister done to O'Brien and Shirley McPherson? How have they been dealt with in the ADC? I agree with Senator Boswell. Minister Hand has not got involved in the proper exercising of ministerial responsibility. He is an insult to the good, sound staff of the Department and the ADC-the 95 per cent of the staff of those authorities who are seeking to get on with their jobs and who do a good job. There are many fine Aboriginal leaders in that group who have emerged to responsibility, but because of the way in which this Minister has stuffed up the administration of his Department he has put all their careers and their futures totally at risk.

SPEECH.PARA: We need only look at what is currently happening in the ADC. Today I asked questions about whether there would be any form of Public Service restructuring in the next week or so. I certainly hope that there will not be. I was made aware that there had been various discussions with unions in this area very recently. But the fact is that, in the last couple of months, 10 senior officers of the ADC have either resigned, have been pushed out, or are contemplating alternative employment. They have been stripped off from the top. How can we relate to that with any confidence?

We would love to know what is happening in the senior echelons of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, either in Canberra or in the regional offices. The way in which many senior officers have been treated is an insult to them. It is the Minister who is devoid of skills; not the people in the Public Service or the commissioners of the ADC. It is the Minister who is forcing so many of these people to quit. I wish to quote from an article in today's Canberra Times which referred to the remarks of Senator Coulter of the Australian Democrats as follows:
. . . Senator John Coulter, said he thought Mr Hand was getting into trouble because he had surrounded himself with a group of advisers and `yes' men who had played down some information.
We also find in the Canberra Times this statement:

. . . Mr Hand's acknowledged ALP left-wing credentials ensured he had a long-standing relationship with many of the more influential Aboriginal lobby groups and not necessarily those aligned with Mr Perkins.

The Minister has surrounded himself with sycophants and fools. That is the way in which he is seeking to administer his Department. If the Prime Minister does not take this into account, he need only look at the Minister's personal staff. Whilst I know that it is the prerogative of any Minister to recruit to his staff people with political sympathies and loyalties on which he can rely, at the same time he should always be mindful of the qualities of those ministerial officers.

It is interesting to note in looking at the Minister's staff list in the telephone directory that at the moment there is a great black line through the name Jackamos. Jackamos was the Secretary of the Woden Town Club who supposedly did not tell the Minister about the degree of funding in that case. A number of others in the Minister's office are Australian Labor Party apparatchiks but some of them have held particularly operative positions in the ALP Left, and that is where they ought to be-back in the branch divisions, back in Melbourne. What about Neil Andrews, a principal private secretary-former lawyer of the Central Land Council? He was the guy who wrote the letter to the staff of Senator Reynolds earlier this year which was a conspiracy against the Northern Territory Government. It was shameful. What about Rob Riley, who is linked with the Tranby College event and the national coalition of Aboriginal organisations-a mate of Pat Dodson and a mate of all the other lefties who are linked to Minister Hand? He was Chairman of the National Aboriginal Conference prior to its liquidation, which cost many millions of dollars of taxpayers' funds. What about Harriet Swift, who also goes under the name Valerie Binns? She is a very strong Labor Party- person-the lady who threw eggs at Governor-General Kerr. These are important criteria that the Prime Minister should be looking at. He should be looking at the way in which Hand is seeking to run his Department.

The censure motion by Senator Chaney stands on its merits. This Senate must censure the Prime Minister for his failure to uphold standards of ministerial propriety and responsibility. It must censure him for his failure to uphold the principles concerning the misleading of parliament and it must censure him for his failure to ensure the orderly and proper administration of the Department and the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it a very important motion-at least, important in the forms of the Senate, though whether if deserves the importance that has been attached to it this afternoon I guess is a matter which will be finally judged by the Senate within the hour. The motion is:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate censures the Prime Minister for:

(a) his failure to uphold proper standards of ministerial propriety and responsibility in relation to the misleading of parliament by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in contrast with the standards adhered to by the Hon. John Brown who resigned because he misled parliament
(b) his failure to uphold even the principles concerning the misleading of parliament applied by the Whitlam government and
(c) his failure to ensure the orderly and proper administration of the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs to the continuing detriment of Aboriginal Australians.

When one reads that motion one has a sense of deja vu, certainly in relation to the first two parts because they speak of a misleading of the Parliament by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand). One is immediately aware that only yesterday this chamber had before it a motion in these terms:
That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Prime Minister to dismiss the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs because of his misleading of Parliament over the question of funding for the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation and the subsequent attempts to falsify the record in defiance of all accepted public service procedures.

What we have in relation to two-thirds of this motion of censure against the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is a reliance on a misleading of the Parliament by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, which assertion has already been dealt with by this chamber in the last 24 hours, when, having the evidence before it, it rejected that assertion. That is the key point. Indeed standing order 133-Madam Acting Deputy President, I have no intention whatsoever of asking you to rule in relation to it-states:
No Question or Amendment shall be proposed which is the same in substance as any Question or Amendment which, during the same Session, has been resolved in the affirmative or negative . . .

Unless, or course, it has been rescinded. As I have said, in relation to at least two-thirds of this motion we are dealing with matters which have already been voted on. The question of the misleading of the Parliament by the Hon. Gerry Hand has already been dealt with. If one looks at page 3597 of the Hansard record dated 6 December 1988 one finds at the end of the debate on the urgency motion put in this chamber and signed by Fred Chaney, senator for the State of Western Australia yesterday, this final paragraph of Senator Chaney's reply to the debate:

The matter is conclusive. I commend the motion to the Senate, and I trust that this motion will be a lesson to the Government that the Parliament is entitled to accurate information from its Ministers.

The questions was put that Senator Chaney's motion be agreed to, the Senate divided, and the question was resolved in the negative. Despite the fact that the Opposition asserted yesterday that the matter was conclusive, and despite the fact that the Opposition wanted to teach the Government a lesson in relation to the purported misleading of the Parliament by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the Senate, having deliberated on the matter, having considered all the points that were put, having listened to all the evidence that was paraded and having accorded it the proper weight and value, resolved the question in the negative and thereby decided that there was no need for the Prime Minister to dismiss the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs because of his alleged misleading of Parliament over the question of funding for the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation (NAIHO) and the subsequent attempts to falsify the record in defiance of all accepted Public Service procedures. We have a very curious situation, at least in terms of what the ordinary, impartial observer outside this place would think. The matter dealt with yesterday in a vote of this place, which resolved in the negative the particular charge which is the central part of two-thirds of this motion has been revived.

As I said, if the motion had been put in exactly the same terms as it was yesterday, standing order 133 would have been invoked, and it would have been ruled out of order. But because Senator Chaney has changed a word here or there and added a new element, namely, the supposed failure of the Prime Minister to ensure the orderly and proper administration of the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs to the continuing detriment of Aboriginal Australians, this matter can stand as a matter that is properly before this chamber. But, as I say, the substance of it has already been dealt with. There has been no new evidence whatsoever brought into the chamber concerning the supposed misleading of Parliament by Mr Hand. It is a very tired re-run of matters which were exhaustively dealt with yesterday. There is not one jot, not one tittle of new information that has been brought into the chamber which would persuade any person who voted against the motion yesterday, to change his mind. What was repudiated yesterday, I am obviously suggesting, deserves to be repudiated today.

The fact is that Mr Hand did not mislead the Senate in relation to the decision as to the funding of the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation. I believe the auditor's report has been fully dealt with and, as I said, was the subject of considerable debate yesterday. One has to ask: Why, given all this, would the Prime Minister not deal with a Minister who he formed the view had misled the Parliament? That is really the charge that is being laid against the Prime Minister. The Opposition says, `Mr Hand is under the protective mantle of the Prime Minister because he is from the left wing of the Party'. I have never heard such an improbable, implausible, baseless assertion for the throwing of the mantle of protection across a Minister by the Prime Minister. It is absurd. It is a reflection on the Prime Minister's integrity in relation to the standards which he demands of his Ministers. Of course, I absolutely reject that assertion. Anybody who knows anything about politics in Australia, particularly within the Labor Party, would know that that is inherently improbable. For the Opposition to give that feeble and only explanation for the protection of the Minister is beyond any credence whatsoever.

The alleged misleading of the Parliament by the Minister has not been made out and there is no need for the Prime Minister to undertake the steps which have been asked of him. Therefore, he has not failed to uphold proper standards of ministerial responsibility. As we all know, the Prime Minister attaches the highest importance to ministerial integrity and regards allegations, such as this, made against a Minister very seriously. He has spoken at length with Mr Hand and he has reviewed relevant documents. The Prime Minister, after examination of the facts relating to whether a decision had been made by Mr Hand on NAIHO funding, is satisfied that Mr Hand did not mislead the Parliament.

Many points could be made, not least that it is perfectly clear that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs knew that it should not move on funding until it was authorised in writing. As for the audit report, the Prime Minister like the Minister believes there could, on reflection, have been greater precision in what was said in the Parliament, but the meaning and the intention of the words were clear. Semantic imprecision is not sufficient ground for calling for a resignation. From all he knows at present, the Prime Minister retains full confidence in the Minister and his integrity. I believe that that is a proper statement of the Prime Minister's responsibilities. It indicates that he has undertaken them with the thoroughness and care that one would expect, and that he has come to what is a defensible conclusion-defensible in terms of the facts and evidence as we know them and as the Senate chamber itself judged them only yesterday. I repeat-and it is the key point-that only yesterday the Senate, in possession of the same evidence, came to the conclusion that there had been no misleading of the Senate or of the other place by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. So the first two key parts of the motion we have before us purporting to censure the Prime Minister fall to the ground. That leaves the claim that the Prime Minister has failed to ensure the orderly and proper administration of the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Autrefois acquit.

—Senator Chaney keeps interjecting about one thing or another and he keeps contrasting in his contributions to the debate his supposed magnificent administration of this very difficult portfolio as compared with--
—At least we took it seriously. That is more than has been done on your side.

—The honourable senator may have taken it seriously, but it does not mean that he delivered the services he ought to have. For example, in the annual report of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs for 1987-88 I see at appendix 10 a table entitled `DAA Administrative Expenses as a Proportion of Aboriginal Advancement Programs'. Looking through the years, from 1972 onwards, one finds that in 1979-80 the percentage of administrative expenses as a proportion of Aboriginal advancement programs was 11 per cent.
—When was that, Minister?
—It was in 1979-80. If I look at the back of the report perhaps I will be able to find who the responsible Minister was at that time.
—Me.
—Senator Chaney says that he was the Minister at the time. In 1987-88 in relation to the administrative expenses as a proportion of Aboriginal advancement programs, it was 8.46 per cent.
—What is the state of the administration?

—I think you would agree, Mr Deputy President, that if one were making a contribution to a charity over the Christmas period in order to provide relief for the homeless or the destitute, either overseas or in Australia, and one was presented with the fact that one of the charities one was thinking of contributing to had 11 per cent of its money spent on administration and another had 8.46 per cent spent on administration, one would be inclined to choose that which provided more funds for the actual delivering of programs rather than that which provided more funds on the administration of the charitable agency concerned. I would have thought that it is quite clear that the constant claims we hear from Senator Chaney, that somehow his administration of the Department was in all respects better in delivering services to the Aboriginal people than is the case under the Government and under this particular Minister, fall to the ground when one sees a very simple table such as the one I referred to. It makes it quite clear that the stringencies which have been applied to the administration of the Department have ensured that a greater proportion of the moneys allocated and appropriated by this Government are finding their way to the provision of services for the Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.PARA: It is always very wrong to generalise. I would not claim that the present delivery of services to the Aboriginal people throughout Australia and their advancement is perfect, and I would not say that everything that Senator Chaney did when he was Minister was deficient, but I believe there has to be a balanced approach.

I could give many examples where the living standards and the situation of Aboriginal people have been considerably advanced under programs funded by this Government and which are part of the policy direction of this Government. For example, since 1984, the provision of basic essential services under the town campers assistance program has extended to 135 town camps. Since 1981, the percentage of Aboriginal students in secondary education has more than doubled. That is good not only for the individual students concerned, but, obviously, for the Australian community as a whole. For example, I know from our sustained efforts in Tasmania that the percentage of students going on to secondary education and going on to tertiary studies has steadily been increasing over the last three or four years in a way which is magnificent because participation in education is one way, almost a sure way but certainly a very important way, in which individuals can be lifted out of a fatalistic frame of mind where their horizons, their job opportunities, their opportunity to participate fully in the affairs of the country and sheer pleasures of culture that might be offered are severely hampered if they do not have a certain educational standard.

Almost 1,000 Aboriginal and Islander people now hold post-secondary awards, which is a considerable advance. The median income of Aboriginal and Islander people has increased by almost 70 per cent during this Government's administration. The Aboriginal infant mortality rate is still very high, and a great tragedy. Nevertheless it has been significantly reduced in areas such as the Northern Territory and Western Australia. The number of Aboriginal controlled medical services has almost tripled in the life of this Government. When one considers those achievements and others one sees that it is not correct to condemn, in a blanket way, the programs that have been undertaken under the administration of various Ministers in this Government, and particularly under the vigorous and concerned administration of the present Minister, Mr Gerry Hand.

To return to the motion before the chamber, the only new element, not dealt with yesterday-as I say, these matters were disposed of, repudiated and rejected by the Senate yesterday-is the claim that the Prime Minister has failed to ensure the orderly and proper administration of the portfolio of Aboriginal affairs to the continuing detriment of Aboriginal Australians. The clear evidence of the last several months, when this matter erupted as a matter of parliamentary concern, has indicated that the Prime Minister has taken all the steps one would expect to ensure the orderly and proper administration of the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio in so far as certain allegations and issues concerning that administration need to be investigated.

It is not the case, in all this, that the Prime Minister is making an assumption which would lend any weight or colour to the sorts of claims that are made-extravagant claims, I believe-by Senator Chaney, Senator Tambling, Senator Short and others. But, given the various allegations and assertions that have been made, a speedy and comprehensive method of ensuring that things were on the right track was required. It was for that reason that the Prime Minister, in consultation with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, agreed that the Auditor-General should examine the financial administration of the Aboriginal Development Commission and of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, and that the Public Service Commissioner should inquire into and report on matters relating to the staffing of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. In addition, the Department of Finance has been called in to lend its special expertise to the rigorous examination of the procedures of the Department.

It should be emphasised that both the Public Service Commissioner and the Auditor-General are independent statutory officers. They have not been restricted by narrow terms of reference. They have been sent in to ensure the orderly and proper administration of the portfolio. Mr Andrew Menzies has been appointed to deal, after the investigation of the other officers has been completed, with allegations which do not fall within the appropriate statutory functions of those officers. Mr Menzies will exercise an independent judgment in his role in these matters.

So one has a clear indication that the Prime Minister has exercised his fullest responsibility in so far as-obviously-he has not displaced, nor did he need to, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in the responsibilities he has accepted and is undertaking in relation to the administration of his port- folio. Together with the Minister, he has ensured that those steps have been taken to ensure the orderly and proper administration of the portfolio, or at least to ensure that the public can be satisfied that orderly and proper administration is being undertaken in the face of the series of propagandist, misleading and generalised slurs on the provision of services to Aboriginal people which have fallen from the lips of so many honourable senators opposite, none more so than Senator Tambling. Senator Tambling has shown an extraordinary blood lust-that is the only way to describe it-in relation to this matter as he seeks to get from one motion or another, or one committee or another, the scalp of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Only a few minutes ago he stood up and quite shamelessly admitted what he had been reported as saying in yesterday's press-that if he did not get Mr Hand by one method he would get him by another. That stands to his discredit. He seemed to revel in the idea that he was heading some sort of posse which was after the Minister. He also did grave discredit to himself by, in the last part of his remarks this afternoon, not only trying to get the scalp of the Minister but also bringing in a list of the Minister's staff, going through it and casting an unjustifiable slur on their integrity.

The motion before the chamber ought to be rejected for two reasons. As I have said, the Senate dealt yesterday with the substance of the question of whether the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs had misled the Parliament. It resolved yesterday that he had not done so in a way which deserved the intervention of the Prime Minister. To bring the matter before the chamber again today only just fails to be out of order in accordance with standing order 133. It puts itself in order with the addition of the claim that the Prime Minister has not tried to ensure the orderly and proper administration of the portfolio. I have demonstrated that the Prime Minister has intervened where it has been required in order to give to the public a sense of confidence that all matters which have been the subject of allegation will be properly inquired into. They will be, and I am sure that the result will be to strengthen the proper administration of the portfolio by the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Chaney's motion:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate censures the Prime Minister for:

(a) his failure to uphold proper standards of ministerial propriety and responsibility in relation to the misleading of parliament by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in contrast with the standards adhered to by the Hon. John Brown who resigned because he misled parliament
(b) his failure to uphold even the principles concerning the misleading of parliament applied by the Whitlam government and

The Senate has just heard from the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate. My summary of what Senator Tate has said would be along the lines that, in Senator Tate's view, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has full confidence in the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, and in Mr Hand's administration of his Department. I lean across the chamber to ask Senator Tate to confirm that in his view the Prime Minister has full confidence in Mr Hand and in Mr Hand's administration of the Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is disorderly to interject, is it not?

—Senator Tate is not able to confirm it. That is exactly what I thought. Although Senator Tate had the audacity to imply all the way through his speech that the Prime Minister has full confidence in Mr Hand and in his administration of his Department, Senator Tate knows, as all of us in the chamber know, that Mr Hand is right on the borderline of being dismissed by the Prime Minister if he does not resign. Senator Tate kept saying things about the Prime Minister's confidence in Mr Hand but, when I challenged him, he did not have the courage to say `Yes, that is right. The Prime Minister has full confidence in Mr Hand and in his administration of his Department'. His response to me was, `I think it is disorderly to interject'.

SPEECH.PARA: It is generally accepted in Canberra at present that Minister Hand has misled the Parliament. By `generally accepted' I mean accepted on both sides of this chamber, for starters. In other words, it is generally accepted amongst senators, whether they are Labor Party, Liberal Party or National Party senators, and even by three Australian Democrat senators, I believe, who know in their heart of hearts, that Minister Hand has misled the Parliament. It does not matter what they say in the debate, it does not matter how they vote on particular matters; it is generally accepted in this place that Minister Hand misled the Parliament. Not only is it generally accepted in this chamber, it is also generally accepted by the fourth estate, that is, the media. It is also certainly and widely accepted by those in the Public Service in Canberra, who follow these matters. They know that Minister Hand has misled the Parliament.

Many people around the corridors of this place are expressing some sympathy for Minister Hand. Apparently they are of the view that it is a difficult portfolio and that his heart is in the right place. I might add that I do not recall much sympathy for my colleagues Fred Chaney and Peter Baume when they held the portfolio. I suspect that most of the sympathy for Minister Hand is because, after all, he happens to be a left winger. That is why people are feeling some compassion for him: he supports their views.

In effect, most of the people in these groups believe that Minister Hand misled the House of Representatives in answer to a question by my colleague Mr Shipton. They believe that he misled the House of Representatives and that he then sent into the Senate a message which misled the Senate. These people also believe there is a third offence, that is, that he and his departmental and ministerial officers made an attempt to cover up this misleading by him of the House of Representatives. In effect, most people around this place believe that Minister Hand is guilty of at least three major offences for which he ought to resign or, if he will not resign, be dismissed.

On the other hand-and this is putting the case at its weakest-Minister Tate has tabled in this chamber documents which in effect acknowledged that Minister Hand misled the Senate in a statement which was read to the Senate on his behalf by his colleague Minister Bolkus. Honourable senators will recall Minister Hand's somewhat pathetic attempt to excuse himself for misleading the House of Representatives, which in effect scored him the double: he misled both the House of Representatives and the Senate.

I will not attempt to go through the evidence which is clearly before the Senate about these matters, because it has been debated at length. I could summarise it in perhaps three or four minutes, but I do not want to go on with that evidence except to refer to the misleading of the Senate, which as I said before, was pathetic. In addition, I put it to the Senate that the way in which the Minister misled the Senate was a clear indication of the breakdown in the communication between the Minister and his Department. It is clear that the Minister had not taken any notice of the briefing which the Department had given him right at the initial stages of becoming a Minister.

Mr Hand became a Minister in July last year. The initial briefing of the Department clearly pointed out to him that Arthur Andersen and Co. had conducted an audit of the affairs of the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation, that NAIHO had not come through that audit successfully, and that funding had ceased. Yet Minister Hand had the audacity to say in his statement to the Senate that he had never even heard of this document before and that it had never been referred to him. It was a clear indication of a breakdown because it was referred to not only in the initial briefing but also in the briefing given to him on 29 August, a briefing note which he signed acknowledging that he had seen it, in preparation for his meeting with the representatives of NAIHO on 31 August. That briefing note also contained reference to that report, but Minister Hand has so little relationship with his Department that he apparently did not even bother to read the Department's briefing note. That, of course, is the third leg of the censure motion which my colleague Senator Chaney has moved in this chamber today.

I would like to turn briefly to the relationship between the Minister and his Department. Senator Collins shook his head when I said that it was the third leg of the motion. It is the third leg of the censure motion because, as the motion reads, the Senate is censuring the Prime Minister for:
(c) his failure to ensure the orderly and proper administration of the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs to the continuing detriment of Aboriginal Australians.

That is what I was referring to. I would like to go on with regard to the Minister's maladministration of his Department. One must remember that when Mr Hand came into this portfolio he had had very extensive contacts with Aboriginal activists in the community. Many of them have expressed deep resentment of departmental officers. In fact, many of them have expressed hatred of departmental officers. Mr Hand, with his close knowledge of many of these activists, has in fact surrounded himself with them. He has surrounded himself with them in his ministerial office and has excluded officers of his Department from contact with him over various matters and from contact with these people.

The most recent example of this is the one that we have in fact been debating, when Mr Hand excluded Mr McDonald from the meeting with NAIHO. Mr McDonald had prepared all of the briefs to the Minister about NAIHO and had all of the intimate knowledge about it, going back many years. He had prepared the briefs explaining all of the problems to the Minister. He put forward in his briefing note the various questions which the Minister should put to the representatives of NAIHO at the meeting. Mr McDonald was excluded from the meeting with NAIHO for the reason that the officers of NAIHO did not want him present. Just imagine that: the officers of NAIHO coming along to make a submission to the Minister did not want the departmental officer there because he knew too much. He might prod them about some of their failings which had been exposed by the inquiry of Arthur Andersen and Co., so Minister Hand agreed to exclude the departmental officer.

I suggest to Minister Hand that he have a conference with his colleague Mr Tom Uren, because recently I read a report of Mr Uren saying that, when he was Minister, he always made sure that his departmental head was present whenever he was meeting anyone of any significance at all, and on other occasions ensured that other officers were present. That is very good advice for Minister Hand, who had apparently excluded his departmental officers from many of his meetings.

There is in the administration of government affairs a need for departmental administrators to be kept fully informed and for them to be present at meetings between Ministers and the supplicants of Ministers. We acknowledge that the use of conversational minutes of meetings may sometimes be burdensome, but they obviate the traps that this Minister has so clearly fallen into. If a Minister defies those conventions and ignores departmental advice, he has a responsibility to ensure that his directions are recorded and that there is a system that ensures his Department understands fully its riding orders. If Mr Hand claims, as he does, that Mr McDonald and the Department got it wrong, it is Mr Hand's fault, not Mr McDonald's fault, because that is his responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where was the minute from Mr Hand's staff regarding the outcome if he thought it was a different one?

—That is right. As my colleague Senator Stone points out, if Minister Hand claims that a different outcome was the result of his meeting with NAIHO, where were his ministerial staff recording the outcome of that meeting? They then had a discussion about the funding arrangements. As Mr McDonald has said in one of the subsequent memos, `as if we would have gone this far if there had not been an agreement to fund them'.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no question that Mr Hand agreed, on 31 August, to recommence funding NAIHO.
