Senator Collins is going to speak after me, so he may be able to explain why he is shaking his head at me.
—I was just wondering about the relevance.

—The relevance is that as far as I am concerned this Minister is going around conducting business in a chequebook manner; that is making decisions on the run, handing out money on the run. I do not see that it falls within the community program budgeting adopted by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh). I do not see that it is a matter for which the Prime Minister would say, `This is the proper way to administer this portfolio'. I believe it is clear evidence that the Prime Minister ought to be taking a greater hand in the administration of this Department. If the Prime Minister had bothered to apply his mind to the matters which we have been debating here over a period, I believe he would dismiss this Minister. We have had the Perkins affairs, in relation to the resignation of Mr Charles Perkins over a difference of opinion on the allocation of funds for the Woden Town Club. We have had the revelations about the wasted funding of the Oasis Hotel. We have had the Senate Estimates Committee discovering the $300,000 allocation for poker machines. All in all, we are getting an emerging picture that the Minister has failed in his responsibility properly to administer the Department. It is clear that there is now little trust between the Minister and his Department and that distrust must seriously be affecting departmental morale and the ability of the Department to perform its function efficiently. All of this must be to the detriment of the Aboriginal people of Australia. That is why the Minister stands condemned. We have the Tranby College affair where this Minister is constantly bypassing the Department. Now we are in a situation where there are seven major inquiries being conducted into the Department, or departmental matters, and there are six inter- departmental inquiries. All in all some 13 inquiries are being conducted. Let me now turn to ministerial responsibility. I adopt the words of my illustrious predecessor, the late Senator Greenwood who, on 13 May 1975, in relation to a motion of censure, said:

SPEECH.PARA: At the heart of our system of responsible government is the accountability of the Executive to the Parliament. Ministers are members of the Parliament. They are responsible to the Parliament for the discharge of their ministerial duties. Ministers are stewards of a trust and in the Parliament they may be asked questions as to how they have discharged that stewardship. It is of the very essence of the system under which this country is governed that when questions are asked of Ministers honest answers are given. The Parliament ought not to be misled. The Parliament ought not to be lied to. The Parliament ought not to be denied that knowledge which is essential to the proper government of the country. There are ministerial tactics by which an evasion of a question may be attempted . . . There are the occasional slips of tongue. There are the occasional mistakes. This motion takes no account of those incidents.

I agree with what Senator Greenwood said then. I also agree with the last sentence. This motion moved by Senator Chaney today takes no account of those incidents such as `slips of tongue' or `occasional mistakes'. I also refer to the attitude adopted by Mr Whitlam when he was Prime Minister. I compare his attitude towards the misleading of Parliament with that of the current Prime Minister. In a letter to Mr Whitlam on 2 July, Dr Cairns said:
I do not intend to resign from any position I hold because I answered the question in Parliament in the clear and sincere belief that what I said was true.
In other words, Dr Cairns really believed, when he gave his answer, that what he said was true. Mr Whitlam replied immediately, saying:

I do not regard these documents as satisfactory explanations of these two issues which I put to you . . . Since you write that you do not intend to resign from any position you hold, I must advise the Governor-General to terminate your commission. He will receive me at 8 o'clock this evening.

What a pity that Mr Hawke has not bothered to read A Certain Grandeur by Graham Freudenberg and to read Mr Whitlam's approach to the Parliament. That is one of the problems when a fellow like Mr Hawke does not give a tuppeny about the principles of parliament or the traditions of parliament and is only interested in the executive authority of government. In relation to Mr Connor's dismissal over the Khemlani affair, Mr Whitlam said:

I have made it clear throughout the life of this Government that there is one standard which, if departed from, must carry the heaviest penalty. It is a principle on which the integrity of the Parliament itself depends. There was, I believe, a departure from that principle . . . The principle and my insistence upon it was made amply clear, tragically clear, only three months ago, in the case of the honourable member for Lalor.
He was referring there to Dr Cairns. Mr Whitlam's statement went on:

In that case, and in this, there was and is no reflection whatsoever on the personal integrity of the Minister involved. The error of judgment in both cases was the same. The consequences of that error of judgment, the same, but let me emphasise, those consequences spring not from misconduct, but from standards in relation to a narrow, precise, but fundamentally important principle which this Government and I as head of this Government must insist upon.

There has been no doubt what Mr Whitlam would have done with Mr Hand. He would have done it some time ago. Let us look at what happened with the Hon. John Brown, the former Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. In tendering his resignation to the Governor-General on 17 December last year he said:

I had no intention whatever to deceive Parliament . . . I have been shown to be wrong on the facts, but my conscience is and will remain completely clear. Because of my respect for the institution of Parliament I feel that I have no alternative in all circumstances but to resign as a Minister.

Mr Hawke has often talked about the excellent standards of his Ministry. Under this convention Mr Hand should resign. On 25 August 1981, when Mr Hawke was considering an action by a Fraser Government Minister, he said:
. . . that if a Minister misleads the House whether deliberately or through gross incompetence he should, with any decency, tender his resignation.

Under that criteria Mr Hand should resign. In his Robert Garran oration on 27 October of this year Mr Hawke sought to redefine ministerial responsibility to occasions in which a Minister has been personally involved in a matter of administration. But even under that criteria Mr Hand should go because he has clearly been personally involved. Mr Hawke often talks about the excellent standards of his ministry. Ministerial standards are so lax that the tradition of ministerial responsibility under this Government has become a forgotten concept. I could go on with a list of very many cases where Ministers have not fulfilled what would traditionally have been considered to be full responsibility under this Government.

The simple fact is that Ministers of the Parliament should not easily discard either the parliamentary or administrative conventions. This whole sorry saga demonstrates the obvious failures in Minister Hand's administration. If ministerial responsibility means anything at all he should-I quote the Prime Minister's own words on misleading the House either deliberately or through gross incompetence-`with any decency, tender his resignation' to this House. If the Minister is not prepared to resign, the Prime Minister, even under his own narrow guidelines-the ones he espoused in the Robert Garran oration, which fall short of the Westminster convention-should sack Minister Hand for the incompetence he has displayed in the administration of his Department and for his misleading the House of Representatives and the Senate and for the attempt to cover up his misleading of the House of Representatives.

Why is it that so far Mr Hawke has been protecting Mr Hand? We know that it has to do with Mr Hawke's need to keep Mr Hand, the left winger, because of his relationship with the Victorian Labor Party and his Federal relationships here. He is concerned about the loony Left of the Labor Party in Victoria in particular, and the fact that so far Mr Hand has proven to be a rational left winger, someone that Mr Hawke can deal with, as opposed to the loonies, who might very well take over the left wing of the Labor Party if Mr Hawke gets rid of people such as Mr Hand. So far Mr Hawke has been protecting Mr Hand, not because of not realising that he has done wrong but because of political reasons only. Only for political reasons has he been protecting Mr Hand from the dismissal which should take place now. If Mr Hawke would only adopt the standards of Mr Whitlam, the Parliament would see some action taken forthwith concerning this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remember what you used to say about Mr Whitlam.

—I hear what Senator Collins says, but in relation to this particular matter and Mr Whitlam's realisation of responsibilities under the Westminster system he was as good as any Prime Minister of this country. If the present Prime Minister applied the Whitlam principles, he would sack Minister Hand. But never fear; I have little doubt that in due course Mr Hand will either be dismissed or will resign because the administration of his Department has now been shown to be totally incompetent.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to reflect on the third point of the censure motion, which refers to the failure of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to ensure the orderly and proper administration of the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs-and I emphasise the following words-to the continuing detriment of Aboriginal Australians. That is a very relevant part of this motion.

Before doing that I would like to read into the record a very short piece from a paper called Public Policy in Australia by Davis, Wanna, Warhurst and Weller, under the heading `Policy at the Centre'. These authors, who are political scientists, make the following point, reflecting on policy in Australia:
In almost all cases, Australian politicians have not resigned their portfolios whenever a mistake is made, though such demands are invariably heard from the Opposition.
Referring to a Minister, they say:

He will only resign if the Prime Minister believes it is for the good of the Government but in most cases that simply admits error and, party conflict being what it is, admission of error is more serious than the error itself.
They conclude:
Ministerial responsibility is a convention which operates only when it accords with political judgment.
In view of what Senator Tate said earlier and what Senator Macklin before him pointed out, I think that adequately deals with the first two points of this censure motion.

In turning to the third matter-namely, the Prime Minister's failure to ensure the orderly and proper administration of the portfolio of Aboriginal affairs to the continuing detriment of Aboriginal Australians-I think we need to remember the background of Aboriginal Australians during the whole period of white settlement, a matter which Senator Macklin was referring to before he left the chamber. We have a people in this country who occupied Australia for a very long period. Those people were displaced by Europeans only 200 years ago. The Aboriginal people were shot, poisoned, or displaced from their land, and their culture was taken away from them. Those conditions, as Senator Macklin was pointing out, continued right up until the late 1960s and into the early 1970s. Senator Macklin was pointing out that he knew people whose parents had been shot before their very eyes.

At that point Senator Stone was interjecting, `Take an aspirin; take an aspirin; take an aspirin'. I point out that one normally takes an aspirin for a headache or some minor ailment. It seems that Senator Stone's interjection clearly indicates the level of concern that he has for these very serious crimes which were perpetrated against Aboriginal people. He assumed that one could overcome the enormous emotional anguish which is associated with reflection on those matters by simply taking an aspirin. That says a great deal about the political context of this censure motion. I reflect again on the statement in Public Policy in Australia that the ministerial responsibilities convention operates only when it accords with political judgment. We need to use our political judgment in relation to this.

One of the things that have been borne in upon me since I have been looking after the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs for the Australian Democrats-and several other senators have reflected on this in this debate-is the incredible complexity and difficulty of this portfolio area. A number of Aboriginal people are still living substantially in their traditional way, associated with their traditional lands and supported by their cultural and political systems. We also have large numbers of Aboriginal people who are totally displaced from their traditional lands, who have lost links with their traditional culture and who are attempting to survive, albeit with great difficulty, in an urban setting. A small number of Aboriginal people have been well educated, have tertiary and secondary qualifications and are performing extremely well in the mainstream of white society. In attempting to administer the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs, one has to address all of those groups of people.

It seems to me also, looking at the history of Aboriginal administration, that there was just as much corruption-if one wants to call it that-maladministration and misappropriation of funding when the coalition Government was administering Aboriginal Affairs between 1975 and 1983 as has gone on since 1983. Indeed, one need look no further than the fact that the Aboriginal Development Commission was created by, and was a child of, the Fraser Government. I do not doubt in any sense that it was created with very good intentions. I think the intentions were absolutely honourable. Recognition of prior Aboriginal occupation was written into the legislation setting up that body. A capital fund was created by the Fraser Government to compensate Aboriginals for dispossession of their land. In 1975 a House of Representatives inquiry was held into the Aboriginal Development Commission. If one goes back and looks at the evidence which was put before that inquiry, one finds precisely the sorts of things which the Opposition is now accusing the Government of in relation to maladministration.

So I do not find the charge that the Prime Minister has failed to ensure proper and orderly administration to the continuing detriment of Aboriginal Australians a charge which is proven. I find that the Prime Minister and his Minister are attempting to administer an extremely difficult portfolio. Ministers on both sides of this chamber and the other place are aware, and have been aware for many years, of these difficulties. I believe that this Minister has been attempting to address some of these problems. I believe that underlying the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission proposal is the idea that Aboriginal people should be able to assume more self-determination and self-administration.

A quotation of what I said which appeared in today's Canberra Times was read into the record earlier today. I do not resile from what I said. I believe that the Minister has made mistakes in relation to the people he has chosen to surround himself with. He has made an attempt to go down a different path in relation to a very difficult portfolio which, over many years, has been demonstrably fraught with enormous difficulty for Ministers on both sides of politics. So, by the standards of the administration of the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs-and that is the only standard one can use to judge Ministers-I do not find that this Minister has performed significantly more poorly than other Ministers, and certainly not to the continuing detriment of Aboriginal Australians. For that reason, I believe it is appropriate to reject this motion.

Moreover, I believe that when one looks at the alternative administration and the clear indication by the Opposition that it would hand the administration of Aboriginal affairs back to the States, that it would mainstream Aboriginal affairs through State administrations, and that it would deny Aboriginal land claims, one can see quite clearly that the Opposition's alternative policies are certainly to the detriment of Aboriginal Australians because they do nothing whatsoever to recognise the unique cultural differences of Aboriginal Australians. The Opposition is attempting to look on Aboriginal people as if they were Europeans. They are not Europeans. They have a different culture and a different background, and that needs to be recognised. So, again by the Opposition's own standards, I find the charge that this Government is administering Aboriginal affairs to the continuing detriment of Aboriginal Australians rather false in view of the track down which the Opposition would take the administration of Aboriginal affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I get on to paragraph (c), I want to address (a) and (b) of this motion, which relate to the alleged misleading of the House by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, on 8 November. I state again categorically-any fair reading of the record and of the papers tabled in the Parliament will demonstrate this-that Minister Hand did not mislead the House of Representatives. Much has been made of the statements by Mr McDonald, and I draw attention to them again. The substantive statement from Mr McDonald was made on 2 December when he said:
The Minister then read me the text of an answer he had given earlier that day to a question about his `decision'-
those are Mr McDonald's quotation marks-

to fund NAIHO. I confirmed that the answer was accurate and consistent with my recollection of his advice to me after his meeting with NAIHO some weeks earlier. I have since read the relevant Hansard, which was consistent with the Minister's earlier reading to me, and have no reason to change my view of the accuracy of his reply.

One cannot get much more categorical than that. It all then relates to what is a decision. I said in debate yesterday, and I will say it again today, that I think Minister Hand's version of events and Mr McDonald's version of events are probably both correct. I have been with the Minister when he has visited Aboriginal communities. Not surprisingly with communities who rarely see Federal Ministers responsible for the vital needs of their communities, it is a theme of those visits that many approaches are made to Ministers. I have made many myself on the spot. For example, I went with the Minister to Yuendumu. We stood in front of a demolished set of public toilets in very bad repair. They had received no maintenance for many years and were in dire need of repair. The Minister said, `Those toilets have to be fixed'. I suppose I could fairly say that the Minister had made a decision to replace those toilets. But, having been in politics for a few years, I would not be silly enough to say that because I know perfectly well that, when the Minister had made his decision that the funding had to be granted, it would then have to go through all the processes-of finding out whether funds are available, whether appropriate contractors are available, whether the design is appropriate and whether all sorts of conditions attached to these things are appropriate. I am pleased to say that, after a period of some 12 months had elapsed, all of those procedures had been found to be appropriate and the toilets were delivered.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear! A good Minister.

—Hear, hear! He is a good Minister. The question is: what is a decision? The Minister has made no secret of the fact that he was predisposed to fund the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation in a restructured form. There is no question about that. But every document tabled in the Parliament very clearly reveals that all of the matters related to that decision to fund had not been achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: The one thing that is missing from this entire collection of documents, because it does not exist, is the absolutely necessary element in a ministerial decision, that is, a written directive from the Minister to the Department upon which it can act to fund the Organisation. That was never delivered. The Organisation has not been funded; therefore, that decision was not made. Therefore, for the second time in 24 hours, it is clear that the Minister did not mislead the House. Further to that, any fair-minded person would look at the context in which the question was asked. Mr Shipton in fact asked, `Has funding for NAIHO been recommenced?'. That was the question. Clearly, funding for NAIHO has not been recommenced. The Minister did not mislead the House. Therefore, paragraphs (a) and (b) of this motion have to fail.

But I want to address (c). Along with some other people in this House, I was sorry that the Opposition tried to dress up with a bit of cant and hypocrisy in paragraph (c) the reason for running this debate, crying crocodile tears about how dreadfully concerned it is about Aboriginal people. The written policy produced by the Opposition gives the lie to that. The Opposition is into mainstreaming services, removing any emphasis of Aboriginality from the delivery of services. That is the consistent theme of the Opposition in its written policy.

One of the most tragic steps backwards in Aboriginal affairs, from the former bipartisan support that existed in Aboriginal affairs in Australia, was taken by the current Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) when he removed any special consideration for Aboriginal people because of their status as the indigenous people of this country. When the Opposition first brought out that tragic policy change, that shift in direction, John Howard said, `We are very concerned about Aboriginal people in Australia, as we are concerned about any other disadvantaged group in this country, and Aboriginal people will get the same consideration as any other disadvantaged minority will get', thus flying in the face of the way that indigenous people have been treated in any progressive country, be it Canada, the United States of America or any other one cares to name. Aborigines have the right to claim special status as the indigenous people of this country who were cruelly dispossessed without any attempt made at reparation or compensation. They have special status but that special status, so far as the Opposition is concerned, was removed by John Howard. So let us see no more crocodile tears about the Opposition's concern for Aboriginal affairs. Let us look at the record of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, and his effectiveness as a Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Presently?

SPEECH.PARA: One interesting statistic about the effectiveness of the delivery of services is contained in the latest annual report of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, tabled in here only a short time ago. At page 112, at Appendix 10 one can see the percentage of administration costs--

SPEECH.PARA: We then get on to the crocodile tears that were also delivered during this debate about what an appalling record the Labor Party has had in supporting the unsupportable and the unachievable. The Leader of the Opposition referred specifically to the treaty with Aboriginal people, the compact, the makarrata, which are all names which have been applied to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —And national land rights.

—And national land rights, but the Leader of the Opposition did refer specifically to the question of the treaty. I was familiar with the negotiations over the makarrata because I was part of them. I was Leader of the Party at the time or the member for Arnhem or something-I cannot remember how many years ago it was now-and I actually travelled with the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, paying my own expenses of course, which took evidence at Yirrkala on the question of the makarrata. I remember that because of the problems that then occurred over the question of the name and what makarrata meant. Until that time makarrata was thought to mean a treaty signed between two people. It almost meant that--
—What it meant was a reconciliation.

—It does mean a reconciliation. What it refers to is the ceremony which, at Yirrkala, would normally be conducted down on the beach. If a member of an opposing tribe had committed a serious offence-which usually was stealing somebody else's wife-and war had broken out between the two tribes as a result, a makarrata was held where a representative of the offending tribe had to place himself at the disposal of the other tribe and be ritually speared to death on the beach. The elders at Yirrkala-and I was there when it happened-had a hilarious discussion about how they thought it would be entirely appropriate for Malcolm Fraser as Prime Minister to put himself in that role, and they indicated that they would be quite happy to spear him to death on the beach at Yirrkala if he wanted a makarrata. It was at that point in time that I thought that perhaps-and I might add that the Senate Committee came to the same conclusion-we had better go cautiously with this proposal if that sort of misunderstanding had occurred so early in the piece.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the key point I want to make is that Senator Chaney, the Leader of the Opposition, who was then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, fully supported the activities of the then National Aboriginal Conference in negotiating, consulting, seeking out the views of Aboriginal people around Australia on the makarrata. This is what Senator Chaney said about the makarrata in the Senate on 23 April 1980 when he was asked to define his Government's approach to the treaty:

. . . the concern which is felt by some Australians that the concept of a treaty involves the recognition, in some way, of two nations is a concern that the Government would wish to put to rest. The Government's approach to the treaty . . . is this: We are not looking at two nations; we are looking at how the Australian nation properly deals with the situation of its Aboriginal people. If we can arrive at arrangements between the national government and the Aboriginal people of Australia which are consensual in nature and which represent the views of the Aboriginal citizens of this country as to what is appropriate, I believe we will have advanced.

Those are fine words and, I might add, words with which I concur. It is not reasonable to say that the treaty that the Leader of the Opposition discussed in here in a statement in 1980 which I supported is going to bring down this nation; nor should it be properly held out as being an unachievable object which has been unfairly held out to Aboriginal people when in fact it received the full support in 1980 of the Leader of the Opposition as the Minister when he spoke in the Senate.

Part (c) of this motion also has to fail, as do parts (a) and (b). The achievements of this Government during its terms of office in the area of Aboriginal affairs have been considerable. Since 1984 the provision of basic essential services under the town campers' assistance program has been extended to 135 town camps-a crying need around this country. Since 1981 the percentage of Aboriginal students in secondary education has more than doubled. Almost 1,000 Aboriginal and Islander people now hold post-secondary education awards. The median income of Aboriginal and Islander people has increased by almost 70 per cent in the course of this Government's administration. The Aboriginal infant mortality rate, although it is still unacceptably high, has been significantly reduced in Western Australia and the Northern Territory. The number of Aboriginal controlled medical services has tripled in the life of this Government, which is one of the reasons for the lowering of that death rate. The coalition's present policy appears to want to abolish these medical services with mainstreaming.

The extension of the community development employment program to over 90 Aboriginal and Islander communities has been achieved around the country. A national health working party, to report in early 1989, has been established. A priority community development strategy totalling $49m has been established over two years. Special health initiatives totalling $13.5m over two years have been provided by this Government. Special initiatives for Aboriginal and Islander women and youth and special public awareness funds have been provided totalling $126m over two years. The reason I have included that tedious repetition of figures is that the one response to all of those commendable initiatives from the Opposition was a virulent criticism from Senator Stone, the then Opposition spokesperson for Finance, who attacked the increased spending on Aboriginal affairs. Opposition senators then come in here this afternoon and cry crocodile tears, trying to clothe this debate in clothing that it is not fit to wear. They are not concerned about Aboriginal people; they are trying to drag down a Labor Minister. They have provided this Senate with no material at all on which they can succeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief, because we have a lot of legislation on the agenda. I am surprised that, as members of the Opposition have indicated, they are not in favour of guillotines and are bringing other matters up at this stage. I gather that they will not be averse to an extra week's sitting and our being here until Christmas Eve. Be that as it may, the issue under debate is a matter of great importance and great concern to the Australian Democrats. The issues at stake are Australian Aboriginal people and their future. Looking at the censure motion put forward by the Opposition, I would say that paragraph (a) we dealt with yesterday at length; paragraph (b) I regard as irrelevant; but paragraph (c) I regard as important and as a matter which can be debated.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Tambling spoke of the policies of this Government as being nonsense, and he blamed the policies of this Government. I find that very hard to take when we look back at the history of governments in general as far as the Aboriginal people are concerned. Senator Lewis also referred to our being caught up in political struggles. I think that we are, but those political struggles are happening right here in this chamber at this very moment.

Having listened to this debate, I am quite surprised at the level of almost desperation in some of the speeches made by the Opposition. Senator Tambling showed no sign of wanting to be helpful or constructive in any way in this very difficult area of Aboriginal affairs. I was very surprised at Senator Stone's lack of sensitivity. He seemed to be disputing the fact that the Aboriginal people have suffered a great deal over the last 200 years. In fact, I know Aboriginal people in their late thirties and early forties who were taken from their parents and who still do not know where their parents are, because of past policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macklin was talking about them being poisoned.

—That also happened in the past. I was not going to go that far back, Senator Stone. I was talking quite recently with an Aboriginal person who was not a citizen as a child-and I am going back now some 25 years-and as a non-citizen was not allowed to be in the town of Carnarvon between 6 a.m. and 6 p.m. His mother had a job doing washing in the town. Because she liked to get there at the crack of dawn to get the washing out before the light of day, as they walked along the road from the reserve to the town they had to dash into the bushes and hide if anyone else came along the road because, as non-citizens, they were simply not allowed to be out and about.

SPEECH.PARA: Looking at paragraph (c) of this motion, I do not doubt that there has been some failure to ensure orderly and proper administration in the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs. I believe that this has been to the continuing detriment of Aboriginal Australians, but, as I said before, I do not think that this Government has the monopoly on that score by any means. Senator Lewis also gave us a list involving some thousands of dollars alleged to be misappropriated. I cannot condone that in any way at all. Neither can I condone the Western Australian Government's involvement with Western Australia Inc. and its activities, which no doubt will cost the taxpayers some millions of dollars. Neither of those issues can be condoned, but I mentioned the second one simply to place what we are talking about within context. It is known, and has been mentioned by previous speakers, that the coalition Opposition want to disband some of the special areas which have been set up for the Aboriginal people in the name of creating one Australia. We cannot be one when we all start from different positions of advantage or disadvantage. We cannot possibly have anything like one nation when we have people who are severely disadvantaged.

I stated previously that paragraph (c) of the motion does have some validity. I say again that I do have some problems with the credibility of the Opposition in putting up this motion. On occasions the Liberals in the Opposition-I exclude the National Party from this-have grossly exaggerated, if not totally distorted, the positions of the Australian Democrats and me over a number of issues. I have heard the Opposition-the Liberals and Nationals-speak against a casino for Canberra and yet vote for it. I have heard them speak for a non-discriminatory immigration policy and yet vote against the Government's motion for a non-discriminatory immigration policy for Australia. As I say, the issues are important. They are of concern to the Australian Democrats. The issues involved are of great importance to the Aboriginal people. In my talks with the Aboriginal people, I have found that the issues that are of particular concern to them are land rights and access to ceremonial land areas, the upholding of their language and culture in their traditional areas, education, and health. Most of all, I believe, their concern is to recapture their former spirit and their very life essence.

Paragraph (c) of this motion has merits. I certainly intended to vote on this issue on its merits. It is very difficult to do this when I listen to the arguments that have been brought down, I believe for political reasons, by the Opposition. I look forward very much to hearing what Senator Chaney now has to say in the conclusion of the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not intended to speak in this debate this afternoon, although naturally I fully support the motion that has been moved by Senator Chaney. But in view of the remarks earlier this afternoon by Senator Macklin, which have been subsequently adverted to by Senator Colston and, in a much briefer way, by Senator Jenkins, who has just sat down, I must take two or three minutes of the Senate's time to set the record straight on some of the more egregious exaggerations, slanders, defamations and so on which have been emerging from the Australian Democrats' camp.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me just recount for the benefit of honourable senators who may not have been present earlier: in the course of Senator Macklin's remarks he became-as, I think it is fair to say, Senator Macklin is wont to do-a little excitable and began recounting his version of the history of the treatment of Aboriginal people in Australia, not all of which redounds to the credit of European settlers in this country, but equally not most of which redounds to their discredit either, as anyone who takes a balanced view of these matters would conclude, rather than the totally unbalanced view which has been expressed by Senator Macklin and, indeed, was expressed a moment ago by Senator Jenkins, although I have to say, in deference to her, in a much more restrained manner. At that point, because I happen to have the misfortune in some ways of sitting in close proximity to Senator Macklin, I told him to `come off it', or words to that effect-I am not sure whether Hansard would have got the words-in response to which Senator Macklin became even more violent and intemperate in his remarks. Again, I note that that is Senator Macklin's behaviour pattern on such occasions: he begins to become more and more excitable, more and more declamatory and more and more-if I may say so-irrational.

At that point-and I now pick up Senator Collins's attempted reconstruction of events a moment ago-I suggested to Senator Macklin that he should take an aspirin and go and have a lie down. That is what I said. I said it for the very good reason that it did seem to me that Senator Macklin was in some danger to his health, given the declamation with which he was proceeding. As we all know, Senator Macklin then proceeded to accuse me of the most extraordinary attitudes towards the Aboriginal people of this country, which will be recorded in the Hansard and which will stand there to Senator Macklin's shame, not to mine, because the accusations which were made against me by Senator Macklin bear no resemblance to the truth. Even Senator Macklin, I hope, may, on more sober reflection, agree with that judgment. Having done that, he then proceeded to an even more infamous charge relating to what he alleged to be my attitude to Buchenwald. It was at that point that Senator Chaney, quite properly, rose and suggested that Senator Macklin might be given the opportunity to withdraw those totally-not merely unparliamentary-disgraceful remarks addressed to a fellow senator for whose attitudes in that regard he has not the slightest scrap of evidence; indeed, quite the contrary.

Mr Deputy President, my only surprise in all of those events was that Senator Macklin refused to take the opportunity which you, quite properly, then gave him to withdraw his disgraceful remarks. Indeed, he compounded the offence by saying that he would not withdraw them because they were true. I naturally regret that, as a consequence of Senator Macklin's actions, it was your unfortunate duty and the unfortunate duty of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) to initiate the processes which led to the suspension of Senator Macklin from this place for the remainder of this sitting day. I do not regard it as an appropriate event for this Senate to see a senator suspended, but I have to say that the events leading up to it I regard as even less appropriate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just before Senator Chaney makes what will no doubt be a most brilliant reply to the debate, perhaps I may say a few words. On this side of the chamber we are matching each speaker from the other side. That is because of the political exigencies of the situation. I point out that this is simply a political exercise. I do not say that in any derogatory sense. Senator Chaney would have to agree that what this is centrally and fundamentally about-I do not suggest for one minute that many of the points put forward were not sincere-has already been read into the Hansard, and I think it is proper to read it again. It appears in the Herald of Tuesday, 6 December 1988. Senator Tambling has already confirmed this, and this is what this debate is all about. He said of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand:

SPEECH.PARA: If we don't get him on this issue of misleading Parliament, we'll get him on others.

This is the first direct indication of the Opposition's campaign-of course, this has not been denied-against the alleged maladministration of Aboriginal affairs which began a month ago and has become a hunt for the scalp of the Minister. No doubt the Opposition will continue to pursue the scalp of the Minister.

It will be most remarkable when we shortly come to vote on this. If we are all exercising our individual minds, if we all take on board the various matters that have been raised, it will be remarkable. I can guarantee now that we on the Government side will go into one lot of chairs and the Opposition-I say, Senator Knowles, first to a woman and then to a man-will come across here. If this is not a political exercise, is it not remarkable that that should be the result? It simply confirms the sorts of remarks that shrewd political analysts have made over the years, and Senator Coulter has already quoted one. I simply say this, and I do not mean to be cynical--

TALK.START.PARA: —You couldn't be.
—I thank Senator Collins. It is a matter set out in Public Policy in Australia, a book published by Allen and Unwin of Wellington, London and Boston. It has this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Ministerial responsibility is a convention which operates only when it accords with political judgment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has already been quoted.
—It has already been quoted but it is worth requoting. It goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: In almost all cases, Australian politicians have not resigned their portfolios whenever a mistake is made, though such demands are invariably heard from the opposition.
What Senator Chaney has done today-and he has done it brilliantly, as he always does-is to add further evidence to that principle of public policy in Australia. I repeat:
In almost all cases, Australian politicians have not resigned their portfolios whenever a mistake is made, though such demands are invariably heard from the opposition.

Not only has this been invariably heard from the Opposition but on this occasion a record may have been broken. This week Merv Hughes from Victoria was making the headlines because of his record. Senator Chaney has broken a new record because he has tried to get a Minister to resign on two occasions. Today he has gone ahead and tried to get the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to dismiss the Minister. It ought to go into the Hansard; it certainly ought to go into the records of--

TALK.START.PARA: —But it was a no ball.

—It was a no ball, but I will give him this: even though it was a no ball he kept on with it. This censure motion was lost very early in the afternoon, but with considerable courage, considerable drive, Senator Chaney went on batting. Even though his jaw was broken he stood at the wicket with the bat and said, `I'm going to bat this out, because I've got to show the people of Australia just how true is the statement that censure motions-motions to get Ministers to resign-are very much political motions'. He has gone down that path very courageously. I will again quote from Public Policy in Australia, not in any cynical fashion but because these great political analysts have observed this over the years:

SPEECH.PARA: As a former minister noted, ministerial responsibility in practice means that `the Minister is responsible to Parliament for his Department to explain, and where error is shown, he takes the corrective action. He will only resign if the Prime Minister believes it is for the good of the Government but in most cases that simply admits error and, party conflict being what it is, admission of error is more serious than the error itself'.

I could quote further but time is short. The reality is that Mr Hand will not and should not resign. This has been an occasion of robust debate in this chamber. No doubt many statements have been produced which honourable senators opposite will be able to mail out to their various constituents-the most important constituents at this time being the members of preselection panels. I think that people have been rather nasty to Senator Chaney in saying he does many of these things because of the preselection for the new seat coming up in Western Australia. If that is so, I think he has done it brilliantly. He ought to send out the Hansard of his speeches to the preselection panel.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hooray!
—Senator Panizza would agree with that. Senator Chaney has attacked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs very well. He has done the job that his Party sent him out to do.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Tambling has gone well but he has to lift his game a little. He will get there if he lifts his game. He shows a lot of potential but he tends to go on for too long-as I am possibly doing now. In all the circumstances, this censure motion should now be put to the test. It will be defeated, as it should be defeated, because it is, as the learned editors of this journal have said, another example of a political exercise. Politically, the Opposition has tried to get the Minister to resign. Politically, he should not resign and will not resign. He will go on administering the affairs of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs in the grand fashion in which he has so far done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-If I had my head in my hands for a while during Senator Cooney's speech, I am sure honourable senators will understand why. After all, we are debating a censure motion, which is perhaps the most serious motion that can be put before the Senate. Senator Cooney managed to impart a lightheartedness that perhaps some other contributions have not brought. Not surprisingly, this debate has brought out some very strong personal responses, not least because there is a series of honourable senators in this chamber-indeed it is true in each of the parties in this chamber that there are such people-with a long and consistent and deep personal interest in the subject we are discussing.

SPEECH.PARA: The concern we have shared in very different ways is not the worthiness of Minister Hand or the worthiness of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) but how the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the policies administered by the Commonwealth Government with respect to Aboriginal affairs can be brought forward to the advantage of Aboriginal Australians. It is not something which has proved easy in any government, under any administration, and there are many blots on our history which we would prefer to forget. I noted in particular the points Senator Collins made when he raised a number of aspects of my own involvement in Aboriginal affairs. Those points in some way cast doubt on what was being done. It was interesting, for example, that he brought forward the representations with which he said I was associated with respect to the Aboriginal dance company, Middar. In light of the fact that this matter was raised, it is worth putting the story on the table, because I think it demonstrates that the Opposition's approach of trying to get to the bottom of what we see as very serious and significant wrongs in the administration of Aboriginal affairs under the present Government is not an approach which has been undertaken without a good deal of work being done to try to bring about change in a quieter, more positive way.

Middar is but one of the Aboriginal contacts I have had over the last year or so that has come to me expressing concern about maladministration. Middar was in desperate difficulty. I took only preliminary advice from that group but that preliminary advice from the people involved was in these terms: `Middar received a commitment from the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). We are a successful dance company and we wish to undertake a tour to the United States. We received an undertaking for substantial funding'-I think in total it was something over $300,000, but I speak from memory-`and we got a commitment so we undertook expenditure. We are now in debt, $170,000 or thereabouts, because the commitment was withdrawn, and we think we have been shamefully treated by the ADC'. I think that would be a fair potted summary of the interview I had with my Aboriginal constituents.

I would not normally come into the Parliament and talk about this but it is history now and the matter has been raised. I told the Middar people that I thought that on the face of it they had a case to make out but I thought they would not successfully make out that case by dealing with it in a political or adversarial manner. Therefore, my advice to them was to consult a Labor senator who I thought would more easily than a Liberal senator be able to raise such an issue of substance and have it dealt with on its merits and, one would hope, have the matter solved. I thereupon went down to Senator Beahan's office. He was not in but I discussed the matter with his staff. I said it was my view that they could be of more help to the Aboriginal people than I could be, and would they consider looking at the matter. I say immediately that I got absolute cooperation from Senator Beahan's staff.

I make the point that Senator Beahan and I had a brief discussion about this-it may have been in the lift; certainly it was in passing-and I asked whether progress was being made. My main concern was that the Aboriginal people might think that I had brushed them off. I went to some pains to say to them-I think I wrote but I have not had time to check-that if they had any concerns, they were free to come back to me and to raise those concerns, but I trusted that the matter would be fixed up. I have no idea what happened subsequently.

I make that explanation because the truth of the matter is that I and I am sure other Opposition people have raised many matters privately, dealing with them in a way that was meant to be constructive. I want to make a point in addition to that anecdote which simply reflects on this question which the Australian Democrats raise in a way which is, whether they like it or not, just as sharp and just as painful as any criticism that is ever made of them. They make consistent criticisms of people on this side of the House for their supposed dreadful attitudes. I have had a succession of private discussions with members of the Australian Labor Party from 1983 on, with some of the most senior people in the Government. I have expressed my deep concern at what I have seen as a lack of direction-I will come back to this in a minute-and my reasons for believing there has been a lack of direction. Two of the most senior people in the Government-I will not name them-said to me, `Don't bother me; this is not a high priority for us'. That is the response I have had from people in the Government who I respect when I have tried to raise these matters directly, quietly and constructively in the hope that serious errors would not be made. Private members of the Government party know that I have talked to them about the same matters and in a similar spirit. They would know that the response has been nil. That is the prelude to the quite determined effort on the part of the Opposition to get to the bottom of what we see as serious problems in the administration of Aboriginal affairs in this country. I make no apology at all for the efforts of Opposition senators to disclose maladministration, for example as we did in the recent Estimates committees.

Let me talk of the Kimberleys, where I followed in the footsteps of the Australian Democrats senator from Western Australia, Senator Jenkins. I acknowledge, and have publicly acknowledged before, her interest and also the fact that she has enough energy to get off her tail and trek around those difficult parts of Western Australia to talk to Aboriginal people and to listen. I acknowledge that many of the things she said publicly just before Easter of this year were things I agreed with, because she talked to many of the same people that I subsequently spoke with. No one could make that sort of trip or take an interest without knowing that the statistics Senator Collins read are but a part of the story.

Part of the story also is that in my State of Western Australia there is indescribable tension between the white and black communities. It is a disgrace. This indescribable tension impacts on the lives not only of Aboriginal Australians but also of those white Australians who live in close proximity to Aboriginal communities. Whether the Democrats like it or not, and whether members of the Labor Party like it or not, a major contribution to that tension is a lack of regard in the attitudes they put forward for the realities of life that face both black and white.

When I complained-as I complain without apology again now-in this place about the unrealism of the promises, the lack of reality, the staginess and the national land rights promises that were destined never to be fulfilled, it was because those things have added mightily to the tension that I describe in this speech. Senator Collins referred back to 1980 and quoted my comments on the treaty. The truth of the matter is that at that time, as Minister, I was desperately trying to reduce what I could see were the developing tensions on the issue of a treaty-the issue of two nations. I bent over backwards to try to move away from anything which could be used in a divisive and destructive way. Indeed, the word `makarrata' came from the National Aboriginal Conference (NAC) at my request. I said, `There must be a way that we can talk together without giving rise to this spectre of two nations'. The treaty does give rise to that problem. The Aboriginal people came back and said that makarrata is a Yolngu word, and it means a reconciliation. I said, `Terrific; I think there should be a reconciliation between the Aboriginal and white people of this country. If that is the word the NAC says is appropriate, I am happy to use it as long as we get away from the treaty concept'. That was my plea over a long succession of meetings, and they moved to makarrata on the basis that it was something which was about reconciliation. Those words which were read by Senator Collins I do not in any sense recant. Consensual arrangements for Aboriginal Australians were something I saw as being potentially a great positive.

We are now eight years down the track and the situation is that there has been a considerable increase in the difficulties for the Aboriginal community because of the national land rights campaign, because of the carelessness of the Prime Minister on the treaty, and because, in my view, there has been a lack of attention to the practical difficulties of administration. All of my response so far has been on this third leg-the question of administration. One of the things put up by the Australian Labor Party is, `When Senator Chaney was there 11 per cent or so of the Budget was going on administration and now it is 8.4 per cent or so'. We have been witnessing the failures of administration in Estimates Committee E, in the sorts of responses Senator Crichton-Browne got from the Government over the last few days. My heaven! There are more than 2,000 unacquitted grants. No wonder the Department's levels of administration are cheap. The more money the Government pushes out and the less it bothers to administer it the better its administrative ratio will be. I ask Senator Jenkins: Does she feel that Red Hill was adequately administered in the Kimberleys of Western Australia? Does she think that Oombulgurri was adequately administered in the Kimberleys of Western Australia? Does she think that the places visited by the Human Rights Commission and reported on this year or last year--

TALK.START.PARA: —Toomelah.
—Does she think Toomelah has been adequately administered?
—Do you think the Liberal Party can afford to buy votes?

—That is what we would expect from Senator Cook. All I am saying is that if Government speakers put it forward as a key argument that the cost of administration as a proportion of the Budget was greater under our Administration, I am not surprised. Let me read what Charles Perkins, as Secretary to the Department, had to say about unacquitted grants in September 1988-in a period when, whacko, the Government was spending only 8.4 per cent of the Budget. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I sought your comments-
that is, of State directors-
on a number of aspects relating to the current status of the backlog of unacquitted grants. I have since studied the reports you have provided in response to my request.

I wish to express, quote unequivocally, my alarm at the number of unacquitted grants. Put simply, the present situation does little to endow the Department's reputation in terms of discharging the accountability aspect of its administrative processes. I am therefore determined that the problem will be quickly rationalised and overcome.

I will not read on. I simply say that, as Secretary to the Department, Charles Perkins was expressing alarm at the failures of administration. Senator Crichton-Browne has pursued this matter. Will the Government criticise him for it? What do we find? Hundreds of things are being acquitted in a rush.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to criticise him.

—Fine; Senator Collins is not going to criticise Senator Crichton-Browne. I say that no-one should criticise him or the attempts of the Opposition to get to the bottom of what I think has been very slack administration. The Opposition has expressed concern. I have raised my concerns in speech after speech in this place and honourable senators opposite know that it is not a button off their shirt. No Minister has responded. Quite frankly, I say to the Australian Democrats that they will inevitably express their scepticism about everything the Liberal and National parties do. There is never any assumption of good faith in these matters.
—There is no good faith. You are run by the mining companies.

—I welcome the interjection. I hope that it will be recorded in Hansard. The honourable senator said, `There is no good faith. You are run by the mining companies'. That gets me back to the first two parts of this motion. Some honourable senators have taken the view that we were not entitled to move a censure motion on this matter because yesterday the Senate decided, as a matter of fact, that Minister Hand did not mislead the Senate. I refer again to the interjection of Senator Sanders. There is a closed mind. There is a person whose vote I would totally discount in terms of determining whether the Senate was misled. It would not matter what the truth was; that would not be what caused that senator to vote. He has his deep and abiding prejudices and he may not be bound by a caucus.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cooney, jocularly we know, questioned whether people were going to vote on the basis of the determination of the argument. I do not mind standing here and arguing with Senator Cooney but I know that, even if he believes absolutely that I am right, he will not vote with me. I understand and respect that the Labor Party has a caucus system and that is the basis on which the honourable senator was elected by the people of Victoria. I make no complaint about that. But I do complain about those who claim that they determine the issues on their merits.

I conclude by referring again to paragraph (c) of the motion, which refers to `the orderly and proper administration of the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs'. If honourable senators want to take an almost disgustingly narrow and highly political view of the future it is no advantage to the Opposition to see Hand go. Unless Minister Hand changes his ministerial performance he will be a goldmine for the Opposition. The serious point is that having a Minister who is a goldmine for the Opposition is not what I want in Aboriginal affairs. It is my wish to see Aboriginal affairs off the political agenda between now and the next election and beyond. I think that most people who have seriously engaged in consideration of this matter would think that it is a good thing. What is the basis for that? I do not think I need give a basis for saying that it would be a good thing because clearly this sort of thing is distracting and is probably painful for many Aboriginal people and many others in the community. The basis for having a bipartisan policy is that there has to be a policy which is operating within broad parameters that are agreed on all sides of politics to be reasonable and fair.

TALK.START.PARA: —And not jump off for opportunistic reasons.
—Not an uncommon scenario.

—I understand that. But there is a very big distinction between those cases, and cases where the Minister is directly involved and those relatively rare cases where the Minister can be said to have misled the House. Connor, Cairns and Brown represent that separate category where the rule is quite straightforward. In my earlier speech I quoted authorities as to why it must be so and I quoted with very great approval what Senator Macklin had to say yesterday. Let me repeat it:

SPEECH.PARA: Misleading the Senate is extremely serious, and so it should be, because we have to rely on what we are told by Ministers. That is the only way in which this place can operate. It is a serious matter.

That is a simple statement and, as the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray) would say, it probably does not warrant these hours of argument. But the Manager of Government Business would also know that, when the Government sets its face, the Opposition has only words that it can use in this place; so we have sought to use them. I do not think much more needs to be said. We saw the rule applied with respect to Minister Brown. We are not seeing the rule applied with respect to Minister Hand. I do not believe that the political reasons for doing that are justifiable and I do not believe it is in the interests of this Senate to regard them as justifiable.

I admire Senator Macklin who yesterday, I think with great pain, voted in favour of our motion because he was prepared to look at the facts. He had said to me earlier in the day, `You have not made out the case'. When we looked at what had happened in the Senate on Monday he accepted that the Opposition had made out a case. I acknowledge, on a day when Senator Macklin has said very cruel and hard things about my colleagues and has been ejected from this chamber as a result, that yesterday he demonstrated that he was prepared to vote according to the facts. I accept that honest men and honest women can differ. All I can say is that Senator Sanders's interjection was pathetic. I adopt that interjection as an explanation of why the Opposition does not believe that the vote yesterday determined a matter of fact. It determined certain alignments in this place. I regret that. It would be nice if it were not so.

Let me return to the reasons why we have brought forward a serious motion which seeks to censure the Prime Minister. Of course, those opposite have a duty to defend this Minister once the Government has taken a decision to keep a straight bat and to bluff the thing through, and they will stick by the Minister whatever. I can understand their coming in here and arguing the case. But the simple truth is that Gerry Hand, I am sure unintentionally-I think it was gross carelessness on the part of all the Ministers concerned, namely, Hand, Bolkus and Tate, and gross inefficiency on the part of Minister Hand's staff-without any doubt provided inaccurate information and made an inaccurate statement to the Senate. Barney Cooney and others were drawing a complete red herring into the argument. We are not arguing about that difficult area of ministerial responsibility which goes to the question of whether a Minister is responsible for the actions of his public servants. That is a difficult matter and I agree that, in the end, politics dominates the decision as to what happens to a Minister whose department makes a mistake. That is a very political matter. I had the joy of watching Senator Gareth Evans argue the case one way when he was in opposition and eat his words in government. He would probably say that he has had the same joy watching me.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister makes a point, but I do not have time to respond to it.
—Not in this case. I am thinking of another one.

—Let us deal with one subject at a time. Let me say that the 1975-76-77 period was fairly close to bipartisanship. SPEECH.PARA: The serious point I make in response to the chiding, if you like, to the concerns which are in many cases genuine and serious from the other side of the chamber about conflict in this area, is that we have to get away from the theatre. TALK.START.PARA: —While we are awaiting copies of the figures that have just been tabled to be provided to honourable senators I would like to take up a couple of other issues so that we can deal with them in advance of the consideration of the other issue. First of all, during the debate both last night and this morning Senator Walsh repeatedly stated that one of the major reasons for introducing the gold tax was the higher level of foreign ownership and the leakage of taxation to foreign countries, in particular to the United States of America. I have it on authority that that is not correct. In fact, the foreign equity interest in 1987 in goldmining companies in this country was only 18 1/2 per cent-half the level that the Minister has been speaking of.

SPEECH.PARA: This is significant in the course of this debate because, quite frankly, the Minister has hung his only argument on the basis of moneys going overseas to foreign governments rather than being paid to Australian governments as a result of goldmining operations in this country. That has been the only economic justification for the introduction of the gold tax. Nowhere in the May economic statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and nowhere in any subsequent statement by any Minister-certainly not in the second reading speech of this Bill-has any economic reason been advanced for the introduction of a gold tax, except that foreign governments may be the recipients of a tax benefit. We now find that the figures that have been thrown around this place for several weeks are in fact wrong and are indicating about double the real truth of the situation with regard to foreign ownership.

I want to reiterate that that information has been provided by the Newmont mining company and provides a different perspective to this question altogether. The information-and I have had this matter checked-that the Minister appears to be working from has figures on foreign equity ownership some four years old. They stem from the Bureau of Mining Economics. That information, being so old, of course fails to take into account the enormous growth in the goldmining industry in the last several years. We all know that there has been a rapid increase in both employment and the number of companies searching for gold in this country. In fact, the centrepiece of our argument here last night and this morning was that the industry is growing so rapidly, employing far more people, exporting more gold overseas and generating more export revenue for this country, and that, therefore, there have been significant economic benefits to the country. The Government should look again at its only argument on economic benefit stemming from goldmining profits being channelled off overseas.

Senator Cook, in the course of his remarks last night, which, of course, as we all know, were thoroughly confused and uninformed, repeatedly stated that the gold price was of the order of $520 and compared that with the cost of running goldmines in this country-about $300 an ounce. According to Senator Cook, he was inferring that there was a clear profit for goldmining operations in this country of something like $200 an ounce. It is remarkable that Senator Cook, who is the Minister for Resources, is so out of touch with his portfolio that he does not realise that gold has been selling below $A500 per ounce in the last several weeks. In fact, today's quote is $484. That has been consistently the pattern over the last several weeks.

The other point I want to mention-and this again emerged last night through the questioning of Senator Panizza and, I think, Senator Watson-is that the costs of financing the operations of goldmining companies, that is, the costs of borrowing money, the costs of installing plant and the costs of insuring that the operations go forward, amount to at least another $100 an ounce. We are talking of maximum profits of something less than $100 an ounce for goldmining, compared with the Government's overstatement and total exaggeration of something like $200 per ounce. In other words, again the Government's economic justification for the whole basis of this presentation of a new gold tax has fallen to the ground, both on the grounds of foreign taxes being absorbed by the United States and, of course, on the grounds that it has overstated the profitability anyway.

The other point I wanted to mention was that Senator Walsh repeatedly stated in the course of his remarks last night that mines operating in the country already have factored into their original cost estimates, in order to evaluate the viability of a particular project, a tax rate of 49 per cent, being the rate of corporate taxation that would apply from now on if this Bill were passed and became law. Quite clearly, that statement is wrong. Companies have repeated publicly-and I would like to mention some of the names of those companies in a moment in particular to the Gutman Inquiry into the Taxation of Gold Mining, although the Chairman has not got a record of it, that, if a goldmining tax had applied at the time they had made the investment decision to proceed with their construction plans, based on the information available at the time the mines would not have been developed. Let me just note some of those mines: Kidston, Mount Leesham, Red Dome, Temora, and Stawell, which is the biggest mine in Victoria. Those mines are some of the examples of mines which would not have proceeded had there been any indication that a gold tax of 49 per cent would be introduced.

There is clear evidence of the fact that the industry is based very marginally on its taxation situation. We have put down in the course of the debate last night figures that showed that the income of goldmining companies had quadrupled in four years. Export earnings have quadrupled in four years. Employment in the industry has jumped from about 3,500 to about 7,500 in the course of the last four years. Where then is the economic justification for the imposition of the tax? I say that particularly seriously because it is demonstrated time and again from the figures that my colleagues and I have cited and have provided to the Minister in the course of the debate-and these figures have been provided by reputable analysts and consultants who are chartered accountants with professional ethics in the industry-that the Government would have lost $363m in tax revenue in the four months to June of this year had a tax applied in that time.

That is the consequence of what the Government is now entering into. It is entering a period in which it will impose a tax to destroy, or stop the further development of, the goldmining industry in this country. It is something that ought to be refused by the Committee. I hope that the Australian Democrats will see fit to support the amendments which we have put forward.
