INCOME SUPPORT FOR THE RETIRED AND THE AGED
AN AGENDA FOR REFORM
This report presents the findings of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs' inquiry into Australia's retirement income system.

The Committee's terms of reference were to inquire and report on existing retirement income systems with particular reference to any changes which may be necessary to ensure equitable and comprehensive income security for Australians of retirement age.

This Report discusses the development of Commonwealth involvement in this area, highlights both the positive and negative aspects of the present arrangements and makes recommendations for reform where it is most needed. It also presents a model for possible reform of the age pension system.

In most other Western countries the retirement income needs of the community are met largely through a single, comprehensive system of national superannuation or social insurance. In Australia financial support is provided from two distinct sources: the social security system and the occupational superannuation system.
The Committee has reviewed these two main areas, and has made recommendations aimed at ensuring a more equitable and comprehensive income security system for Australians of retirement age.

In devising its recommendations the Committee has been conscious, on the one hand, of the need for a system of assistance that is both adequate and fair, and on the other hand, does not place an unmanageable financial burden on the taxpaying community in the long term, especially given the substantially different demographic structure and socio-economic circumstances forecast for the end of the century and beyond.

In its approach to the inquiry, the Committee has adhered to the notion that any review of the present retirement income system should be conducted within the context of the gradual evolutionary process that has characterised its development to date. The Committee has therefore recognised the fact that past experience has shown that where attempts have been made to introduce reforms which have required fundamental shifts away from the basic structure of the present system they have invariably been met with strong opposition from within both parliamentary circles and the community generally.

The Committee believes it has adopted a balanced, reasonable and evolutionary approach to reform and that it has done so in a manner which it considers to be economically and financially responsible and which will gain a significant degree of public acceptance.

In its examination of income support for the aged provided through the Social Security system the Committee has noted that some four-fifths of the aged population currently receive some type of assistance from the Government. Additionally, over half the number of aged people currently derive 90 per cent or more of their income from this source.

The age and service pension system is openly financed entirely from general revenue. The superannuation system on the other hand is only partially funded by the Commonwealth through the provision of deductions and other tax relief made available to contributors, employers and trustees of funds. These `tax expenditures' represent a substantial cost to the community in terms of revenue forgone and their impact is not generally understood.
In 1987-88 the cost of providing age and service pensions amounted to $8.9 billion. The estimated cost to the Commonwealth of superannuation tax concessions exceeded $3.5 billion for the same period.

In view of the generally low level of benefits received by most superannuants, together with the fact that only 8 per cent of the population aged 65 years and over receive any income from superannuation, and less than 5 per cent rely on such benefits as their principal or main source of income in retirement, it is not surprising that a large number of those who contributed to the inquiry questioned the effectiveness of the Government's role in providing financial assistance for the occupational superannuation system.

Despite disagreements concerning the amount of financial support provided for superannuation by the Commonwealth Government through taxation expenditure, it is clear that the level of assistance is substantial, currently representing an estimated 39 per cent of the cost of providing income support for the aged through the social security system, a program that supports a significantly larger proportion of the aged population.

In the Committee's view the prime objective of superannuation is to encourage self-provision in retirement. The provision of financial assistance in the form of taxation concessions should aim both to reduce dependence on publicly funded income support programs such as the age pension and fulfil an income maintenance function for aged people.

Clearly this system has neither diminished demand for income support provided through the social security system, nor enabled many aged people to maintain their pre-retirement living standards: goals often used by proponents of superannuation to justify continued government support of this form of retirement saving.

The Government has over the past 3 years made a number of changes to superannuation arrangements designed to put superannuation on a more secure long-term footing. The imposition of some vesting and preservation standards in 1986 and new taxation arrangements this year have reduced inequities but the Committee strongly believes that these measures do not go far enough. The Report identifies many problems with present policies, particularly concerning inadequacies relating to the vesting, preservation and portability of many superannuation arrangements and the widespread scope to use such savings for purposes other than to generate retirement income.

The Committee has recommended the extension of vesting regulation standards to encompass all employer-financed benefits and preservation of all benefits at least until the age of 55. Additionally the Committee recommends that lump sum payments from employer-financed benefits be prohibited and that pension take-up be enforced for this part of a member's entitlement. Lump sum payments from employee financed benefits should continue to remain an option however.

The Committee believes that it is not equitable to provide tax concessional support for personal saving for retirement and then allow such savings to be spent in ways which are not directed towards that end.

Another reason for regulating in this area is to overcome the problem created by the large gap between the age of compulsory preservation to age 55 and the age of age pension entitlement, which under the Committee's recommendations would become 65 for both men and women. The likely result is the development of a vast system of early retirement subsidised through occupational superannuation. With an ageing population this will simply not be financially sustainable. While lifting the age of required preservation from 55 to 60 or even 65 is a possible answer, this measure would cut across many schemes now offering the option of retiring at the age of 55. In the Committee's view, a more appropriate approach is to require certain benefits to be paid as a life pension or annuity. This has two distinct effects. One is to prevent the running down of a retirement benefit prior to the receipt of a government pension, and the other is to impose a financial discipline on retirees who must explicitly trade-off their early retirement against the much lower superannuation pension they are likely to receive, compared to working an additional 5-10 years.

In terms of membership eligibility criteria the Committee believes that if an employer chooses to operate a superannuation scheme and in so doing benefits from taxation incentives then membership should be readily available to all classes of employees, including part-time, and recommends the removal of restrictive membership eligibility criteria. Equality between the sexes is also recommended. The Committee asks that the Government repeal certain sections of the Sex-Discrimination Act 1984 to make it unlawful to discriminate on the ground of a person's sex.

The Committee does not specifically advocate mandating occupational superannuation at this stage, although it does not exclude the possibility that its use may ultimately be the only way to ensure that the coverage of superannuation becomes sufficiently comprehensive and fair to all employees.

The Committee has made recommendations which it believes will not only ensure greater benefit levels in retirement from this source but also lead to a better integration of pension and superannuation provisions for the retired and the aged. Greater integration is necessary to achieve maximum benefit from the large total outlays involved.

Reliance on the social security system increases with age and is greater for women, particularly older aged women, than for aged men. Furthermore, statistics indicate that single aged people, especially single aged women, are considerably more dependent on social security for their livelihood than married aged couples.

In this report the Committee examines the validity of the criticism levelled at what many regarded during the inquiry as the unnecessarily restrictive and discriminatory nature of the eligibility criteria governing the availability of pensions for the aged-namely, a person's age, marital status, period of residency within Australia, and possession of income and assets. In terms of age requirements, numerous groups who presented evidence to the Committee argued that the growing acceptance within the community of social and economic equality between men and women meant that it was no longer justifiable to treat aged women more favourably than aged men by granting them financial assistance 5 years earlier than men. It was maintained by others that the application of a differential payment structure whereby pensions are granted at either the married or single rate (depending on a person's marital status) discriminates between married and non-married pensioners, especially since the latter are often able to share accommodation and other associated living expenses.

The Committee assesses the adequacy of current income arrangements for the aged and makes recommendations to improve the level of age and service pensions and rent assistance and broaden access to pensioner fringe benefits. The Committee also reviews the current indexation arrangements for pensions and the taxation treatment of pensioners and makes recommendations for improvements in both of these areas.
The Committee also recommends changes to the age qualifications for age and service pensions and the rate of pension payment in relation to marital status.

It examines the inequities and anomalies in the present means testing of pensions and makes recommendations for the inclusion of the owner-occupied home in the assets test and a widening of access to the Pension Loans Scheme.

Finally, the Committee identifies the need for fundamental structural changes to the present age pension system and considers various reform options. A proposal is put forward for a two-tiered pension system which at one level, would provide a flat-rate, non-means-tested entitlement to all aged people and, at another level, would provide a tightly means-tested income supplement to those in particular need who are unable to supplement their income in retirement and old age from other sources. The proposal is presented in the form of a discussion paper and, as such, is intended to indicate the possibilities for reform, highlighting the advantages and disadvantages of meeting the income support needs of the retired and the aged through a two-tiered pension system rather than the present single-tiered system. The Committee believes the need for reform in this area is an important issue and one that will acquire increasing prominence over time as the population ages.

I have only highlighted the major points and recommendations presented in this report. It contains a much more comprehensive discussion of the issues and it points the way towards a more adequate, equitable and cost-efficient retirement income system for all.

I believe the report is timely in the light of recent releases of issues papers, discussion papers and policy statements on the subject and that it will add considerably to policy development in this area.
In conclusion I would like to thank all those who made submissions to the inquiry, those who gave evidence, and all others who assisted the Committee in the presentation of this report.

The statement read as follows-
On 18 March 1988 the Senate referred the following matter to the Standing Committee on Transport Communications and Infrastructure:
The adequacy of international terminal and aircraft handling facilities at Sydney Airport having regard to projected increases in passenger traffic through that airport.

The Committee received 42 submissions, inspected the airport on 15 June and held public hearings in Sydney on 13 and 14 July and in Canberra on 26 September. Fifty-three witnesses appeared before the Committee.

Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport is Australia's major international airport with more overseas visitors arriving there than in all our other international airports combined. The airport plays a strategic role in the New South Wales and Australian economies as a hub for tourism, domestic aviation, commercial activity and cargo.
In terms of total arrival passenger movements, Sydney Airport in 1986 with 10m passengers was ranked 36th out of 473 on the world airport listings.
The Committee received considerable evidence criticising various facilities at the airport and these criticisms are examined in the Committee's report.
I would like to focus on two of these criticisms. These are
the capacity of the international terminal building; and
the capacity of the airport to handle aircraft movements.

Since the construction of the international terminal building in 1970, the number of international passenger movements has increased markedly from one million in 1971 to 3.65 million passengers in 1987. The number of transit passengers has also increased significantly. These increases have placed severe operational constraints on the terminal building.

During the inquiry, the Committee was told that these constraints now result in massive passenger and public inconvenience, aircraft delays and long queues for passengers awaiting services at key processing points. One witness likened the terminal to a `broken down cattle-yard'. Other witnesses emphasised the adverse effects of the terminal on tourism and consequent ramifications on the Australian economy in general.

The criticisms of the facilities at the international terminal were so strident, it is not surprising that the Committee also concluded that the terminal is inadequate. The Committee also formed the view that even with the current $38 million program of improvements, the terminal would not be able to cope with conservative forecasts of passenger growth.

On 7 November 1988, the Public Works Committee in a report to the Parliament recognised the urgent need to expand the terminal and recommended expansion and improvements amounting to $214m. This Committee endorses the PWC's recommendations and welcomes the Government's acceptance of them.

The second major criticism presented to the Committee concerned the capacity of the airport to handle aircraft movements. Several witnesses maintained that the airport, particularly at peak periods was unable to cope adequately with the demands of international, domestic, commuter and general aviation.

This resulted in congestion and delays to arrivals and departures. Australian Airlines told the Committee that in 1987 delays resulting from congestion at Sydney Airport involved more than 1600 hours at a cost to the airline of $8.5m.

Various aviation and tourism organisations argued that these problems would be alleviated by the construction of an additional runway at Sydney Airport to be used by smaller aircraft up to F27 size. Other witnesses who appeared before the Committee were opposed to any expansion of the airport and in particular the construction of an additional runway, especially into Botany Bay. These witnesses maintained that an expansion of this kind would exacerbate existing social, environmental and ecological problems.

During the Committee's inquiry, the then Minister for Transport and Communications announced that Badgerys Creek would be built as Sydney's second airport and that a submission would be put to Cabinet seeking commencement of work during 1989. The first phase of this development would involve the construction of a substantial General Aviation facility that could be operational by 1993.

Given the Minister's announcement on a phased development of Badgerys Creek, the Committee's view is that the construction of an additional runway at Sydney Airport would duplicate an essential element of the Badgerys Creek initiative and would not be cost effective.
If the Minister's proposal is not accepted by Cabinet, the Committee believes that the option of an additional runway at Sydney Airport should not be dismissed.

Forecasts indicate that Sydney Airport will need to cope with increasing passenger and aircraft traffic. In this report the Committee identifies various options to assist passenger processing and air traffic demand management and draws these to the attention of the Federal Government authorities with responsibilities at the airport.

The Committee is aware that this report is one of several studies on the airport needs of the Sydney area. The issues involved are complex and technical. Nevertheless, the Committee believes that it is essential that those authorities empowered to operate Sydney Airport continue to monitor the airport's operations and standard of facilities to ensure that if changes are required they are implemented promptly and in full consultation with all parties involved.
The Committee extends its gratitude to all those people who assisted it in the course of this inquiry.

AIDC is a financial enterprise, operating on commercial principles and as such operates a continuous borrowing strategy which is directed towards achieving the most economical use of funds. AIDC's borrowings are used, in the same way as other financial intermediaries, in making loans and other investments in Australian industrial concerns. During 1986-87 and 1987-88 the net increase in borrowings of AIDC was $264 million and $27 million respectively.
AUSTRADE undertook borrowings in 1986-87 and 1987-88 of nil and $442.4 million respectively.
